alphabetical letter d d
The eighth letter of the alphabet: called daAlN. It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, not with the breath only]; and of the letters termed niTaEiy~ap [pronounced by pressing the tip of the tongue against the upper gums and suddenly withdrawing it], like T and t. (TA.) It is substituted, agreeably with general usage, for the t of the form AifotaEala and its variations, when the first radical letter is z, as in AizodaAda [for AizotaAda]; or *, as in Aid~akara [for Ai*odakara, originally Ai*otakara]; or d, as in Aid~araA^a [for AidodaraA^a, originally AidotaraA^a]: and sometimes after j, as in AijodamaEuwA, a dial. var. of AijotamaEuwA: also, sometimes, for the pronominal affix t after d, as in jalad~u for jaladotu; and after z, as in juzodu for juzotu: it is also substituted for the t of tawolajN, contr. to analogy: and it occurs substituted for T, contr. to general usage, as in maradaY for maraTaY. (MF.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Four.]

R. Q. 1 daA^odaA^a *
, inf. n. daA^odaA^apN and diy^odaA='N, He (a camel, S) ran (EadaA) most vehemently, (S, M, K, TA,) going a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN [q. v.]: (TA:) or hastened, or sped, and ran, or rose in his running; syn. A^asoraEa wa A^aHoDara: (K:) accord. to AA, daA^odaA='N↓ is [a subst., or quasiinf. n., signifying] a quick pace or manner of going: and [the inf. n.] daA^odaA^apN is syn. with A_iHoDaArN: and in the Nawádir [app. of Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee] it is said that dawodaA^a (inf. n. dawodaA^apN) and tawodaA^a (inf. n. tawodaA^apN) and kawodaA^a (inf. n. kawodaA^apN) are syn. with EadaA; and that daA^odaA^apN and diy^odaA='N signify a camel's proceeding with short steps, at a rate quicker than that of the pace termed HafadN [q. v.]: accord. to the Kf, these two words signify the going a pace quicker than that termed xababN [q. v.], not so quick as that termed rabaEapN [q. v.]. (TA.) You say, daA^odaA^ati Ald~aAb~apu The beast ran a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN. (M.) And daA^odaA^a fiY A_ivorihi He followed him, having him near before him. (M, * K, * TA.) And hence, daA^odaA^a minohu He ran (A^aHoDara) to escape from him, being followed by him, and being near before him; as also tadaA^odaA^a↓. (M.) ＝ -A2- He put a thing in motion. (M, K.) ― -b2- And, contr., He rendered a thing, still, or motionless. (M, K.)

R. Q. 2 tadaA^odaA^a *
: see above. ― -b2- Also It (a stone, TA) rolled; or rolled along or down: (K, TA:) it (anything) rolled, or rolled along or down, before one, (M, TA,) and went away: IAth says that it may be from tadahodaha. (TA.) ― -b3- It became, or was put, in motion. (TA.) ― -b4- And, contr., It became, or was rendered, still, or motionless. (TA.)

daA^odaA^N *
: see daA^odaA='N, in three places.

daA^odaA^apN *
inf. n. of R. Q. 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Also The hasty replying of a foolish, or stupid, person. (T, TA.) ― -b3- The sound of the falling (T, M, K) of stones in a torrent, (T,) or of a stone upon the bed of a torrent: (M, K:) or the falling of stones in the bed of a torrent. (Lth, IKtt, O.) ― -b4- And The sound of one's moving, or putting in motion, [or rocking,] a child in the cradle (K, TA) in order that it may sleep. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

daA^odaA='N *
(AA, T, S, M, K) and diy^odaA='N↓ (AA, S, M, K) and duw^oduwo'N↓, (M, K,) all with medd, (TA,) The last (of the days, T) of the [lunar] month; (AA, T, S, M, K;) as also daA^odaA^u↓: (M:) or the day of doubt; yawomu Al$~ak~i [generally meaning the day of which one doubts whether it be the last of Shaabán or the first of Ramadán; but here app. relating to any month]: (TA:) or daA^odaA^N↓ signifies the day, (M,) or night, (TA,) of which one doubts whether it be the last of one month or the first of the next month: (M, TA:) so says Kr: (M:) or the first word and the second (M, K) and the third (K) signify the twenty-fifth, and the twenty-sixth, and the twentyseventh, night: (M, K:) or the twenty-eighth night, and the twenty-ninth: or each of these two is called daA^odA^apN↓; and the two together, Ald~aA=diy^u: (Th, M:) or [each of] three nights of the end of the month; (K, TA;) which are [also] called layaAliY AlmuHaAqi: (TA:) pl. daA=diy^u, (M, K,) and, by poetic license, daA=dK: (M:) or the daA=diy^ are three nights of the latter part of the month, before those called lyAlY AlmHAq: (T, S:) thus says A 'Obeyd; and IAar says the like: or they are the three nights that are after the mHAq; and are so called because the moon hastens therein to become invisible; from the phrase daA^odaA^apu AlbaEiyri: As says that three of the nights of the month are called the mHAq; and three, the dA=dy^; and these latter are the last; and AHeyth says the like. (T.) Ald~iy^odaA='u↓ signifies also The last part of the night. (Kr, M.) And layolapN daA^odaA^N↓ and daA^odaA^apN↓ and daA^odaA='N and daA^odaA='apN↓, (M, K, TA,) of which the first two are the most common, mean A dark night: (TA:) or a very dark night: (M, K:) because of the concealment of the moon therein. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also R. Q. 1.

layolapN daA^odaA='apN *
: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

duw^oduwo'N *
: see daA^odaA='N.

diy^odaA='N *
: see daA^odaA='N, in two places.

1 daA^aba *
, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
daAa^a
, (T, M, A, K,) inf. n. daA^obN (T, S, M, A, K) and daA^abN (T, M, A, K) and duw^uwbN, (T, S, M, A, K,) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself; (T, S, A, K;) and wearied himself, or became wearied; (S, A, K;) in his work, (S, A, K,) or in a thing, (T,) and in a journey or journeying; (T, A;) in which last case, daA^abato is said of a she-camel, (T,) or of a daAb~ap [or horse or the like]: (A:) or he held on, or continued, (M, and Bd in viii. 54,) in his work, and his way. (Bd ibid.) See also 4. Hence, All~ayolu waAln~ahaAru yadoA^abaAni fiY A@EotiqaAbihimaA (tropical:) [The night and the day hold on their course in their alternating]. (A.) ― -b2- daA^obN (K) and duw^uwbN (TA) also signify The act of driving vehemently; and i. q. TarodN [the act of driving away, hunting, &c.]. (K, TA.)

4 AdA^b *
, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. A_idoA=bN, (T,) He made another, (S, A, K,) his hired man, and his beast, (A,) to strive, labour, toil, or exert himself; (S, A, K;) he fatigued, or wearied, (T, S, A, K,) another, (S, K,) his hired man, (A,) and his beast: (T, A:) or he made another, and anything, to hold on, of continue: and AdA^bhu also signifies A^aHowajapu A_ilaY Ald~uw^uwbi [he made him to be in need of striving, &c.; or of holding on, or continuing]: (M:) and A^adabuwA is used by a rájiz, but not necessarily by poetic license, for A^adoA^abuwA. (IAar, M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AdA^b Als~ayora [He pursued the journey laboriously, or with energy; or he held on, or continued, the journey]: (S, M, L, K, in art. msd; and M and L in art. sA^d:) and [in like manner] you say, sayoranaA daA^abonaA↓ [for
fiY sayorinaA, or perhaps fY is omitted by inadvertence]. (TA in art. nHb.)

daA^obN *
(T, S, M, A, K) and daA^abN↓ (S, M, K) [both originally inf. ns. of 1: and hence,] (tropical:) A custom, manner, habit, or wont: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K:) an affair, a business, or a concern: (Zj, T, S, A, K:) and a case, state, or condition: (Zj, * T, * S, * M, A, * K: *) and a deed, or work. (A.) You say, h`*aA daA^obuka (tropical:) This is [thy custom, &c.:] thy affair, business, or concern: or thy case, state, or condition: and thy deed, or work. (A.) Zj says that kadaA^obi A=li firoEawona [in the Kur iii. 9 &c.] means, accord. to the lexicologists, (assumed tropical:) Like the case of the people of Pharaoh: but in his opinion, like the striving, labouring, or toiling, of the people of Pharaoh in their unbelief, and their leaguing together and aiding one another against Moses. (T.)

daA^aba *
: see the next preceding paragraph.

day^ibN *
: see daAy^ibN.

rajulN daw^uwbN EalaY $aYo'K *
[A man who strives, labours, toils, or exerts himself, and wearies himself, or who holds on, or continues, with energy, to do a thing]. (M.)

daAy^ibN *
(TA, and so in a copy of the S,) and day^ibN↓ (TA, and so in two copies of the S,) Striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, and wearying himself, in his work [&c.: or holding on, or continuing, therein: see the verb]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] layolapN daAy^ibapN [A hard, fatiguing, or continuous, night-journey]. (M and K in art. mrs.) ― -b3- And Ald~aAy^ibaAni (tropical:) The night and the day; (S, A, K;) which [are so called because they] hold on their course (yadoA^abaAni) in their alternating. (TA.)

1 daA^ala *
, aor.
daAa^a
, inf. n. daA^olN (S, M, K) and daA^alN (K [perhaps a mistake for the next, which is well known but not mentioned in the K, but see *aA^ala,]) and daA^alaAnN (S, M) and daA^alaY, (M, K,) He walked, or went, in a weak manner, (M, K,) and with haste: (M:) or he ran with short steps: (M, K:) or he walked, or went, in a brisk, or sprightly, manner: (K:) or he walked, or went, as though labouring in his gait, by reason of briskness, or sprightliness: (M:) [or he went along by little and little, stealthily, lest he should make a sound to be heard: for] daA^olN is syn. with xatolN: or, accord. to AZ, it signifies the walking, or going, in a manner resembling that which is termed xatolN; and in the manner of him who is heavily burdened, or overburdened: and As, in describing the manner in which horses go, explains daA^alaAnN as signifying the walking, or going, with short steps, and in an unusual manner, as though heavily burdened, or overburdened. (S.) [See also *aA^ala.] ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] daA^ala lahu, aor. as above, inf. n. daA^olN and daA^alaAnN, He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; syn. xatalahu: (M, K:) [and daAA^alahu↓ signifies the same: or he practised with him mutual deceit, delusion, &c.: for] mudaAA^alapN is syn. with muxaAtalapN; and sometimes it is with a quick pace: (AA, T, K:) you say, daA^alotu lahu and daAA^alotuhu: (AA, T, TA:) and Al*~iy^obu badoA^alu lilogazaAli liyaA^okulahu i. e. yaxotuluhu [The wolf deceives, &c., the gazelle, or young gazelle, that he may eat him]. (AZ, T, TA.)

3 daA~a^a
see the last sentence of the paragraph above.

daA^olN *
: see the next paragraph, in four places.

duw^ulN *
: see the next paragraph, in four places.

duy^ilN *
, and sometimes it is pronounced duw^ulN↓, The jackal; as also daA^alaAnN↓ and daA^olN↓: and the wolf: and a certain small animal resembling what is called Aibonu EirosK [the weasel]: (K accord. to the TA: [accord. to the CK, and app. most MS. copies of the K, daA^olN↓ has the last two significations, and not the first signification: but this is inconsistent with what follows the last signification in the K, as it would require us to read that Ald~aA^olu, instead of Ald~uy^ilu, which is well known as the correct form, is the name of the father of a certain tribe:]) duy^ilN has the last of these significations: (T, S:) or it signifies a certain small animal resembling the fox; and this is well known: and accord. to Kr. duw^ulN↓ signifies a certain small animal; but this is not known: and accord. to him also, daA^alaAnN↓, with fet-h to the ', signifies the wolf; (M;) as also *aA^alaAnN; (TA;) or so daA^olaAnN↓ and *aA^olaAnN; and also the jackal. (Lth in art. *A^l.) duy^ilN is the only instance of the measure fuEilN (S, K) known to Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, (S,) i. e. Th: (TA:) but there are several other instances: (MF, TA:) [one of these is ruy^imN, or Alr~uy^imu.]

daA^olaAnN *
and daA^alaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

duw^oluwlN *
A calamity, or misfortune: (S, M, O, K:) pl. daA=liylu. (S.) And Confusion. (K.) You say, waqaEa Alqawomu fiY duw^oluwlK The people, or party, fell into confusion in respect of their case or affairs. (S.)

daw^uwlN *
[That runs in the manner termed daA^alaAnN, inf. n. of 1,] is [an epithet] from AldAlAn [i. e. Ald~aA^alaAnu], which signifies a kind of running, as also daA^Alyn↓ and dAAlyl↓ [i. e. daA=liynu and daA=lylu, pls. of daA^alaAnN; the latter irreg., like *aA=liylu pl. of daA^alaAnN, q. v.]. (Ham p. 458.) [See also *aw^uwlN.]

daA=liylu dA=lyl
and daA=liynu: see what next precedes.

1 daA^aA *
, first pers. daA^awotu, aor. yadoA^aY, inf. n. daA^owN: see 1 in the next art.

1 daA^aY *
, and daA^aA, aor. yadoA^aY, (T, M, K,) inf. n. daA^oYN, (T, M,) of the former verb, (M,) and daA^owN, (T, K,) of the latter verb, (K,) said of a wolf, (M, K,) [and of a man, as shown below,] He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him. (T, M, K.) You say, daA^ayotu lahu, (S, K,) aor. A^adoA^aYo lahu, inf. n. daA^oYN, I deceived, deluded, &c., it, namely, a thing, (S, K,) or him, namely, a man; (so in one of my copies of the S;) and so daA^awotu lahu. (S, M.) And Al*~iy^obu yadoA^aY lilogazaAli The wolf deceives, deludes, &c., the gazelle, or the young gazelle: (S, M:) or walks, or goes, in the manner of him who deceives, deludes, &c., to the gazelle, or the young gazelle. (T.)

daA^oYN *
and diy^iY~N↓ and duy^iY~N↓, (M, K,) the last said by IB, on the authority of As, to be pl. of [the n. un.] daA^oyapN↓, of the measure fuEuwlN, [originally duw^uwYN,] (TA,) The vertebræ of the kaAhil [or withers (app. of a camel)] and of the back: or the cartilages of the breast: or the ribs thereof, where it meets the side: (M, K:) or Ald~aA^ayaAtu↓ signifies the ribs of [i. e. within] the shoulderblade, three on either side; (IAar, M, K;) sing. daA^oyapN↓: (M:) or daA^oyapN↓, (T,) or daA^oYN, (S,) signifies the part of the camel against which lies the [piece of wood called] Zalifap of the saddle, and which is [often] galled thereby: (T, S:) or daA^oYN is the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of daA^oyapN↓, and signifies the vertebræ of the withers, in the part between the two shoulder-blades, of the camel, peculiarly; (Lth, T;) and the pl. [of daA^oyapN] is daA^ayaAtN↓: (Lth, T, S:) or the dA^yAt are the vertebræ of the neck: or the vertebræ of the spine: (AO, T:) or the two ribs next to the waAhinataAni are called the daA^oyataAni: AZ says that the Arabs knew not the term dA^yAt in relation to the neck, but they knew it in relation to the ribs, as signifying six [ribs] next to the stabbing-place of the camel, three on either side; and this is correct: (T:) [and it is said in the L, in art. jnH, that daA^oYN signifies the ribs of the back, of a man, which are called the jawaAniH, pl. of jaAniHapN, six in number, three on the right and three on the left:] the pl. of daA^oYN [or rather the quasi-pl. n.] is day^iY~N, like as Day^iynN is of DaA^onN, and maEiyzN of maEozN: (S:) and, accord. to IB, duy^iY~N is a pl. of daA^oyapN↓, as mentioned above, meaning the vertebræ of the neck. (TA.)

daA^oyapN *
; and its pls. daA^ayaAtN and duy^iY~N: see the next preceding paragraph, in seven places. ― -b2- Hence, (S,) Aibonu daA^oyapa The guraAb [or crow]: (S, M, K:) so called because it alights upon, and pecks, the dA^yp of the camel that has galls, or sores. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also The part, of a bow, upon which the arrow lies: there are two parts of which each is thus called, next to the part of the stave that is held by the hand, above and below. (M.) ＝ -A3- daAyapN [without ', from the Pers. daAyaho,] A child's nurse; a woman who has the charge of a child, who takes care of him, and rears, or nourishes, him; (TA in art. HDn;) i. q. Ziy^orN; both of which words are said by IJ to be chaste Arabic: pl. daAyaAtN. (M and TA in art. dwY.)

day^iY~N *
and day^iy~apN: see daA='N (in the latter part of the paragraph), in art. dwA^.

duy^iY~N *
and diy^iY~N: see daA^oYN.

dayoA^aY *
, of the measure fayoEalN; and its fem; with p: see daA='N (in the latter part of the paragraph), in art. dwA^.

1 dab~a db
aor.
dabi3a
, inf. n. dabiybN (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and dab~N (M, K,) and madab~N, (S, K,) [and perhaps dababN also, q. v.,] It, or he, (the ant, T, M, and any animal, M, and in like manner a party moving towards the enemy, T, or an army, and a child, Msb,) [crept; crawled; or] went, or walked, leisurely, or gently, (T, M, Msb, K,) without haste, (T,) EalaY AlA^aroDi [upon the ground]: (S:) and [simply] he walked: (IAar, T:) he (an old man) [crept along; or] walked leisurely, softly, or gently: (S:) and db~b↓, also, he walked leisurely, by slow degrees. (TA.) Hence, A^ako*abu mano dab~a wadaraja The most lying of those who have walked and died, or passed away, or perished: (T:) i. e., of the living and the dead. (T, S, K.) And yadib~u maEa AlquraAdi [He creeps about with ticks]; said of a man who brings a small worn-out skin containing ticks, and ties it to the tail of a camel; in consequence of which, when one of the ticks bites it, the camel runs away, and the other camels run away with it; and thereupon he steals one of them: whence it is said of a thief, or stealer of cattle &c. (TA.) And huwa yadib~u bayonanaA biAln~amaAy^imi (tropical:) [He creeps among us with calumnies, or slanders]. (A, TA.) And dab~ato EaqaArabuhu [lit. His scorpions crept along]; meaning (tropical:) his calumnies, or slanders, and mischief, (M, A, K,) crept along; syn. sarato. (M, K [See also art. Eqrb.]) And the same phrase is also used to signify (tropical:) His downy hair crept [along his cheeks]. (MF in art. Eqrb.) And dab~a qamoluhu [lit. His lice crept]; meaning (tropical:) he became fat: said of a man. (Ham. p. 633.) And dab~a Aljadowalu (tropical:) [The rivulet, or streamlet for irrigation, crept along]. (A.) And dab~a fiyhi (tropical:) It crept in, or into, it, or him; syn. saraY; (M, A, K;) namely, wine, or beverage, (T, M, A, K,) in, or into, the body, (M, K,) or in, or into, a man, (T,) and into a vessel; (M;) and a disease, or malady, (M, A, K,) in, or into, the body, (M, K,) or fiY Euruwqihi [in his veins]; (A;) and wear in a garment, or piece of cloth; (M, K;) and the dawn in the darkness of the latter part of the night. (M.) ― -b2- dib~iY Hajalo (in the CK Hajalu) is the name of A certain game of the Arabs: (K, TA:) the l is quiescent. (TA.) ― -b3- dub~a used as a noun: see below. ＝ -A2- dab~a [second pers. dabibota,] aor. yadab~u, inf. n. dababN, He (a camel) was, or became, such as is termed A^adab~u; (IAar, T, TA;) i. e., had much hair, or much fur (wabar), or much fur upon the face. (TA.)

2 dab~a3a
see 1, first sentence.

4 A^adobabotuhu *
[third pers. A^adab~a] I made him (namely, a child, S) [to creep, or crawl, or] to go, or walk, leisurely, or gently. (S, K. [For the correct explanation, Hamalotuhu EalaY Ald~abiybi, Golius seems to have found Hmlth ElY Ald~aAb~api.]) ― -b2- Adb~ AlbilaAda (assumed tropical:) He filled the country, or provinces, with justice, so that the inhabitants thereof walked at leisure (dab~a A^aholuhaA [whence Golius has supposed dab~a to signify “ juste se habuit populus ”] M, K, TA) by reason of the security and abundance and prosperity that they enjoyed. (M, TA.)

R. Q. 1 dabodaba dbdb
, [inf. n. dabodabapN,] He (a man) raised cries, shouts, noises, or a clamour. (AA, T.) ― -b2- And He beat a drum. (AA, T.)

dab~N db
: see dababN.

dub~a db
and $ub~a are used as nouns, by the introduction of mino before them, though originally verbs. (S and K * and TA in art. $b.) One says, A^aEoyayotaniY mino $ub~a A_ilaY dub~a, (M, K, *) by way of imitation [of a verbal phrase], (M,) and mn $ub~K AlY dub~K, Thou hast wearied me from the time of thy becoming a youth until thy walking gently, [or creeping along, resting] upon a staff: (M, K, * TA:) a prov.: (M, TA:) said alike to a man and to a woman. (TA in art. $b.) And faEalota ka*aA mino $ub~a A_ilaY dub~a and mn $ub~K AlY dub~K Thou hast done thus from youth until thy walking gently, [or creeping along, resting] upon the staff. (S.) ＝ -A2- dub~N: see dub~apN, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also [The bear;] a certain beast of prey, (S, M, K,) well known; (K;) a certain foul, or noxious, animal: (Msb:) a genuine Arabic word: (M:) fem. with p: pl. [of mult.] dibabapN (S, M, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] A^adobaAbN. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ald~ub~u (assumed tropical:) The constellation of the Greater Bear: and, accord. to some, that of the Lesser Bear: the former, for distinction, being called Ald~ub~u AlA^akobaru; and the latter, Ald~ub~u AlA^aSogaru. (M, K.)

dab~apN db dbh dbp
A single act [of creeping, or crawling, or] of going, or walking, leisurely, or gently: pl. dibaAbN. (K.) ＝ -A2- A hill, or heap, or gibbous hill, syn. kaviyb, (IAar, T, S, M, K,) of sand: (S, K:) and (in some copies of the K “ or ”) a tract of red sand: or an even tract of sand: (K:) or, as in some copies of the K, an even tract of land: (TA:) and a place abounding in sand: (T, L:) pl. as above. (TA.) Hence the prov., waqaEa fulaAnN fiY dab~apF mina Alr~amoli [lit. Such a one fell into, or upon, a place abounding in sand]; meaning, (tropical:) into difficulty, or misfortune; for the camel in such a place suffers fatigue. (T.) ＝ -A3- A certain thing for oil, or ointment; (S;) a receptacle for seeds (bizor) and olive-oil: (M, K:) pl. as above. (Sb, M.) A kind of bottle, or pot, (baT~apN,) peculiarly of glass. (K.) [Form the Pers. dab~aho.] ― -b2- See also dub~aA='N. ＝ -A4- And see dababN, in three places.

dub~apN db dbh dbp

[signifying Any small animal that walks or creeps or crawls upon the earth, a small beast, a small reptile or creeping thing, a creeping insect, and any insect, and also a mollusk, a shell-fish (as in an instance cited voce maHaArapN in art. Hwr) and the like,] is duwayob~apN↓, (Zj, T, Msb,) in which the Y is quiescent, but pronounced with A_i$omaAm [i. e. a slight approximation to the sound of kesr], as it is in every similar case, in a dim. n., when followed by a doubled letter: (Zj, T:) and duwaAb~apN↓ also has been heard, with the Y changed into A anomalously. (Msb; and L in art. hd, on the authority of ISd.) ― -b2- daAb~apu AlA^aroDi [The Beast of the Earth] is an appellation of one of the signs of the time of the resurrection: (S, M, K:) or the first of those signs. (K.) It is said to be a beast sixty cubits in length, or height, with legs, and with fur (wabar), and to be diverse in form, resembling a number of different animals. (TA.) It will come forth in Tihámeh, or between Es-Safà and ElMarweh, (M,) or at Mekkeh, from Jebel Es- Safà, which will rend open for its egress, during one of the nights when people are going to Minè; or from the district of Et-Táïf; (K) or from three places, three several times. (M, K.) It will make, upon the face of the unbeliever, a black mark; and upon the face of the believer, a white mark: the unbeliever's mark will spread until his whole face becomes black; and the believer's, until his whole face becomes white: then they will assemble at the table, and the believer will be known from the unbeliever. (M.) It is also said that it will have with it the rod of Moses and the seal of Solomon: with the former it will strike the believer; and with the latter it will stamp the face of the unbeliever, impressing upon it “ This is an unbeliever. ” (K.) ― -b3- See also A^araDapN.

, (M, TA,) inf. n. dabaArN, (As, S, M, K,) like damaArN, (As, S,) [and dabaArapN, like damaArapN (q. v.), and app. dabaraY↓, (see AlxayobaraY,) or dabraY may be a simple subst.,] The people, or company of men, perished; (As, * S, * M, K * TA;) went away, turning the back, and did not return. (TA. [And Adbr (q. v.) has a similar, or the same, meaning.]) Hence, Ealayohi Ald~abaAru Perdition befall him; may he go away, turning the back, and not return. (M, TA.) ― -b6- And dabara (tropical:) He became an old man. (S, A, K.) Hence, as some say, the expression in the Kur [lxxiv. 36], waA@ll~ayolu A_i*aA dabara (tropical:) [And the night when it groweth old]. (TA. [See also 4.]) ― -b7- dabarati Alr~iyHu, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
dabuxa
, inf. n. dubuwrN, (M,) The wind blew in the direction of that wind which is termed dabuwr [i. e. west, &c., which is regarded as the hinder quarter]: (M, A:) or changed, and came in that direction. (S, K.) [Hence,] dabarato lahu Alr~iyHu baEoda maA A^aqobalato [lit. The wind became west to him after it had been east: meaning (tropical:) his fortune became evil after it had been good]: and dabara baEoda A_iqobaAlK [(tropical:) which means the same: see dabuwrN; and see also 4 in this art., and in art. qbl]. (A.) ― -b8- And dubira, (S, K,) a verb of which the agent is not named, (S,) He, (K,) a man, (TA,) or it, a people, (S, M,) was smitten, or affected, by the wind called Ald~abuwr. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- dabara AlHadiyva Eanohu: see 2. ＝ -A3- qabalotu AlHabola wadabarotuhu: see dabiyrN. ＝ -A4- dabara, aor.
dabuxa
, inf. n. daborN, signifies, accord. to Kr, He wrote a writing or letter or book: but none other says so; and the known word is *abara. (M.) [The inf. n. is explained in the K as syn. with AikotitaAbN.] ＝ -A5- dabira, (S, M, Mgh, K,) aor.
dabaxa
, (K,) inf. n. dabarN, (M, Mgh,) He (a horse or the like, M, K, and a camel, S, M, Mgh) had galls, or sores, on his back, (M, Mgh, K, * TA,) produced by the saddle and the like; (Mgh;) as also Adbr↓. (K. [But the corresponding passage in the M shows that this is probably a mistake for A^adobaru a syn. of dabirN.])

2 db~r AlA^amora *
, (T, M, A,) or fiY AlA^amori (S,) inf. n. tadobiyrN, (T, S, K,) He considered, or forecast, the issues, or results, of the affair, or event, or case; (TA;) and so tdb~rhu↓: (Mgh:) or its end, issue, or result; (T, M, K;) as also tdb~rhu↓: (T, M, Msb, K:) or he looked to what would, or might, be its result: and fiyhi tdb~r↓ he thought, or meditated, upon it; (S;) [as also tdb~rhu↓:] Aktham Ibn-Seyfee said to his sons, A^aEojaAza yaAbaniY~a laA tatadab~aruwA↓ A^umuwrK qado wal~ato SuduwruhaA [O my sons, think not upon the ends of things whereof the beginnings have passed]: (T: [see EajuzN:]) and in the Kur [iv. 84] it is said, AlquroA=na A^afalaA yatadab~aruwna↓ Will they, then, not consider the meanings of the Kur-án, and endeavour to obtain a clear knowledge of what is in it? (Bd:) and again, in the Kur [xxiii. 70], Alqawola A^afalamo yad~ab~aruwA↓ Have they, then, not thought upon, (TA,) and endeavoured to understand, (yatafah~amuwA, K,) what has been said to them in the Kur-án? for tadab~urN↓ signifies the thinking, or meditating, upon [a thing], and endeavouring to understand [it]; syn. tafak~urN and tafah~umN: (TA:) and tdb~rhu↓ he looked into it, considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, in order to know it, or until he knew it. (Msb in art. Aml.) db~r A^amorFA, inf. n. as above, signifies [also] He did, performed, or executed, a thing, or an affair, with thought, or consideration. (Msb.) [And He devised, planned, or plotted, a thing, EalaY gayorihi against another. And hence, He managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, an affair; because the doing so requires consideration of the issues, or results, of the affair. You say, db~r A^umuwra AlbilaAdi, and, elliptically, db~r AlbilaAda, He managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, the affairs of the provinces, or country: and in like manner, the affairs of a house. tadobiyrN is also attributed to irrational animals; as, for ex., to horses; meaning their conducting the affair of victory: and to inanimate things; as, for ex., to stars; meaning their regulating the alternations of seasons &c.: see Bd in lxxix. 5. And db~r alone signifies He acted with consideration of the issues, or results, of affairs, or events, or cases; acted with, or exercised, forecast, or forethought; or acted with policy.] ― -b2- db~r Eabodahu, (M, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He made his slave to be free after his own death, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) saying to him, Thou art free after my death: (T, TA:) he made the emancipation of his slave to depend upon his own death. (TA.) ― -b3- db~r AlHadiyva, (inf. n. as above, K,) He related the tradition, narrative, or story, having received it, or heard it, from another person: (As, T, S, K: *) and huwa yudab~iru Hadiyva fulaAnK He relates the tradition, &c., of, or received from, or heard from, such a one: (As, S:) and db~r AlHadiyva Eanohu; (M;) or Eanohu dabarahu↓, (S, K,) aor.
dabuxa
; (TA;) He related the tradition, &c., having received it, or heard it, from him, (S, M, K,) after his death: (S, K:) Sh says that db~r AlHadiyva is unknown; but so the phrase is related on the authority of A'Obeyd: Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th] disallows yudab~iruhu as meaning he relates it; and says that it is ya*oburuhu, with *, meaning “he knows it, or learns it, well, soundly, or thoroughly;” syn. yutoqinuhu. (T.)

3 dAbrhu dAbr dAbrh dAbrp
, (S, A, *) inf. n. mudaAbarapN and dibaArN, (K,) [He turned his back upon him: see 6. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He severed himself from him, and avoided him, or shunned him; (TA;) became at variance with him; (A;) regarded him, or treated him, with enmity, or hostility. (S, A, K.) And dAbr raHimahu (assumed tropical:) He cut, or severed, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; disunited himself from his relations. (A.) ― -b3- daAbarotuhaA I made a slit such as is termed A_idobaArap in her (a ewe's or goat's or camel's) ear. (As, S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4 Adbr A^dbr Adbr dbr
, (M, K, and Bd in ix. 25,) inf. n. A_idobaArN (S, M) and duborN↓, accord. to Kr, but correctly the latter is a simple subst. [or quasi-inf. n.]; (M;) and dabara↓, (IAar, S, K,) inf. n. daborN (TA) and dubuwrN; (TK;) He went, turning his back; turned back; went back; took a backward course; retreated; retired; retrograded; declined; syn. wal~aYi (S, M, K) and taA^ax~ara (IAar) and *ahaba A_ilaY xalofK; (Bd ubi suprà, and S and K in art. qbl;) contr. of A^aqobala. (S, Bd.) And Adbr bihi [He went back, or backward, with it, or him; removed, or turned, it, or him, backward]. (S, K.) You say, yudobiru biAld~alowi A_ilaY AlHawoDi [He goes back with the bucket to the watering-trough]: opposed to the phrase yuqobilu bihaA A_ilaY biy^ori. (A.) See also dabiyrN, first sentence. And Adbr Eanohu [He went back, &c., from it, or him]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He feigned himself negligent of, or inattentive to, the want of his friend; (K;) as though he turned back from him. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] Adbr signifies (assumed tropical:) It went backward, to a bad state; said of the affair, or case, of a people. (M, TA.) You say also, A^amorN fulaAnK A_ilaY A_iqobaAlK and [in the contr. sense] AlY A_idobaArN (assumed tropical:) [The affair, or case, of such a one is inclining to advance, and to go backward, to a bad state]. (A.) [A_idobaArN often signifies The retiring, or declining, of good fortune; opposed to A_iqobaAlN: see also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.] And Adbr Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The case of the people took a backward course, and there remained none of them. (TA.) And Adbr Aln~ahaAri and dabara↓ (inf. n. of the latter dubuwrN, A) signify the same; (Fr, T, S, M;) i. e. The day went, or departed; (M, A;) and so AlS~ayofu [the summer, or the spring]: and in like manner one says [in the contr. sense] A^aqobala and qabala: so says Fr, and he adds, but you say of a man, Aqbl Alr~aAkibu and Adbr only, with A, though [Az says] it seems to me that the two forms are applicable in the same manner to men as they are to times. (T.) Some read, in the Kur [lxxiv. 36], waA@ll~ayoli A_i*aA dabara↓, (T, S,) which, accord. to some, means And the night when it cometh after the day; (T;) or when it followeth the day: (S: [for another rendering, see 1:]) others, (T, S,) the greater number, (T,) read A*A A^adobara, (T, S,) meaning when it retreateth to depart. (T.) [Hence,] Adbrt AlS~alaApu (assumed tropical:) The prayer ended. (Bd in l. 39.) And waA_idobaAra Als~ujuwdi: and waA_idobaAra Aln~ujuwmi: see duburN. And Adbr (assumed tropical:) He died; (K;) as also dAbr↓.
(Lh, M, K. [See also dabara Alqawomu, in the first paragraph.]) ― -b4- maA A^aqobala mina Aljabali wamaA A^adobara and maA qabala minohu wamaA dabara↓ signify the same [i. e. What is in front, of the mountain; and what is behind]. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Adbr also signifies He made a man to be behind him. (M.) ＝ -A3- And It, (the saddle, S, K, or a burden, M, TA,) and he, (a man, S, Mgh,) caused a camel, (S, M, Mgh,) or a horse or the like, (K,) to have galls, or sores, on the back; galled the back. (M, Mgh, K. *) ― -b2- And His camel became galled in the back. (S, K.) ― -b3- See also 1, last signification. ＝ -A4- It is also said [app., of a man, as meaning He slit the ear of a she-camel in a particular manner, i. e.,] when (T) the fatolap [or twisted slip formed by slitting (see A_idobaArapN)] of the ear of a she-camel, (T, K,) it being slit, (T, [but for A*A nHrt in the TT and TA, from which this is taken, I read A_i*aA buHirato, an emendation evidently required,]) turns towards the back of the neck: (IAar, T, TT, K, * TA:) and A^aqobala is said in like manner when this ftlp is turned towards the face. (IAar, T, TT, TA. [See also 3.]) ＝ -A5- It signifies also Earafa dabiyrahu mino qabiylihi, (IAar,) or Earafa qabiylahu mino dabiyrihi; (K;) said of a man. (IAar. [See dabiyrN.]) ＝ -A6- Also He, (K,) a man, (TA,) or it, a company of men, (S, M,) entered upon [a time in which blew] the wind called Ald~abuwr. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A7- And He journeyed on the day called dubaAr, i. e. Wednesday. (K, TA.) ＝ -A8- And He became possessed of much property or wealth, or of many camels or the like. (Msb, * K.)

5 tadab~axa
see 2, in nine places. ― -b2- Earafa AlA^amora tadab~urFA means He knew the thing at the last, (M, Mgh,) after it had past. (Mgh.) Jereer says, (M,)
walaA tat~aquwna Al$~ar~a Hat~aYyuSiybakumo
walaA taEorifuwna AlA^amora A_il~aA tadab~uraA
[And ye fear not evil until it befalleth you, and ye know not the thing save at the last, when it has past]. (M, Mgh. *) [See also 10.] And in like manner, tadab~ara AlkalaAma [meaning He postponed the saying] is said of one who has sworn after doing a thing. (Mgh.)

6 tdAbrwA tdAbr tdAbrwA
They turned their backs, one upon another. (A'Obeyd, T.) ― -b2- And hence, (A'Obeyd, T,) (assumed tropical:) They severed themselves, one from another, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) and avoided, or shunned, one another; (A'Obeyd, T;) became at variance, one with another; (A;) regarded, or treated, one another with enmity, or hostility: (M, A:) or it is only said of the sons of one father, or ancestor. (M.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) They spoke [evil], one of another, behind the other's back. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) They abstained from, or neglected, aiding, or assisting, one another. (TA in art. x*l.)

10 Astdbrhu A^stdbrh Astdbrh Astdbrp {stdbr {stdbrh
contr. of Astqblhu. (S, * Msb, K. *) [As such it signifies He turned his back towards him, or it.] You say, Astdbr Alqibolapa He turned his back towards the kibleh. (MA.) ― -b2- [As such also,] He came behind him. (TA.) You say, Astdbrhu faramaAhu (A, TA) He came behind him and cast, or shot, at him. (TA.) ― -b3- [As such also, He saw it behind him: he looked back to it: he saw it, or knew it, afterwards:] he saw, (M, K,) or knew, (TA,) at the end of it, namely, an affair, or a case, what he did not see, (M, K,) or know, (TA,) at the beginning of it: (M, K:) [or rather] he knew it at the end of an affair, or a case; namely, a thing that he did not know at the beginning of it. (T, A.) You say, Aisotadobara mino A^amorihi maAlamo yasotaqobilo He knew at the end of his affair, or case, what he did not know at the beginning of it. (A.) And A_in~a fulaAnFA lawi A@sotaqobala mino A^amorihi maA A@sotadobarahu lahudiYa liwijohapi A^amorihi Verily such a one, had he known at the beginning of his affair, or case, what he knew at the end thereof, had been directed to the right way of executing his affair. (T.) [See also 5.] ― -b4- Astdbrhu EalaY gayorihi He appropriated it to himself exclusively, in preference to others: (AO, K:) because he who does so turns his back upon others, and retires from them. (TA.) El-Aashà says, describing wine,
EalaY Al$~arobi A^awo munokirK maA Eulimo
tamaz~arotuhaAgayora musotadobirK
i. e. [I sipped it] not appropriating [it] to myself exclusively [in preference to the other drinkers, nor denying what was known]. (AO, TA.)

daborN dbr
The location, or quarter, that is behind a thing. (K. [In the CK, for xalof is put xalaf.]) Hence the saying, (TA,) jaEalotu kalaAmahu dabora A^u*uniY (assumed tropical:) I turned away from his speech, and feigned myself deaf to it: (T, S:) I did not listen to his speech, nor care for it, or regard it. (M, K, * TA.) You say also, A^u*unihi jaEalahu daAbira↓ (tropical:) He turned away from him, avoided him, or shunned him. (T, * A.) ― -b2- See also dabariY~N. ― -b3- Also, [like A_idobaArN, inf. n. of 4,] (assumed tropical:) Death. (K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Constant sleep: (M, K:) it is like tasobiyxN. (M.) ＝ -A2- I. q. dibaArN↓; these two words being pls. [or rather coll. gen. ns.] whereof the sings. [or ns. un.] are daborapN↓ and dibaArapN↓; which signify A ma$aArap [explained in the TA as meaning a channel of water; but it seems to be here used as meaning a portion of ground separated from the adjacent parts, for sowing or planting, being surrounded by dams, or by ridges of earth, which retain the water for irrigation, as explained in art. $wr, and as is indicated by its Persian equivalent here following,] in, (S,) or of, (K,) land that is sown or for sowing; (S, K;) called in Persian kurod: (S:) and dibaArN signifies small channels for irrigation between tracts of seedproduce; (K;) and its sing. is daborapN: (TA:) [Mtr says,] daborapN is syn. with ma$aArapN; in Persian karodah [app. a mistranscription for kurod as above]; and the pl. is daborN and dibaArN: (Mgh:) [ISd says,] daborapN signifies a small channel for irrigation between tracts of land sown or for sowing: or, as some say, i. q. ma$aArapN: and the pl. is dibaArN: it is also said that dibaArN signifies i. q. kurodapN; and its n. un. is dibaArapN: and dibaAraAtN signifies rivulets that flow through land of seed-produce; and its sing. is daborapN: but I know not how this is, unless daborapN have dibaArN for its pl., and this have p added to it, as in fiHaAlapN, and so dbArAt be a pl. pl., i. e. perfect pl. of dibaArapN: AHn says that daborapN signifies a patch of ground that is sown; [as is also said in the K;] and the pl. is dibaArN. (M.) ― -b2- Also A piece of rugged ground in a baHorN [i. e. sea or large river], like an island, which the water overflows [at times] and from which [at times] it recedes. (M, K.) ― -b3- And A mountain; (T, K;) in the Abyssinian language: (TA: [Az says, “I know not whether it be Arabic or not:”]) whence the saying of the King of Abyssinia, (T, * K, * TA,) maA A^uHib~u A^an~a liY daborFA *ahabFA waA^an~iYA=*ayotu rajulFA mina Almusolimiyna [I would not that I had a mountain of gold and that I had harmed a man of the Muslims]: (T, K:) but [SM says that] this is a confounding of two readings; which are, daborFA mino *ahabK and A^ano yakuwna daborN liY *ahabFA: (TA:) another reading is *aborFA mino *ahabK. (TA in art. *br.) ― -b4- See also diborN. ― -b5- Also, (S, M, K, &c.,) and diborN↓, (AHn, M, K,) A swarm of bees: and hornets, or large wasps; syn. zanaAbiyru: (S, M, K:) and the like thereof, having stings in their hinder parts: (B:) it has no sing., or n. un.: (As, M:) or the n. un. is daborapN↓ or diborapN↓; of which the dim. dubayorapN↓ occurs in a trad.: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^adoburN (K) and [of mult.] dubuwrN: (As, S, K:) and dabuwrN↓, with fet-h to the first letter, signifies bees; and has no proper sing. (M.) 'Ásim Ibn-Thábit El-Ansáree was called HamiY~u Ald~abori [The protected of hornets, or bees], because his corpse was protected from his enemies by large hornets, (S,) or by a swarm of bees. (M, Mgh * in art. HmY.) ― -b6- daborN also signifies The young ones of locusts; (AHn, K;) and so diborN↓. (AHn, M, K.)

duborN dbr
: see duburN: and dabariY~N; the latter in two places. ＝ -A2- See also 4, first sentence.

diborN dbr
: see daborN, last sentence but two, and last sentence. ― -b2- Also, (S, M, K,) and daborN↓, (M, K,) Much property or wealth; or many camels or the like; (S, M, K;) such as cannot be computed, or calculated: (M:) the sing. [and dual] and pl. are alike: you say [using it as an epithet] maAlN diborN and maAlaAni diborN and A^amowaAlN diborN: (S, M:) this mode of usage is best known; but sometimes dubuwrN is used as its pl.: (M:) in like manner you say maAlN davorN: and you say also rajulN *uw diborK, (S, TA,) and rjl dbr, [unless this be a mistake for the phrase immediately preceding,] (Fr, TA,) meaning a man having large possessions in land or houses or other property. (Fr, S, TA.)

dabarN dbr
[app. signifies A tract of the western sky at sunset: for] the Arabs said, A_i*aA raA^ayota Alv~uray~aA bidabaro fa$ahorN nitaAjo wa$ahorN maTaro waA_i*aA raA^ayota Al$~iEoraY biqabalo famajodu fatFY waHimolu jamalo, meaning When thou seest the Pleiades near to setting with sunset, then [is a month which] is a time of breeding of camels, and [a month which is] a time of rain: and when thou seest Sirius [near to rising] with sunset, [then is the glory of the generous man, and the time for the burden of the full-grown hecamel; for] then is the most intense degree of cold, when none but the generous and noble and
ingenuous man will patiently persevere in the exercise of hospitality and beneficence, and when the heavy burden is not laid save upon the strong full-grown he-camel, because then the camels become lean and the pasturage is scanty. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also, and so is A^adobaArN, a pl. [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n.] of dabarapN↓, (S, M, K,) which signifies A gall, or sore, on the back (M, * Mgh, K, * TA) of a horse or the like (M, K, TA) and of a camel, (M, Mgh,) produced by the saddle and the like; (Mgh;) and also on the kirokirap [or callous projection on the breast] of a camel. (S and K in art. sr.) They used to say, in the Time of Ignorance, A_i*aA baraA^a Ald~abaru waEafaA AlA^avaru, explained as meaning [When] the galls on the back of the beast or upon the foot of the camel [shall heal, and the footstep, or mark, become obliterated]. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A3- Also inf. n. of dabira. (M, Mgh.)

dabirN dbr
(M, K) and A^adobaru↓ (M) A horse or the like, (M, K,) and a camel, (M,) having galls, or sores, (M, K,) on his back (TA) [produced by the saddle and the like; having his back galled: see dabarN]: fem. [of the former] dabirapN and [of the latter] daboraA='u↓: and pl. [of either] daboraY. (M, TA.) [Hence the prov.,] haAna EalaY AlA^amolasi maA laAqaY Ald~abiru [What he that had galls on his back experienced was a light matter to him that had a sound back]: applied to one who has an ill concern for his companion. (K.) ― -b2- In the phrase rajulN xasirN wadabirN [app. meaning A man erring and perishing], Lh says that dabirN is an imitative sequent to xasirN: but [ISd says,] I think that xasirN is a verbal epithet, and that dabirN is a possessive epithet. (M in art. dmr.) You say also A^aHomaqN daAmirN xaAsirN daAbirN↓: (T in art. bt: [see art. xsr:]) and daAbirN is said to be an imitative sequent to xaAsirN. (TA.)

duburN dbr
and duborN↓, (the latter a contraction of the former, Msb, [and not so commonly used, like as A_ibolN is not so commonly used as A_ibilN,]) The back; syn. ZahorN: (S, A, B, K;) the first signification given in the [S and] A and B: pl. A^adobaArN. (TA.) You say, wal~aY duburahu [lit., He turned his back; and tropically,] (tropical:) he was put to flight. (A.) And wal~aAhu duburahu [lit., He turned his back to him; and tropically,] the same as the phrase immediately preceding. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [liv. 45], wayuwal~uwna Ald~ubura [And they shall turn the back, in flight]: where Aldbr is used in a collective sense, agreeably with another passage in the Kur [xiv. 44], laA yarotad~u A_ilayohimo Tarofuhumo. (S, B.) You also say, wal~awoA daborapF↓ (tropical:) They turned back in flight, or being routed. (A, TA.) ― -b2- The back, or hinder part, contr. of qubulN, (S, A, Msb, K,) of anything: (Msb:) as, for instance, of a shirt. (Kur xii. 25, 27, and 28.) You say, waqaEa Als~ahomu bidubori Alhadafi The arrow fell behind the butt. (TA in art. qbl.) ― -b3- The backside; posteriors; buttocks; rump; or podex: and the anus: syn. AisotN. (K.) [It has the former of these two significations in many instances; and the latter of them in many other instances: in the S and K in art. jEr, it is given as a syn. of majoEarN, which has the latter signification in the present day. This latter signification may also be intended in the S, M, A, Msb, and K, by the explanation “ contr. of qubulN, ” as well as the “ back, or hinder part, ” of anything: for qubulN very often signifies the “ anterior pudendum ” of a man or woman, and is so explained. The anus is also called Haloqapu Ald~uburi and HitaAru Ald~uburi and $araju Ald~uburi.] Its pl. A^adobaArN is also applied to the part which comprises the Aisot [or anus] and the HayaA=' [or vulva, i. e., external portion of the female organs of generation,] of a solid-hoofed animal, and of a cloven-hoofed animal, and of that which has claws, or talons: or, as some say, of a camel, or an animal having feet like those of the camel: and the sing., to the HayaA=' [or vulva] alone, of any such animal. (M, TT.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The latter, or last, part, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) of a thing, an affair, or an event, (T, S, Msb,) or of anything: (M, K:) pl. A^adobaArN (M) [and dibaArN: see dabariY~N]. [See also daAbirN.] One says, jiy^otuka duburi Al$~ahori, and fiY duburihi, and EalaY duburihi, and A^adobaAra Al$~ahori, and fiY A^adobaArihi, (tropical:) I came to thee in the latter, or last, part or parts, of the month. (M, K.) And A^adoEuw laka fiY A^adobaAri AlS~alawaAti (assumed tropical:) [I will petition for thee in the latter, or last, parts, or the conclusions, of the prayers]. (A.) See also dabariY~N. In the Kur [I. xxxix.], waA^adobaAra Als~ujuwdi signifies (assumed tropical:) And in the latter parts, or the ends, of the prayers: and Als~ujuwdi waA_idobaAra↓ [virtually] signifies the same [i. e. and in the ending of prostration], and is another reading of the text: Ks and Th adopt the former reading, because every single prostration has its latter part: or, accord. to the T, the meaning is, and in the two rek'ahs (Alr~akoEataAni) after sunset; as is related on the authority of 'Alee the son of Aboo-Tálib. (TA.) The similar expression in the Kur [lii. last verse] waA^adobaAra Aln~ujuwmi is explained by the lexicologists as signifying (assumed tropical:) And during the consecution of the stars, and their taking towards the west, to set: but [ISd says,] I know not how this is, since A^axo*N, by which they explain it, is an inf. n., and A^adobaAr is a pl. of a subst.: Aln~ujuwmi waA_idobaAra↓, which is another reading of the text, signifies and during the setting of the stars: and Ks and Th adopt this latter reading: (M:) or, accord. to the T, both mean and in the two rek'ahs before daybreak. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The hinder part, (M,) and angle, (zaAwiyap,) of a house or chamber or tent. (M, K.) ― -b6- Eitoqa AlEabodi Eano duburK (S, K) means The emancipation of the slave after the death of his owner. (S, Mgh, * Msb. * [See 2.]) ― -b7- [See also dabiyrN, of which, and of dibaArN, duburN is said in the TA in art. qbl to be a pl.].

daborapN dbr dbrh dbrp
: see duburN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A turn of evil fortune; an unfavourable turn of fortune: or a turn to be vanquished; contr. of dawolapN: (As, M, K:) dawolapN relates to good; and daborapN, to evil: one says, jaEala A@ll~`hu Ealayohi Ald~aborapa (assumed tropical:) [May God make the turn of evil fortune to be against him]: (As, T, M:) this [says ISd] is the best explanation that I have seen of daborapN: (M:) or (so accord. to the M, but in the K “ and ”) it signifies (assumed tropical:) the issue, or result, of a thing or an affair or a case; (M, K;) as in the saying of Aboo-Jahl to Ibn-Mes'ood, when he [the former] lay prostrate, wounded, limani Ald~aborapu (assumed tropical:) In whose favour is the issue, or result? and was answered, “ In favour of God and his apostle, O enemy of God: ” (T, TA:) also (tropical:) defeat in fight; (S, A, Mgh, K;) a subst. from AlA_idobaAru, as also dabarapN↓, (S,) and daAbirapN↓: (IAar, A, K:) you say, kaAnati Ald~aborapu lahu, meaning (tropical:) His adversary was defeated; and Ealayohi meaning (tropical:) He was himself defeated: (A:) and limani Ald~aborapu, meaning (assumed tropical:) Who is the defeater? and EalaYmani Ald~aborapu (assumed tropical:) Who is the defeated? the pl. of daborapN in the last sense is dibaArN: (TA:) which also signifies conflicts and defeats; (K;) as in the saying, A^awoqaEa A@ll~`hu bihimu Ald~ibaAra God caused, or may God cause, to befall them conflicts and defeats. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also daborN, in two places.

diborapN dbr dbrh dbrp
The direction, or point, towards which one turns his back; contr. of qibolapN. (S, K.) One says, maA lahu qibolapN walaA diborapN, meaning (tropical:) He has no way of applying himself rightly to his affair. (S, K, TA.) And layosa lih`*aA AlA^amori qibolapN walaA diborapN (tropical:) The right way of executing this affair is not known. (S, A.) ― -b2- See also A_idobaArapN. ＝ -A2- And see daborN, near the end.

dabarapN dbr dbrh dbrp
: see daborapN: ＝ -A2- and see also dabarN.

dabaraY dbr dbrY dbry dbryy
: see 1.

daboriY~N dbr dbrY dbry dbryy
: see the next paragraph, in two places.

dabariY~N dbr dbrY dbry dbryy
[Backward: and hence, (tropical:) late]. You say, AlEilomu qabaliY~Nwalayosa biAld~abariY~i (assumed tropical:) [True learning is prompt, and is not backward]: i. e., the man of sound learning answers thee quickly; but the backward says, I must consider it. (Th, T.) And tabiEotu SaAHibiY dabariy~FA (assumed tropical:) I followed my companion, fearing that he would escape me, after having been with him, and having fallen back from him. (M.) And $ar~u Alr~aA^oYi Ald~abariY~u (T, S, A, K *) (tropical:) The worst opinion, or counsel, is that which occurs [to one] late, when the want [of it] is past; (T, S, K, * TA;) i. e., when the affair is past: or raA^oYN dabariY~N signifies an opinion, or a counsel, not deeply looked into; and in like manner, jawaAbN, an answer, or a reply. (M.) And fulaAnN laA yuSal~iY AlS~alaApa A_il~aA dabariy~FA (AZ, S, M, A, K) and daboriy~FA↓, (AHeyth, K,) and the relaters of traditions say duburiy~FA↓, (S,) which is said in the K to be a corruption, but it may have been heard from a good authority, and with respect to the rules of the language is chaste, for, accord. to IAth, dabariY~N is a rel. n. irregularly formed from duburN, (TA,) (tropical:) Such a one performs not prayer save in the last part of its time. (AZ, S, K *) It is said in
a trad., laA yaA^otiY AlS~alaApi A_il~aA dabariy~FA; and in another, Al~A duborFA↓ or daborFA↓, accord. to different relations; (tropical:) He will not come to prayer save at the last, or late: and in another, A^ataY AlS~alaApa dibaArFA↓ (tropical:) He came to prayer at the latest of the times thereof; (IAar, TA;) or after the time had gone: (S:) dibaArN↓ being a pl. of duburN↓ and duborN↓ meaning the last of the times of prayer &c. (IAar, TA.) One says also, jaA='a fulaAnN daboriy~FA↓ (tropical:) Such a one came last, or latest. (A, * TA.) dbry~FA is in the accus. case as an adv. n. of time [like duborFA and daborFA and dibaArFA], or as a denotative of state with respect to the agent of the verb. (TA.) In the passage in the K [where it is said that dabariY~N signifies Prayer in the last of its time, &c.], there is a looseness. (TA.)

duburiY~N dbr dbrY dbry dbryy
: see the next preceding paragraph.

Ald~abaraAnu AldbrAn dbr
[The Hyades: or the five chief stars of the Hyades: or the brightest star among them, a of Taurus:] five stars of Taurus, said to be his hump; (S;) one of the Mansions of the Moon; [namely, the Fourth;] a certain star, or asterism, between Alv~uray~aA [or the Pleiades] and AljawozaA='u [or Orion], also called Alt~aAbiEu and Alt~uwayobiEu; (T;) it follows Alvry~A, (T, M,) and therefore is thus named. (T.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl: and see AlmijodaHu, in art. jdH.]

dubaArN dbAr
, (S, M, K, [in the M, accord. to the TT, written dubaAru, and it occurs in poetry imperfectly decl., but there is no reason for its being so in prose,]) and dibaArN↓, (K,) Wednesday; the fourth day of the week; (S, K;) an ancient name thereof: (S, M, * TA:) or, accord. to the 'Eyn, (K,) the night of [i. e. preceding the day of] Wednesday: (M, K:) which latter explanation is preferred by some authorities. (TA.) Wednesday is a day of ill luck: Mujáhid, being asked respecting the day of ill luck, answered, “ The Wednesday that does not come round [again, i. e. the last Wednesday,] in the month. ” (TA.)

dibaArN dbAr
: see dabariY~N, in two places. ― -b2- You say also, fulaAnN maA yadoriY qibaAla AlA^amori mino dibaArihi Such a one does not know the first part of the affair from the last thereof. (TA.) And maA yaEorifu qibaAlFA: mino dibaArK: see dabiyrN. And maA A^anota lahumo fiY qibaAlK walaA dibaArK (assumed tropical:) Thou art not one for whom they care. (TA in art. qbl.) ＝ -A2- See also daborN: ＝ -A3- and dubaArN.

dabuwrN dbwr
, used as a subst. and as an epithet, [of the fem. gender,] so that one says either riyHu Ald~abuwri or riyHN dabuwrN and simply dabuwrN, but more commonly used as an epithet, (M,) [The west wind: or a westerly wind: the west being regarded as the hinder quarter:] the wind that is opposite to that called AlS~abaA (S, L, Msb, K) and Alqabuwlu, (L,) blowing from the direction of the place of sunset: (L, Msb:) or the wind that comes from [the direction of] the back, or hinder part, of the Kaabeh, going towards the place of sunrise: (M:) but IAth rejects this explanation: (TA:) or the wind that comes from the quarter behind a person when he is standing at the kibleh: [but this is a most strange explanation:] or, accord. to IAar, the wind that blows from the tract extending from the place where En-Nesr et-Táïr [or Aquila] sets [i. e. about W. 10° N. in Central Arabia] to the place where Suheyl [or Canopus] rises [about S. 29° E. in Central Arabia]: (M:) or that comes from the direction of the south (Aljanuwb), going towards the place of sunrise: (Msb:) it is the worst of winds: it is said that it does not fecundate trees, nor raise clouds: (Meyd, TA:) and in a trad. it is said that the tribe of 'Ád was destroyed by it: (T, TA:) it blows only in the hot season, and is very thirsty: (TA voce nakobaA='u:) pl. duburN and dabaAy^iru. (M.) [Hence the saying,] EaSafato dabuwruhu wasaqaTato Eabuwruhu [lit. His west wind, or westerly wind, blew violently, and his Sirius set: meaning (tropical:) his evil fortune prevailed, and his good fortune departed: for the dbwr is the worst of winds, as observed above, and Sirius sets aurorally in the beginning of winter, when provisions become scarce]. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also daborN, last sentence but two.

dabiyrN dbyr
A twist which a woman turns backward (bihi maA A^adobarato↓), in twisting it: (S, K:) or what one turns backward from his chest [in rolling it against the front of his body]: (Yaakoob, S, A, K:) and qabiylN signifies “ what one turns forward (maA A^aqobala bihi) towards his chest: ” (Yaakoob, S, A:) or the former, what the twister turns backward towards his knee [in rolling it against his thigh; against which, or against the front of the body, the spindle is commonly rolled, except when it is twirled only with the hand while hanging loosely]: and the latter, “ what he turns forward towards his flank or waist: ” (As, T:) [whence the saying,] qabalotu A^uxoraY AlHabolu mar~apF wa dabarotuhu↓ [I turned the rope, or cord, forward, or toward me, in twisting it, one time, and turned it backward, or from me, another time]: (TA in art. qbl:) or dabiyrN signifies the twisting of flax and wool: and qabiylN, the “ twisting of cotton. ” (Lth, T.) One says, Earafa qabiylahu mino dabiyrihi, meaning (tropical:) He knew, or distinguished, his obedience from his disobedience; (K,) TA;) or dabiyrahu mino qabiylihi his disobedience from his obedience. (Aboo-' Amr Esh-Sheybánee, IAar, T.) And fulaAnN maA yaEorifu qabiylFA mino dabiyrK (S, A) or qabiylahu mn dabiyrihi (TA) (tropical:) [Such a one knows not &c.]: or maA yaEorifu qabiylFA mino dabiyrK and qibaAlFA mino dibaArK↓ he knows not the ewe, or she-goat, that is termed muqaAbalap from that which is termed mudaAbarap: or him who advances towards him from him who goes back from him: or the parentage of his mother from that of his father: (K in art. qbl:) or that of his father from that of his mother: so says IDrd in explaining the former phrase: or a qubul from a dubur: or a thing when advancing from a thing when going back: and the pls. of each are qubulN and duburN. (TA in that art.) Accord. to El-Mufaddal, dabiyrN signifies An arrow's losing in a game of chance [such as Almayosir]; and qabiylN, its “ winning therein. ” (T, TA.) [See qabiylN, in art. qbl.] ― -b2- Also The upper [because it is the hinder] part of the ear of a camel: the lower part is called the qabiyl. (TA in art. qbl.)

dibaArapN dbArh dbArp
: see daborN.

dubayorapN dbyrh dbyrp
: see daborN.

daAbirN dAbr
act. part. n. of dabara, Following (S, K, TA) behind the back; following the back; following, with respect to place, and also with respect to time, and also (assumed tropical:) with respect to rank or station. (TA.) [Hence,] daAbiru qawomK The last that remains of a people or party; he who comes at the end of a people or party; as also daAbiratuhumo↓; which likewise signifies those who remain after them: and daAbirapN↓ [so in the TA, but accord. to the T daAbirN, which I think the right reading,] signifies one who comes after; or follows, another. (TA.) And Ald~alowu bayona qaAbilK wadaAbirK The bucket is between one who advances with it to the well and one who goes back, or returns, with it to the wateringtrough. (A.) And jaEalahu daAbira A^u*unihi: see daborN. And A^amosi Ald~aAbiru and Almudobiru↓ Yesterday that is past: (S, M, K:) the epithet being here a corroborative. (S, * M.) You say, SaAruwA kaA^amosi Ald~aAbiri [They became like yesterday that is past]. (A.) And hayohaAta *ahaba kamaA *ahaba A^amosi Ald~aAbiru [Far distant is he, or it! He, or it, hath gone like as hath gone yesterday that is past]. (S.) ― -b2- Also An arrow that passes forth from the butt, (S, Msb, K,) [or passes beyond it, (see 1,)] and falls behind it: (TA:) you say sahomN daAbirN, and sihaAmN daAbirapN and dawaAbiru. (Msb.) ― -b3- An arrow that does not win [in the game called Almayosir]; (K, TA;) contr. of qaAbilN. (S, TA.) ― -b4- The last arrow remaining in the quiver. (A.) ― -b5- The last of anything; (Ibn-Buzurj, T, M, K;) and so daAbirapN↓: (M:) [see also duburN:] and (accord. to As and others, TA) the root, stock, race, or the like; syn. A^aSolN. (K.) One says, qaTaEa A@ll~`hu daAbirahumo May God cut off the last that remain of them. (S.) And qaTaEa A@ll~`hu daAbirahu May God cut off the last of him, or it: (A:) or may God extirpate him. (As, T.) And in the Kur [vi. 45] it is said, faquTiEa daAbiru Alqawomi And the last of the people were extirpated. (M, TA.) And in a trad., yuqoTaEu bihi daAbiruhumo All of them shall be cut off thereby, not one remaining. (TA.) ― -b6- See also dabirN, last sentence. ― -b7- As an epithet applied to a camel: see gud~apN.

daAbirapN dAbr dAbrh dAbrp
: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The end of a tract of sand: (Esh-Sheybánee, S, A, * K:) pl. dawaAbiru. (A.) ― -b3- Of a solid hoof, The hinder part: (T, TA:) or the part that corresponds to the hinder part of the pastern: (S, K:) or the part that is next after the hinder part of the pastern: (M, TA:) pl. as above. (T, TA.) ― -b4- Of a bird, The back toe: it is with this that the hawk strikes: (M, TA:) or a thing like a toe, in the inner side of the foot, with which the bird strikes: (S:) that of a cook is beneath his SiySiyap [or spur]; and with it he treads: (M, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- See also daborapN. ― -b6- Also A mode of $agozabiy~ap [or throwing down by a trick] (S, K) in wrestling. (S.)

A^adobaru *
; and its fem. daboraA=hu: see dabirN.

A_idobaArN A^dbAr A_dbAr AdbAr dbr
[originally inf. n. of 4]: see the next paragraph, in two places.

A_idobaArapN A^dbArh A_dbAr A_dbArh AdbArh AdbArp dbr
A slit in the ear [of a ewe or she-goat or she-camel], which being made, that thing [thus made, meaning the pendulous strip,] is twisted, and turned backward: if turned forward, it is termed A_iqobaAlapN: and the hanging piece of skin of the ear is termed A_idobaArapN [in the former case] and A_iqobaAlapN [in the latter case]; as though it were a zanamap [q. v.]; (As, S, M, * K;) and, respectively, A_idobaArN↓ and A_iqobaAlN, and diborapo↓ and qibolapN. (TA in art. qbl.) The ewe or she-goat [to which this has been done] is termed mudaAbarapN↓ [in the former case] and muqaAbalapN [in the latter]: and you say of yourself [when you have performed the operation, in these two cases respectively], daAbarotuhaA and qaAbalotuhaA: and the she-camel is termed *aAtu A_idobaArap and *aAtu A_iqobaAlapN; (As, S, K;) and so is the ewe or she-goat; (As, T;) and the she-camel, *aAtu A_idobaArK↓ and *aAtN A_iqobaAlK. (TA in art. qbl.)

A^udaAbirN *
A man who cuts, or severs, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; who disunites himself from his relations; (S, K;) like A^ubaAtirN: (S:) one who does not accept what any one says, (AO, [who mentions A^ubaAtirN therewith as having the former signification,] T, S, M, K,) nor regard anything: (AO, T, S, M:) one who will not receive admonition. (IKtt.) [See A^uxaAyilN.]

mudobirN mdbr
[Going, turning his back; turning back; &c.: see its verb, 4]. You say, maA lahumo mino muqobilK walaA mudobirK They have not one that goes forward nor one that goes back. (A.) In the phrase in the Kur [ix. 25], vum~a wal~ayotumo mudobiriyna [Then ye turned back retreating], the last word is a corroborative denotative of state; for with every tawoliyap is A_idobaAr. (M.) See also daAbirN. ― -b2- naAbN mudobirN is said to signify (assumed tropical:) An aged she-camel whose goodness has gone. (TA.) ― -b3- A^aroDN mdbrpN [app. mudobirapN] (assumed tropical:) A land upon which rain has fallen partially, not generally, or not universally. (TA in art. qbl. [This explanation is there given as though applying also to ArD mqblp, app. muqobilapN; but I think that there is an omission, and that the latter phrase has the contr. meaning.])

madobarapN mdbr mdbrh mdbrp
i. q. A_idobaArN [inf. n. of 4, q. v.]. (M.)

mudab~arN mdbr
A slave made to be free after his owner's death; (S;) to whom his owner has said, “ Thou art free after my death; ” whose emancipation has been made to depend upon his owner's death. (TA.)

mudab~irN mdbr
[is extensively and variously applied as meaning One who manages, conducts, orders, or regulates, affairs of any kind, but generally affairs of importance]. faA@lomadab~iraAti A^amorFA, in the Kur [lxxix. 5], signifies [accord. to most of the Expositors] And those angels who are charged with the managing, conducting, ordering, or regulating, of affairs. (TA. [See also Bd.])

madobuwrN mdbwr
, (TA,) and madobuwruwna, (S,) A man, (TA,) and people, (S,) smitten, or affected, by the [westerly] wind called Ald~abuwr. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, the former, Wounded: (K:) or galled in the back. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And Possessing much property or wealth, or many camels or the like. (K.)

mudaAbarN mdAbr
applied to a place of abode, Contr. of muqaAbalN. (M.) You say, h`*aA jaAriY muqaAbaliY and mudaAbariY [This is my neighbour in front of me and in rear of me]. (TA in art. qbl.) ― -b2- mudaAbarapN applied to a ewe or she-goat: see A_idobaArapN: so applied, Having a portion of the hinder part of her ear cut, and left hanging down, not separated: and also when it is separated: and muqaAbalapN is applied in like manner to one having a portion of the extremity [or fore part] of the ear so cut: (As, T:) and the former, applied to a she-camel, having her ear slit in the part next the back of the neck: or having a piece cut off from that part of her ear: and in like manner applied to a ewe or she-goat: also an ear cut, or slit, in the hinder part. (M.) [It seems that a she-camel had her ear thus cut if of generous race. And hence,] naAqapN muqaAbalapN mudaAbarapN (tropical:) A she-camel of generous race by sire and dam. (T, TA.) And fulaAnN muqaAbalN wa mudaAbarN (tropical:) Such a one is of pure race, (S, K,) or of generous, or noble, race, (A,) by both parents: (S, A, K:) accord. to As, (S,) from AlA_iqobaAlapu and AlA_idobaArapu. (S, K.)

mudaAbirN mdAbr
[act. part. n. of 3, q. v.:] (assumed tropical:) One who turns back, or away, from his companion; who avoids, or shuns, him. (As.) ― -b2- Also A man whose arrow does not win [in the game called Almayosir]: (S, K:) or one who is overcome in the game called Almysr: or one who has been overcome [therein] time after time, and returns in order that he may overcome: or, accord. to A'Obeyd, he who turns about, or shuffles, the arrows in the ribaAbap in that game. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. xD.]

fulaAnN musotadobirN Almajodi musotaqobiluhu flAn mstdbr Almjd mstqblh flAn mstdbr Almjd mstqblp
(tropical:) Such a one is [as though he had behind him and before him honour or dignity or nobility; meaning that he is] generous, or noble, in respect of his first and his last acquisition of honour or dignity. (TA. [But it is there without any syll. signs; and with mstqbl in the place of musotaqobiluhu.])

4 Adbst AlA^aroDu *
The land showed its plants or herbage: (K:) or began to show the blackness of its plants or herbage. (AHn, M, S.)

9 Adbs~ Adbs
, inf. n. AidobisaAsN; (S, K;) or AdbAs~↓; (M;) He (a horse, S, M, K, and a sheep, or goat, M, and a bird, S) became black: (K:) or [brown; i. e.] of a colour between black and red; (S;) or black tinged, or intermixed, with redness. (M, TA.) [See dubosapN and A^adobasu.]

11 A_idobaAos~a
see 9. AdbAs~t AlA^aroDu The blackness of the land became mixed with redness. (M, TA.)

dabosN dbs
Anything black. (Lth, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] Much people; as also dibosN↓: (IAar, K:) the former is also common to other things; (M, * TA;) so that you say maAlN dabosN, meaning much property. (TA.)

dubosN dbs
: see the next paragraph.

dibosN dbs
(S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and dubosN↓ (M) and dibisN↓ (K) The expressed juice of fresh ripe dates; (A, Mgh, Msb;) what flows from fresh ripe dates; (S;) the honey of dates; [i. e. the sweet, thick, or inspissated, juice thereof;] (M, K;) the expressed juice of dates, (M,) or of fresh ripe dates not cooked: (AHn, M:) what is called SaqorN in the dial. of the people of ElMedeeneh: said by some to be the honey of fresh ripe dates: by some, what flows, or exudes, from raisins and from fresh grapes: and by some, what flows from the baskets of dates: (TA:) [see also rub~N, in an explanation of which the inspissated juice of any fruit is termed its dibos:] also the honey of bees, Easalu Aln~aHolu: so in the copies of the K and in [some of the copies of] the A; a signification not known; but [AHn] EdDeenawaree mentions the word dabaAsaAtN, and explains it as signifying “ domestic bee-hives; ” and by this it is seen that the application of dbs to what bees eject may be correct: or the true reading may be Easalu Aln~axoli, with x, as in some copies of the A; and it may be meant as explaining what precedes, meaning the expressed juice of the fruit of the palm-tree, by a kind of trope; though, as such, a useless repetition: but it is said in the O, on the authority of IDrd, that bees' honey is called dibisN↓: (TA:) the vulgar apply the word to [the inspissated juice of fresh ripe grapes, which resembles thick honey: and sometimes to] the honey of raisins. (MF.) ＝ -A2- See also dabosN.

dibisN dbs
: see dibosN, in two places.

dubosapN dbs dbsh dbsp

(IAar, TA.) And dabalotu Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. as above; (TA;) and dab~alotuhu↓; (S;) I made the thing into lumps, or compact pieces or portions: (S, * TA:) and AlHayosa db~l↓, inf. n. tadobiylN, He made the Hys [generally explained as meaning dates mixed with clarified butter and the preparation of dried curd called A^aqiT, kneaded, or rubbed and pressed with the hand until they mingle together and their stones come forth,] into dubal [pl. of dubolapN, q. v.]. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- dabala AlA^aroDa, (T, M, K,) inf. n. dabolN (S, M, K) and dubuwlN, (M, K,) He put the land into a right, or proper, state, prepared it, or improved it, [or manured it,] with dung such as is termed sirojiyn, [in the K siroqiyn,] and the like, (T, S, M, K,) in order that it might become good: (T, M:) and so damalahaA. (T.) ― -b2- And dabalotuhu means I put it into a right, or proper, state; prepared it; or improved it; namely, anything; as also damalotuhu: for instance, a rivulet; i. e. he cleansed it, and put it into a right, or proper, state. (S.) ＝ -A3-
dabalahu, (K,) inf. n. dabolN, (TA,) also signifies He struck him consecutive strokes with a staff, or stick, (K,) and with a whip. (TA.) ― -b2- dabalatohu Ald~ubuwlu↓ Calamities, or misfortunes, befell him: or may calamities, or misfortunes, befall him. (K.) And dabalatohumu Ald~ubayolapu↓ Calamity, or misfortune; befell them: or may calamity, &c.: (A'Obeyd, S, M:) or they perished: or may they perish. (T.) And dabalatohu Ald~abuwlu↓, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Ald~ubuwlu,]) and *abalatohu Al*~abuwlu, (TA,) Calamity, or misfortune, befell him: or may calamity, &c.: (TA:) or the bereft woman, i. e. his mother, became bereft of him by death: or may the bereft woman, &c. (K, TA.) ― -b3- maA lahu dabala daboluhu↓, or *abala *aboluhu, is a form of imprecation: see the latter in art. *bl. (TA.) ＝ -A4- dabila, aor.
dabala
, inf. n. dabalN, He (a camel, or other animal,) became full of fat and flesh. (TA.)

A rivulet, or streamlet: (T, M, Mgh, K:) pl. dubuwlN: (S, M, Mgh, K:) so called because cleansed, and put into a right, or proper, state [when needing]. (T, S, M. *) ＝ -A2- Plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwnN. (Th, M, K.) ＝ -A3- maA lahu dabala daboluhu: see 1, last sentence but one.

A calamity, or misfortune; (S, K;) as also dubayolapN↓, (S, M, K,) in which the dim. form denotes enhancement; (S, TA;) and dabuwlN↓: (K:) pl. of the first dubuwlN: (TA:) whence the saying, dabalatohu Ald~ubuwlu: see 1, latter part. Also The state of being bereft of a child, or of a person beloved, by death. (IAar, M, K.) See dabiylN, in four places.

(En-Nadr, T.) ― -b2- See also dubayolapN. ＝ -A2- Also The hole of the faA^os [i. e. hoe, or adz, or axe]: pl. dubalN and dubulN. (K.)

dibolN↓ (M, K) and daAbilN↓ dibolN↓ (T, M, K) are intensive expressions (K) meaning A severe, or heavy, calamity or misfortune: (K, * TA: [in the CK, dabolN, which is said in the TA to be incorrect:]) or a severe, or heavy, bereavement. (T, M, TA.) And one says, sometimes, (M,) dabiylFA dibolFA↓ (S, M) and daAbilFA↓ dibolFA↓ (M) in the accus. case as an imprecation [meaning May God send upon such a one a severe, or heavy, calamity or bereavement]. (M.) As used to say *bl *Abl, meaning “ [deep] abasement or ignominy: ” (T, TA:) and Aboo-' Amr Esh-Sheybanee, *blFA *bylFA: (TA:) others pronounced with d. (T.)

dubayolapN dbylh dbylp
A certain malady (M, Mgh, K) in the jawof, (M, K,) [i. e.,] in the belly, (Mgh,) being a collection of corrupt matter therein; (Mgh, TA;) wherefore it is thus called; (TA;) as also adbolapN↓ (M, K) and dubolapN↓: (K:) accord. to ISh, an ulcer that penetrates into the belly: [see also dubaAlN:] or an ulcer that comes forth within the side, and discharges internally; the sufferer from which seldom recovers: also called *aAtu Aljanobi: (TA in art. jnb:) a large tumour (in Pers. waram buzurG). (KL.) [Abu-l-Kásim Ez-Zahráwee describes the modes of cauterizing the dbylp in order to hasten its coming to maturity. (See “ Albucasis de Chirurgia, ” p. 98, where the word is twice written *bylp; once, *bEylp; and once, correctly, dbylp.) Golius explains dabolapN and dubolapN by “ vomica, apostema, ” as on the authority of the S and KL; in neither of which do I find anything of the kind: nor do I find dabolapN even mentioned in either of those works.] ― -b2- See also dibolN. Hence the saying, dabalatohumu Ald~ubayolapu: see 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.

, said of the [tree, or shrub, called] rimov, (S,) or of the Earofaj, (M, K,) or of each of these, (TA,) It put forth what resembled [the young locusts termed] dabFY; (M, K;) [i. e.] what came forth, of its leaves, resembled dabFY; (S;) and thus became fit to be eaten. (S, M.) [See A^aboqala and vaq~aba and HanaTa; and see also rimovN, and EarofajN.]

dabFY db dbY dby dbyy
or dabFA [sometimes written with Y and sometimes with A] Locusts before they fly: (S:) or locusts when they [first] put themselves in motion, and become black, before their wings grow: in their first state, when they are white, they are termed saro'N: (AO, T:) or the smallest of locusts, and of ants: (M, K:) or [locusts] after the state of that which is termed sirowapN: (M:) [see jaraAdN:] n. un. dabApN. (S, M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaA='a bidabaY dubaY~K↓, (M,) or bidabaA dubaY~K, and bidabaA dubay~ayoni, (IAar, T, Mj, K,) and bidabaY dubay~aAna↓ and bidabaY dubay~aAnK, (Th, M,) (assumed tropical:) He came with, or brought, much; and what was good: (M:) he came with, or brought, much property or wealth, or many cattle: (M, K:) dubaY~N↓ is a soft tract in EdDahnà, frequented by locusts, which lay their eggs therein; (M;) it is a spacious place; so that the phrase [jaA='a bidabaY dubaY~K] is as though it meant he came with, or brought, property, or wealth, or cattle, like the [locusts termed] dbA of the spacious place called dbY~. (T.) J is in error as to this phrase: (K, TA:) for it is stated in the S, as on the authority of IAar, that one says, jaA='a fulaAnN bidabaA dabaA, meaning Such a one came with, or brought, property, or wealth, or cattle, like the dbA in abundance: and thus it is found in his handwriting: and in the Tekmileh it is written, as on the same authority, bidabaY dabFY. (TA.) Accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás [Th], the [right] phrase is bidabaY dubiY~K↓: and in one place he says that dabY~N↓ [thus (for dabiY~N) in the TT as from the T, but probably a mistranscription for dubaY~N↓,] signifies Much property or wealth, or many cattle: and accord. to AA, one says, jaA='a fulaAnN bidubaY~N↓, meaning Such a one came with, or brought, property, or wealth, or cattle, like the dbA. (T.) ＝ -A2- Also A gentle, or leisurely, manner of walking or going. (K. [See 1.])

1 davara dvAr dvr
, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) aor.
davura
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. duvuwrN, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) said of a trace, or mark, of a house; or of what remains, cleaving to the ground, marking the place of a house; (S, Msb, K, TA;) or of a place of abode, (T, A,) &c.; (T;) or of a thing; (M;) It became covered with sand and dust blown over it by the wind: this is the primary signification: (TA:) or it became effaced, or obliterated, (T, S, M, A, K, TA,) by the blowing of the winds over it; (TA;) as also tdAvr↓, (S,) or Andvr↓: (M, K:) and it became old; (M, K;) as also Andvr↓, (M,) or tdAvr↓. (K.) By one of the poets it is metaphorically said of a man's reputation, meaning (tropical:) It became worn out of regard or notice; became effaced, or obliterated. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He became overcome by old age and emaciation. (T, TA.) ― -b3- Also, said of a garment, (T, K,) inf. n. as above, (T,) It became dirty. (T, K.) ― -b4- And, said of a sword, (T, A, K,) inf. n. as above, (A,) (tropical:) It became sullied from remaining long unfurbished; (A;) it became rusty. (T, K.) Hence the trad. of El-Hasan, HaAdivuwA h`*ihi Alquluwba bi*ikori A@ll~`hu faA_in~ahaA sariyEapu Ald~uvuwri [explained in art. Hdv]. (Sh, T, A, TA.) duvuwrN attributed to the heart is (assumed tropical:) The having the remembrance of God effaced from it: and attributed to the mind, (assumed tropical:) The being quick to forget. (Sh, T, K.) ＝ -A2- davara Al$~ajaru, (K,) inf. n. as above; (TA; [in which, by a strange mistake, Alrjl is put for Al$jr;]) or dv~r↓; (so in the M, accord. to the TT;) The trees put forth their leaves (M, K, TA) and their branches. (M, TA.)

2 dv~rhu dvAr dvr dvrh dvrp

(S, O.) You say, daxalotu madoxalFA HasanFA [like duxuwlFA HasanFA I entered with a good entering]. (S.) And daxalotu Albayota (S) or Ald~aAra, i. e. [I entered the house, or] I became within the house, and the like, (Msb,) correctly meaning A_ilaY Albayoti [&c., or fiY Albayoti &c., i. e. I entered into the house, &c.], the prep. being suppressed, and the noun put in the accus. case after the manner of an objective complement: for nouns of place are of two kinds, vague and definite; the vague being such as the six relative locations, xalofN, and qud~aAmN, and yamiynN, and $imaAlN, and fawoqN, and taHotN, and the like, such as A^amaAmN, and waraA='N, and A^aEolaY, and A^asofalu, and Einoda, and laduno, and wasoTN in the sense of bayonN, and qubaAlapN, all which, and similar nouns of place, may become adverbs, because indefinite; for dost thou not see that what is xalof to thee may be qud~aAm to another? but that which is definite, having make, and corporeal substance, and tracts that comprehend it, as a mountain and a valley and a market and a house and a mosque, the noun signifying such a thing cannot become an adverb; for you may not say, qaEadotu Ald~aAra, nor Sal~ayotu Almasojida, nor nimotu Aljabala, nor qumotu AlwaAdiYa; the phrases of this kind that occur being instances of the suppression of a prep.; as daxalotu Albayota, and nazalotu AlwaAdiYa, and SaEidotu Aljabala. (S, O, TA.) You say also, daxalotu EalaY zayodK Ald~aAra, meaning I entered the house after Zeyd, he being in it. (Msb.) [And simply daxala Ealayohi He came in upon him: and also he came upon him; i. e. invaded him.] And daxala biA@moraA^atihi, (Msb, TA,) and EalayohaA, (MA,) inf. n. duxuwlN, (Mgh, Msb,) [like daxala biA^aholihi, and EalayohaA, (see A^aholN,) i. e.
