And A^um~ahaAtu Ald~ar~i The teats of a camel or clovenfooted animal. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence also the saying, lil~`hi dar~uka (tropical:) To God be attributed the good that hath proceeded from thee! or thy good deed! (TA:) or thy deed: (A:) or thy gift! and what is received from thee! [and thy flow of eloquence! and the like: when said to an eloquent speaker or poet, it may be rendered divinely art thou gifted!] a man's gift [or the like] was originally thus likened to the milk of a camel; and then this phrase became so common as to be used as expressive of admiration of anything: (Aboo-Bekr, TA:) it was first said by a man who saw another milking camels, and wondered at the abundance of their milk: (ISd, TA:) the thing alluded to therein is attributed to God to indicate that none other could be its author. (TA.) You say also, lil~`hi dar~uhu (tropical:) To God be attributed his deed! (S, K:) or his knowledge! or his good! or bounty! or beneficence! (Har p. 418:) [&c.:] meaning praise. (S.) Accord. to IAar, dar~N signifies (tropical:) A deed, whether good or evil. (TA.) Ibn-Ahmar says, lil~`hi dar~iY [To God be attributed what hath brought me to this state!] wondering at himself. (TA.) One also says, lil~`hi dar~uka mino rajulK, which is likewise an expression of praise, (S,) meaning (tropical:) To God be attributed the goodness, or good action, of thee, as a man! [i. e., of such a man as thou!] (TA.) And lil~`hi dar~uhu faArisFA (tropical:) [To God be attributed his excellence as a horseman!]. (Msb.) And, in dispraise, (S,) dar~uhu laA dar~a↓ May his good, or wealth, not be, or become, much, or abundant! (S, A, TA:) or may his work not thrive! (K.) El-Mutanakhkhil says,
laA dar~a dar~iYa A_ino A^aToEamotu naAzilahumo
qirofa AlHat~iYi waEinodiY Albur~u makonuwzu
[May my wealth not become abundant, or may my work not thrive, if I feed him among them who is a guest with the rind of HatiY~ (q. v.) when I have wheat stored up]: this verse is cited by Fr, who also mentions the phrase, dar~a dar~u fulaAnK [May the wealth of such a one become abundant! or may his work thrive!]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The soul; syn. nafosN. (K.) One says rajulN sariY~N Ald~ar~i A man of generous and manly soul. (TK.) And dafaEa A@ll~`hu Eano dar~ihi May God defend his soul. (Lh.)

1 daraA^ahu *
, aor.
daraAa
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. daro'N (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and daroA^apN; (K;) and dr~A^hu↓; (M, TA; [or this latter has probably an intensive signification;]) He pushed it, or thrust it; or pushed it, or thrust it, away, or back; repelled
it; or averted it; syn. dafaEahu; (S, * M, Mgh, * Msb, K;) namely, a thing. (Msb.) Hence, kaAna bayona Eumara wamuEaA*i boni EaforaA='a daro'N There was, between 'Omar and Mo'ádh Ibn-'Afrà, a contending, and a mutual pushing or thrusting, &c. (Mgh.) And daraA^a Eanohumo He repelled from them, or defended them; as also daraha, which is formed by substitution from the former, like haraAqa from A^araAqa. (S in art. drh.) And daraA^a Eanohu AlHad~a He averted (dafaEa) from him the prescribed castigation: (M, Mgh:) or he deferred his prescribed castigation: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to other things. (AZ, T.) It is said in a trad., Aidoraw^uwA AlHuduwda biAl$~ubuhaAti [Avert ye, or defer ye, the prescribed castigations on account of dubious circumstances]. (ISk, M, TA.) And Aidoraw^uwA AlHuduwda maA A@sotaTaEotumo [Avert ye, or defer ye, the prescribed castigations as long as ye are able]. (S, form a trad.) ― -b2- See also 5. ― -b3- daraA^a Eani AlbaEiyri AlHaqaba is explained by Sh as meaning He pushed back the kind girth of the camel: but AM says that the correct meaning is, he spread the kind girth upon the ground, and made the camel to lie down upon it [in order that he might gird him]. (TA.) [For] daraA^a signifies also He spread, or laid flat, (K, TA,) a thing upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b4- daraA^a Al$~aYo'a biAl$~aYo'a He supported the thing by the thing; made the. thing to be a support to the thing. (TA.) [Hence,] daraA^a AlHaAy^iTa bibinaA='K He conjoined the wall with a structure [so as to support the former by the latter]. (TA.) ― -b5- daraA^a biHajarK He cast a stone; like radaA^a. (TA.) You say, daraA^ahu biHajar and radaA^ahu bihi He cast a stone at him. (M in art. rdA^.) ― -b6- daraA^a said of a torrent, (K,) inf. n. daro'N, (TA,) (tropical:) It rushed, or poured forth with vehemence; as also AndrA^↓. (K.) And daraA^a AlwaAdiY biAls~ayoli (assumed tropical:) The valley poured along the torrent. (TA.) [See also daro'N, below.] ― -b7- daraA^a, (K,) inf. n. duruwo'N, (TA,) is syn. with TaraA^a [He came from a place, or from a distant place, unexpectedly; &c.]. (K.) And you say, daraA^a EalayonaA fulaAnN, (T, S, K, * TA,) inf. n. duruwo'N (S, TA) and daro'N; (TA;) and AndrA^↓ (S, TA) and tdr~A^↓; (TA;) Such a one came, or came forth, upon us unexpectedly, (T, S, K, * TA,) or whence we knew not; as also TaraA^a, (T,) and daraha. (IAar, TA in art. drh.) And Ealayohi bi$ar~K AndrA^↓, vulg. AndrY, He came upon him suddenly with evil, or mischief. (TA.) ― -b8- Hence, i. e. from daraA^a signifying “ he came, or came forth, unexpectedly, ” (T, S, TA,) daraA^a, inf. n. duruwo'N, said of a star, meaning (tropical:) It shone, or glistened, (S, K, TA,) intensely, (S, TA,) and its light spread: (TA:) or, as some say, it rose. (T.) [Hence also,] daraA^ati Aln~aAru (assumed tropical:) The fire gave light, shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (Sh, K.) ＝ -A2- daraA^a, (T, S, K,) aor.
daraAa
, (T,) inf. n. duruwo'N, (T, S,) He (a camel) had what is termed the gud~ap, (S, K,) i. e. the plague, or pestilence, (TaAEuwn,) of camels, (T,) and had therewith a tumour in his back, (S, K,) or in his naHor [or stabbing-place, in the uppermost part of the breast]: but in a female, it is in the udder: (TA:) or had a tumour in his naHor. (IAar, T.) The epithet applied to the male is daAriy^N↓: and so, accord. to ISk, to the female, (T, S,) meaning Attacked by the gud~ap in her maraAq, (T, and so in a copy of the S,) thus, without teshdeed to the q, signifying the part, of her throat, which is the place of passage of the water, (T, TA,) or in her maraAq~ [or thin and soft parts of the belly], (so in one of my copies of the S,) so that the protuberance of the gud~ap [or pestilential tumour] is apparent: which protuberance is termed daro'N↓. (T, S.)

3 mudaAraA^apN *
, primarily, (TA,) signifies The act of opposing; and repelling, or striving to repel: (S, TA:) or treating in an evil, or adverse, manner; and opposing: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or the putting one off in the matter of a right or due, by promising to render it time after time; and treating in an evil, or adverse, and a contrary, manner. (Mgh in arts. drY and $rY.) One says, daraA^otuhu I repelled him, or strove to repel him. (T, Msb, K.) And fulaAnN laA yudaAriy^u wa laA yumaAriY, (S, TA,) i. e. Such a one does not act in an evil, or adverse, manner, nor oppose, [nor does he wrangle, or dispute obstinately:] and lA yudaAriY, meaning, accord. to Sgh, if for lA yudaAriy^u, does not repel, or strive to repel, him who has a right from his right. (TA.) ― -b2- Accord. to El-Ahmar, in [the exercise of] good disposition, (T, S,) and in social intercourse, (S,) it is with and without '; (T, S;) contr. to the assertion of A 'Obeyd, who says that in this case it is without '. (T.) [F says,] daAraA^otuhu is syn. with daArayotuhu and daAfaEotuhu and laAyanotuhu [the second of which has a meaning explained above; the first and last meaning I treated him with gentleness or blandishment, soothed him, coaxed him, or wheedled him; &c.]; thus bearing two contr. significations: (K:) [or] daraA^otuhu and daArayotuhu both signify I was fearful, or cautious, of him; and treated him with gentleness or blandishment, or soothed him, coaxed him, wheedled him, or cajoled him: (S:) [but Az says,] I say that the verb with ' means I was fearful, or cautious, of him, as says AZ; or of his evil, or mischief: and daArayotu signifies “ I deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted; ” as also darayotu. (T.)

They repelled, or strove to repel, one another (M, Msb, K) in contention, or altercation, (M, K,) and the like; and disagreed. (M.) (TA.) See also 6, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b5- Also It (a thing) attained its proper time: (Msb, K:) it attained its final time or state, or its utmost point or degree. (K.) [He (a boy, and a beast,) attained his perfect, ripe, or mature, state; and in like manner Adrkt is said of a girl: or it is like Adrk as meaning] he (a boy) attained to puberty, (S, Msb,) or to the utmost term of youth. (TA.) It (fruit) attained to ripeness, or maturity; became ripe, or mature; (S Msb;) attained its time, and its utmost degree of ripeness or maturity. (T, TA.) And Adrkt Alqidoru The cooking-pot attained its proper time [for the cooking of its contents]. (TA.) And Adrkt Alxamoru [The wine became mature]. (Msb and K in art. xmr.) And Adrk maA='u Alr~akiy~api The water of the well reached its darak, i. e. its bottom (Aboo-' Adnán, TA.) ― -b6- Also It passed away and came to an end; came to nought; became exhausted; or failed entirely: (S, K:) said in this sense of flour, or meal: (S:) and thus it has been explained as used in the Kur [xxvii. 68], where it is said, [accord. to one reading,] balo A^adoraka Eilomuhumo fiY AlA=xirapi [Nay, their knowledge hath entirely failed respecting the world to come]. (TA. [See also 6.]) Sh mentions this signification as heard by him on no other authority than that of Lth; and Az asserts it to be incorrect: but it has been authorized by more than one of the leading lexicologists, and the language of the Arabs does not forbid it; for it is said of flour, or meal, and in this case can only mean it came to its end, and entirely failed, or became exhausted; and fruits, when they are ripe (A_i*aA A^adorakoto) are exposed to coming to nought, and so is everything that has attained to its extreme term; so that the signification of “ coming to nought ” is one of the necessary adjuncts of the meaning of A_idoraAkN. (TA.) [In like manner,] Aid~araka↓ signifies It (a thing) continued uninterruptedly and then come to nought: (IJ, TA:) and agreeably with this signification is explained the saying in the Kur [xxvi. 61], A_in~aA lamud~arikuwna [Verily we are coming to nought, by those who read thus instead of lamudorakuwna being overtaken]. (TA.) ― -b7- You say also, Adrk Alv~amanu Almu$otariYa, meaning [The payment of] the price was, or became, obligatory on the purchaser: this is an ideal reaching, or overtaking. (Msb.)

6 td~ArkwA dArk tdArk tdArkwA
i. q. tlAHqwA (S) [i. e.] They attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, one another; as also Aid~aArakuwA, and Aid~arakuwA↓; (Sh, TA;) [or] the last of them attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, the first of them. (S Msb, K, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [vii. 36], (S,) Hat~aY A_i*aA A@d~aArakuwA fiyhaA jamiyEFA [Until, when they have overtaken one another, or have successively arrived, therein, all together]: originally tadaArakuwA. (S, K. *) And tdArk Alv~ariyaAna [The two moistures reached each other; (like AilotaqaY Alv~arayaAni;) meaning] the moisture of the rain reached the moisture of the earth. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence] tdArk signifies [It continued, or was carried on, uninterruptedly; it was closely consecutive in its parts, or portions;] one part, or portion, of it, followed, or was made to follow, another uninterruptedly; said of anything. (TA.) You say, tdArk Als~ayoru [The course, or pace, or journeying, continued uninterruptedly]. (S and TA in art. Hfd, &c.) And tdArkt AlA^axobaAru The tidings followed one another closely. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, when said of knowledge, meaning, accord. to Fr, It continued unbroken in its sequence or concatenation.] bali A@d~araAka Eilomuhumo fiY AlA=xirapi (K, TA,) in the Kur [xxvii. 68], (TA,) [virtually] means Nay, they have no knowledge respecting the world to come: (K, TA:) or, as IJ says, their knowledge is hasty, and slight, and not on a sure footing, &c.: Az says that AA read balo A^adoraka [of which an explanation has been given above (see 4)]: that I'Ab is related to have read balaYA=A^adoraka↓ [&c., i. e. Yea, hath their knowledge reached its end &c.?], as interrogatory, and without tesh-deed: and that, accord. to the reading bl Ad~rAk Fr says that the proper meaning is, [Nay,] hath their knowledge continued unbroken so as to extend to the knowledge of the world to come, whether it will be or not be? wherefore is added, balo humo fiY $ak~K minohaA balo humo minohaA Eamuwna: he says also that Ubeí read, A^amo tadaAraka; and that the Arabs substitute balo for A^amo, and A^amo for balo, when a passage begins with an interrogation: but this explanation of Fr is not clear; the meaning is [said to be] their knowledge shall be unbroken and concurrent [respecting the world to come] when the resurrection shall have become a manifest event, and they shall have found themselves
to be losers; and the truth of that wherewith they have been threatened shall appear to them when their knowledge thereof will not profit them: accord. to Aboo-Mo'ádh the Grammarian, the readings balo A^adoraka↓ &c. and bali A@d~aAraka &c. mean the same; i. e. they shall know in the world to come; like the saying in the Kur [xix. 39], A^asomiEo bihimo waA^aboSiro, &c.: and Es-Suddee says of both these readings that the meaning is, their knowledge shall agree, or be in unison, in the world to come; i. e. they shall know in the world to come that that wherewith they have been threatened is true: or, accord. to Mujáhid, the meaning of bali A@d~aAraka Eilomuhumo &c. is said to be, is their knowledge concurrent respecting the world to come? bl being here used in the sense of A^am: (TA:) or it may mean their knowledge hath gone on uninterruptedly until it hath become cut short; from the phrase tdArk banuw fulaAnK meaning The sons of such a one went on uninterruptedly into destruction. (Bd.) ＝ -A2- tdArkhu: see 4, in two places. It is used in the [primary] sense of A^adorakahu in the saying in the Kur [lxviii. 49], lawo laA A^ano tadArakahu niEomapN mino rab~ihi lanubi*a biA@loEaraA='i [Had not favour (meaning mercy, Jel) from his Lord reached him, or overtaken him, he had certainly been cast upon the bare land]. (Jel.) ― -b2- [Hence, elliptically, He overtook him, or visited him, with good, or with evil.] El-Mutanebbee says,
A^ana fiY A^um~apK tadaArakahaA A@ll~`
hu gariybN kaSaAliHK fiY vamuwdi
[I am among a people (may God visit them with favour and save them from their meanness, or visit them with destruction so that I may be safe from them,) a stranger, like Sálih among Thamood]: tdArkhA All~`h is a prayer for the people, meaning All~`h wnj~Ahm mn lwmhm AdrkhA↓ [i. e. luw^omihimo]: or it may be an imprecation against them, i. e. All~`h bAlAhlAk liA^anojuwa mnhm Adrkhm↓: [each meaning as explained above:] and IJ says that because of this verse the poet was named Almtnb~Y. (W p. 35. [The verse there commences with A^anaA; but A^ana is required by the metre, and is more approved in every case except the case of a pause.]) It is mostly used in relation to aid, or relief, and benefaction: [so that it signifies He aided, or relieved, him; he benefited him; he repaired his, or its, condition; he repaired, amended, corrected, or rectified, it:] whence the saying of a poet,
tadaArakaniY mino Eavorapi Ald~ahori qaAsimN
bimaA $aA='a mino maEoruwfihi AlmutadAriki
[Kásim relieved me, or has relieved me, from the slip of fortune with what he pleased of his relieving, or continuous, beneficence]. (TA.) [See also, in the first paragraph of art. dq, another example, in a verse of Zuheyr, which is cited in that art. and the present in the TA: and see the syn. talaAfaAhu. Hence,] tadaArakotu maA faAta i. q. Astdrkthu, q. v. (S, Msb, TA.)

8 Aid~araka A^dAr A^dr A^drY A^drk Adrk dAr drY drk
: see 4, first and second sentences: ― -b2- and near the end of the paragraph: ― -b3- and see also 6, first sentence.

10 Astdrk Al$~aYo'a biAl$~aY'i *
[properly] signifies bihi HaAwala A_idoraAkahu↓ [i. e. He sought, or endeavoured, to follow up the thing with the thing]: (K:) as, for instance, AlxaTaA^a biAlS~awaAbi [the mistake with what was right]. (TK.) [Hence,] you say, Aisotadorakotu maAfaAta [I repaired, amended, corrected, or rectified, what had passed neglected by me, or by another; and I supplied what had so passed, or what had escaped me, or another, through inadvertence]; and tadaArakotuhu↓ signifies the same [in relation to language and to other things; whereas the former verb is generally restricted to relation to language or to a writer or speaker]. (S, Msb.) You say also, Astdrk Ealayohi qawolahu He corrected, or rectified, what was wrong, or erroneous, in his saying: [but more commonly, he supplied what he had omitted in his saying; generally meaning, what he had omitted through inadvertence: and Aisotadorakotuhu Ealayoh I subjoined it, or appended it, to what he had written, or said, by way of emendation; or, more commonly, as a supplement, i. e., to supply what had escaped him, or what he had neglected:] and hence, EalaY AlbuxaAriY~i Almusotadoraku↓ [The Supplement to ElBukháree; a work supplying omissions of ElBukháree;] by El-Hákim. (TA.) [Thus] AisotidoraAkN signifies The annulling a presumption, or surmise, originating from what has been before said, [by correcting an error, or errors, or by supplying a defect, or defects,] in a manner resembling the making an exception. (Kull.) [Hence Harofu A@sotidoraAkK, meaning A particle of emendation, applied to balo, and to l`kin~a or l`kino.]

darokN dr drk
: see the next paragraph, in eight places.

darakN dr drk
The act of attaining, reaching, or overtaking; syn. laHaAqN; (K, TA; [in the CK, All~iHAqu is erroneously put for All~aHaAqu;]) [properly an inf. n. of the unused verb daraka (q. v.), but, having no used verb, said to be] a noun from AlA_idoraAku [with which it is syn.], (TA,) or a noun from A^adorakotu Al$~aYo'a; as also darokN↓: and hence DamaAnN Ald~araki [which see in what follows]. (Msb.) [Hence,] laA taxaAfu darakFA, in the Kur [xx. 80.], means Thou shalt not fear Pharaoh's overtaking thee. (TA.) One says also AlT~arydapi farasN daroku↓, meaning A horse that overtakes what is hunted; like as they said farasN qayodu AlA^awaAbidi. (TA.) ― -b2- ― -b3- Also The attainment, or acquisition, of an object of want: and the seeking the attainment or acquisition thereof: as in the saying, bak~iro fafiyhi darakN [Be thou early; for therein is attainment, &c.]: and darokN↓ signifies the same. (Lth, TA.) [Hence, perhaps,] yawomu Ald~arika: this was [a day of contest] between El-Ows and El-Khazraj: (K:) thought to be so by IDrd. (TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. tabiEapN [i. e. A consequence; generally meaning an evil consequence: and perhaps it also means here a claim which one seeks to obtain for an injury]: as also darokN↓. (S, K.) One says, maA laHiqaka mino darakK faEalaY~i xalaASuhu (S, TA) and mn darokK↓ [i. e. Whatever evil consequence ensue to thee, on me be the compensation thereof]: in the A, mA A^adorakahu mn darakK fElY~ xlASh i. e. maA yaloHaquhu mino tabiEapK [Whatever evil consequence ensue to it, &c.; relating to a thing sold]. (TA.) And hence DamaAnu Ald~araki in the case of a claim for indemnification for a fault of a defect or an imperfection in a thing sold [meaning either Responsibility, or indemnification, (see DamaAnN,) for evil consequence]: (TA in the present art:) or this means [indemnification for evil consequence in a sale; i. e., virtually,] the returning of the price to the purchaser on the occasion of requirement by the thing sold: the vulgar say incorrectly [DamaAn darak, and still more incorrectly] DumaAn darak [generally meaning thereby I sell this, or I purchase this, on the condition of responsibility, or indemnification, for any fault or defect or imperfection that may be found in it]: (TA in art. Dmn:) [and in this manner DamaAnu Ald~araki may be correctly rendered; for] darakN also signifies a fault or a defect or an imperfection [in a thing sold]; for instance, in a slave that is sold. (TA in art. Ehd.) [In the KT, Ald~araku is also explained as signifying The purchaser's taking from the seller a pledge for the price that he has given him, in fear that the thing sold may require it: but this seems to be an explanation of the case in which the word is used; not of the word itself.] ＝ -A2- Also A rope, (M, K,) or a piece of rope, (S,) that is tied upon the [lower] extremity of the main rope (S, M, K) of a well, to the cross pieces of wood of the bucket, (S,) so as to be that which is next the water, (S, M, K,) in order that the main rope may not rot (S, M) in the drawing of water: (M:) or a doubled rope that is tied to the cross pieces of wood of the bucket, and then to the main wellrope: (Az, TA:) and darokN↓ signifies the same. (K. [But only darakN is authorized by the TA in this sense.]) [See also karabN.] ― -b2- Also, and darokN↓, The bottom, or lowest depth, (Sh, T, S, M, K,) of a thing, (T, M, K,) as of the sea and the like, (T,) or of anything deep, as a well and the like: (Sh:) pl. A^adoraAkN, (K,) a pl. of both, of a form frequent and analogous with respect to the former, but extr. with respect to the latter; and darakaAtN also. (TA.) And A stage of Hell: (IAar:) a stage downwards: (MA:) or stages downwards; like darakaAtN: (B:) opposed to darajN (MA, B) and darajaAtN, (B,) which are upwards: wherefore, (MA, B,) the abodes of Hell, or the stages thereof, are termed darakaAtN; (AO, S, MA, K, B;) [Golius and Freytag give darakapN as its sing.; the former as from the S, and the latter as from the K, in neither of which it is found;] and those of Paradise, darajaAtN. (S, MA, B.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 144], A_in~a A@lomunaAfiqiyna fiYA@ld~araki A@loA^asofali mina A@ln~aAri [Verily the hypocrites shall be in the lowest stage of the fire of Hell]: here the Koofees, except two, read fY Ald~aroki↓. (TA.) ― -b3- [Golius gives another signification, “ Pars terræ, ” as on the authority of the S and K, in neither of which it is found.]

dirokapN drk drkh drkp
The ring of the bow-string, (K, TA,) that
falls into the notch of the bow. (TA.) ― -b2- And A thong that is joined to the string of the bow, (K,) of the Arabian bow. (TA.) ― -b3- And A piece that is joined to the girdle when it is too short, (Lh, K,) and in like manner, to a rope, or cord, when it is too short. (Lh, TA.)

daraAki drAk drY
an imperative verbal noun, (S,) meaning A^adoriko [Attain thou, reach thou, overtake thou, &c.]: (K:) form the unused verb daraka: (IB:) like taraAki [from taraka], meaning A^utoruko. (TA.)

diraAkN drAk drY
[an inf. n. of 3, used in the sense of the part. n. mutadaArikN↓]. You say, TaEanahu TaEonFA diraAkFA He thrust him, or pierced him, with an uninterrupted thrusting or piercing: and $ariba $urobFA diraAkFA He drank with an uninterrupted drinking: and DarobN diraAkN An uninterrupted beating or striking. (TA.)

diraAkapN drAk drAkh drAkp
: see madorakN.

dariykapN drykh drykp
i. q. TariydapN [as meaning An animal that is hunted]. (S, K.)

dar~aAkN drAk drY
an epithet from A^adoraka, (S, Kudot;,) applied to a man, (K,) and signifying kaviyru AlA_idoraAki [i. e. One who attains, reaches, or overtakes, &c., much, or often: and also having much, or great, or strong, perception: as will be seen from what follows]: (S, TA:) and so mudorikN↓ [expressly said in the TA to signify kvyr AlAdrAk, though why it should have this signification as well as that (which it certainly has) of simply attaining &c., I cannot see,] and mudorikapN↓: (K, TA:) the last explained by Lh as signifying sariyEu AlA_idoraAki [i. e. quick in attaining, &c.]. (TA.) Keys Ibn-Rifá'ah says,
waSaAHibu Alwitori layosa Ald~ahora mudorikahu↓
EinodiY waA_in~iY ladar~aAkN biA^awotaAri
[And he who has a claim for blood-revenge is not ever an attainer of it with (meaning from) me; but verily I am one who often attains bloodrevenges]. (IB.) Seldom does faE~aAlN come from A^afoEala; but they sometimes said Has~aAsN dar~aAkN [i. e. Having much, or great, or strong, perception]; it being [in this instance] a dialectal syn. [of Hs~As], or thus for conformity: (S:) it is said to be the only instance of faE~aAlN from A^afoEala except jab~aArN and saA^~=rN; [and some other instances might be added; but all of them require consideration:] accord. to IB, dr~Ak is from the unused verb daraka. (TA.)

madorakN mdr mdrk
: see mudorakN ― -b2- lahu madorakN [if not a mistranscription for mudorikN or mudorakN] means He has a sense in excess; [app. a preternatural perception, or a second sight;] and so diraAkapN↓. (TA.)

mudorakN mdr mdrk
A place, and a time, of A_idoraAkN [i. e. attaining, reaching, overtaking, &c.]. (Msb.) Hence madaAriku Al$~aroEi; (Mgh, Msb;) among which is included investigation of the law by means of reason and comparison; (Mgh;) i. e. The sources from which are sought the ordinances of the law; where one seeks for guidance by means of texts [of the Kur-án or the Sunneh] and by means of investigation by reason and comparison: (Msb:) the lawyers make the sing. to be madorakN↓; (Mgh, * Msb;) but there is no way of resolving this: (Msb:) correctly, by rule, it is mudorakN; because the meaning intended is a place of A_idoraAk. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Also pass. part. n. of 4. ― -b3- And hence, Perceived by means of any of the senses; like maHosuwsN: and perceived by the intellect; thus opposed to maHosuwsN.]

mudorikN mdr mdrk
: see dar~aAkN, in two places. ― -b2- [Alquw~apu Almudorikapu, and simply Almudorikapu, as a subst., The perceptive faculty of the mind. See also what next follows.]

mudorikapN mdrk mdrkh mdrkp
: see dar~aAkN. ― -b2- [See also mudorikN.] ― -b3- AlmudorikaAtu Alxamosu and AlmadaAriku Alxamosu signify The five senses. (TA.) [See also madorakN.] ＝ -A2- Also The Hajomap [a word I do not find in any other instance, app. a mistranscription for maHojamap (which when written with the article differs very little from the former word) i. e. the place to which the cupping-vessel is applied, for this is often] between the two shoulder-blades: (K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

mudaArikapN mdArk mdArkh mdArkp
A woman (TA) that will not be satiated with coitus; (K, TA;) as though her fits of appetency were consecutive. (TA.)

mutadaArikN mtdArk
Uninterrupted; or closely consecutive in its parts, or portions: differing from mutawaAtirN, which is applied to a thing in the case of which there are small intervals. (Lh.) See also diraAkN. ― -b2- Applied to a rhyme, (Lth, M, K,) and to a word, (Lth, TA,) Having two movent letters followed by a quiescent letter; as faEuwo and the like: (Lth, TA:) or having two movent letters between two quiescent letters; as mutafaAEiluno, (M, K,) and musotafoEiluno, and mafaAEiluno, (M, TA,) and faEuwluno faEalo, (M, K,) i. e. as faEalo when immemediately following a quiescent letter, (M, TA,) and faEuwlu fulo, (M, K,) i. e. as fulo with a movent letter immediately followed by it: (M, TA:) as though the vowel-sounds overtook one another without an obstacle between the two movent letters. (M, K.) ― -b3- [AlmutadaAriku is also the name of The sixteenth metre of verse; the measure of which consists of faAEiluno eight times.]

musotadorakN mstdrk
[A supplement]: see 10. ― -b2- [In the TA and some other similar works, it is often used as signifying Superfluous, or redundant.]

1 darina dAr drn drnn
, aor.
darana
, inf. n. daranN; (T, * S, * M, Msb, K; *) and Adrn↓; (T, M, K;) It (a garment, S, M, &c.) was, or became, dirty, or filthy: (S, M, Msb, K:) or was, or became, defiled, polluted, or smeared, with dirt, or filth. (T, K.) And darinato yaduhu biAl$~aYo'i His hand was, or became, defiled, polluted, or smeared, with the thing. (K.)

4 Adrn A^dAr A^drn A^drnn Adrn drn
: see 1. ＝ -A2- Also He rendered a garment dirty, or filthy: (S, K:) or he defiled, polluted, or smeared, a garment with dirt, or filth. (K.) ＝ -A3- A^adoranati AlA_ibilu The camels fed upon what is termed dariyn: (M, K:) thus they do in the case of drought, or sterility. (M.)

daranN dAr drn drnn
Dirtiness, or filthiness; or dirt, or filth: (S, M, K:) or defilement, or pollution, with dirt or filth: (T, K:) and accord. to the K, AlA_idorawonN↓ also is syn. with Ald~aranu; but ISd says that this is not known. (So in the TA. [In the text of the M, however, as given in the TT, in the place of Ald~aranu in this case I find AlradiY= (for Alr~adiYo'u, i. e. the bad, &c.); and another passage in the M, respecting a signification of A_idorawonN, (which see below,) suggests that the explanation of AlA_idorawonu as meaning Ald~aranu may have been taken from this passage in consequence of an oversight.]) maAkaAna A_il~aA kadaranK bikaf~iY, meaning It was no otherwise than like dirt in my hand, which I therefore wiped with the other hand, is a prov. applied in the case of a thing done in haste. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^um~u daranK means (assumed tropical:) The present world, or the present state of existence. (Z, K.) ― -b3- daranN is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Vileness, ignominy, or abjectness. (Har p. 509.)

darinN dAr drn drnn
(S, M, Msb, K) and A^adoranu↓, (M, TA,) applied to a garment, Dirty, or filthy: (S, M, Msb, K:) or defiled, polluted, or smeared, with dirt, or filth. (K.) ― -b2- And, so applied, Old and worn out; as also dariynN↓. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] yadaAhu daranaAtN biAlxayori (tropical:) [in the CK mina Alxayori, His hands are worn out by beneficence; meaning, much used therein]: and A^ayodiyhimo diraAnN (tropical:) [Their hands are worn out thereby]: and huwa darinu Alyadayoni (tropical:) [He is worn out in respect of the hands thereby]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- darinapN applied to a she-camel means Mangy, or scabby. (TA.)

daranN dAr drn drnn
, like saHaAbN, (K,) or dar~aAnN↓, (so accord. to the TT as from the M,) The fox. (M, K.)

dariynN drY dryn
: see darinN. ― -b2- Also, (S, M, K,) and duraAnapN↓, (M, K,) Dry herbage: (M:) and whatever is broken in pieces, of [plants of the kind termed] HamoD, or of trees, or of herbs, or leguminous plants, (M, K,) of such as are eaten without being cooked, or are slender and succulent or soft or sweet, and such as are hard and thick, or thick and inclining to bitterness, or thick and rough, when old (M) and dry: (M, K:) or dariynN signifies what is broken in pieces, of herbage, when it is old (S, TA) and withered, or wasted, and black; (so in a copy of the S;) i. e. withered, or wasted, herbage; such as is seldom made use of by the camels: (S, TA:) or herbage that has become a year old, and then dried up: (Th, M:) dry herbage a year old: (Lth, T:) or dry and old herbage. (Ham p. 527.) ― -b3- [Hence,] A^um~u dariynK (assumed tropical:) Sterile, or unfruitful, land. (S, K.) A poet says,
taEaAla nusam~iTo Hub~a daEodK wanagotadiY
sawaA='ayoni waAlmaroEaY biA^um~i dariyni
[Come thou, let us keep to our love of Daad (a woman's name), and we will go forth early in the morning, both alike, though the pasturing be in sterile land]: he means, we will keep to our
love, though the means of subsistence be strait. (S.)

duraAnapN drAnh drAnp

dar~aAnN drAn
: see daraAnN.

A^adoranu *

, quasi-coordinate to jirodaHolN, (IJ, M,) i. q. A=riY~N (M, K) or A=xiy~apN (TA in art. Axw) [A rope, or loop of a rope, to which a beast is tied: for further explanations, see A=xiy~apN]: and a manger: (M, K:) pl. A^adaAriynu. (TA in art. Axw.) (TA.) ― -b2- A place of abode; settled place of abode; place of constant residence; dwelling; or home. (M, K.) So in the saying, rajaEa A_ila A_idorawonihi [He returned to his place of abode, &c. See also what next follows.] (M.) ― -b3- I. q. A^aSolN [app. as meaning Origin; or original state or condition: and this may sometimes be meant by the phrase immediately preceding]: (M, K:) particularly such as is bad, accord. to some, who derive it from Ald~aranu: but this is nought, or of no account. mudorinN mdrn
Dry firewood. (M, K.)

midoraAnN mdr mdrAn
, applied to a man and to a woman, Very dirty or filthy: (IAar, M, K: *) pl. madaAriynu. (M.) ＝ -A2- And A gazelle that eats dariyn. (K.)

, (S, Msb, K,) and lahumo, (K,) aor.
daraha
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. darohN, (TA,) He repelled from them, or defended them; (S, K;) like daraA^a, from which it is [said to be] formed by substitution, as haraAqa from A^araAqa; (S;) and so darahahumo: (Har p. 551: [but for this I find no other authority:]) or he spoke for them, and repelled from them or defended them. (Msb.) ― -b2- daraha Ealayohimo, aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) or the inf. n. is duruwhN, (JK,) He came upon them suddenly, or unawares, (IAar, K,) whence they did not expect him; like daraA^a: (IAar, TA:) and [simply] he came upon them. (JK, K.) ― -b3- darohN also signifies The being bold, or daring. And daEawotu Aln~aAsa, (Msb,) inf. n. duEaA='N and daEowapN, (S,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and madoEaApN, (S, [app. there mentioned as an inf. n., agreeably with many other instances,]) means also I invited people to eat with me, or at my abode. (TA.) ― -b8- And daEaA Almay~ita He called upon the dead, praising him, and saying, Alas for such a one! or he wailed for, wept for, or deplored the loss of, the dead, and enumerated his good qualities and actions; as though he called him. (Msb.) ― -b10- daEaAhu A@ll~`hu (assumed tropical:) God destroyed him: [as though He called him away:] whence tadoEuw mano A^adobara watawal~aY, in the Kur lxx. 17, [describing the fire of Hell,] (assumed tropical:) It shall destroy him who shall have gone back from the truth and turned away from obedience: or this means (tropical:) it shall draw, and bring, &c.: or it refers to the zabaAniyap of Hell [i. e. the tormentors of the damned]: (Bd:) or it means (assumed tropical:) it will do to them hateful deeds. (TA.) [Also] God punished him, or tormented him. (TA.) And daEaAhu A@ll~`hu bimakoruwhK (tropical:) God caused an evil, or abominable, event to befall him. (ISd, Z, K.) ― -b11- daEaA fiY AlD~aroEi (tropical:) He left some milk, such as is termed daAEiyap, in the udder. (M, K, TA.) Accord. to IAth, daAEiyapN is an inf. n., like EaAqibapN and EaAfiyapN. (TA.)

3 mudaAEaApN dEymyS
signifies (tropical:) The proposing an enigma or enigmas to a person; or the contending with another in doing so; syn. muHaAjaApN. (S, K, TA.) You say, daAEayotuhu (tropical:) I proposed to him an enigma or enigmas; &c. (TA.) A poet says,
A^udaAEiyka maA musotaSoHabaAtN maEa Als~uraY
HisaAnN wamaA A=vaAruhaA biHisaAni
[(assumed tropical:) I propose to thee an enigma: What are things that are taken as companions in night-journeying, good, and the effects whereof are not good?]: meaning swords. (S.) ― -b2- And The asking a thing of one much, so as to weary; as also muHaAjaApN. (K.) ― -b3- daAEayonaA AlHaAy^iTa Ealayohimo (tropical:) We pulled down, or demolished, the wall upon them, from the sides [or foundations] thereof. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- [Golius assigns other significations to daAEaY, for which I find no authority: namely, “ Convocavit ad Deum propheta, præco sacer, ” followed by an accus.: and “ Contendit contra alium: Provocavit: pecul. rem vindicans sibi vel arrogans. ”]

4 A^adoEaAhu *
[so in some copies of the K; in other copies Aid~aEaAhu↓; the former of which I regard as the right reading;] He made him to assert his relationship as a son [for yudoEaY, in my copies of the K, I read yad~aEiY↓, syn. with yaEotaziY,] to one who was not his father. (K.) [SM, who appears to have read Aid~aEaAhu↓, says that it is like AisotaloHaqahu and AisotalaATahu.]

5 Alt~adaE~iY AltdEY AltdEy
[inf. n. of tadaE~ato] signifies The taToriyb [or singing, or quavering or trilling and prolonging of the voice, or prolonging and modulating of the voice,] of a woman wailing for the dead. (TA. [See daEaA Almay~ita, above.])

6 Alt~adaAEiY AltdAEY AltdAEy tdAEy
signifies The calling, summoning, or convoking, one another. (Mgh.) You say, tadaAEawo liloHarobi [They called, summoned, or convoked, one another for war: and hence,] (assumed tropical:) they prepared themselves for war. (TA.) And tadaAEawoA Ealayohi, (Msb, K,) or EalaY baniY fulaAnK, (T, M,) They collected themselves together, (K,) or called one another so that they assembled together, (M,) or leagued together, and called one another to mutual aid, (T, Msb, *) against him, (Msb, K,) or against the sons of such a one. (T, M.) And
tadaAEaY Ealayohi AlEaduw~u mino kul~i jaAnibK (assumed tropical:) The enemy advanced against him from every side. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tadaAEati Als~aHaAbapu biAlbaroqi waAlr~aEodi mino kul~i jaAnibK (assumed tropical:) The cloud lightened and thundered from every quarter. (TA.) And tadaAEaY AlbunoyaAnu, (Mgh, Msb,) or AlbinaA='u, (TA,) (tropical:) The building cracked in its sides, (Msb,) or became much broken, (TA,) and gave notice of falling to ruin: (Msb, TA:) or cracked in several places, without falling; and in like manner, tadaAEati AlHiyTaAnu, (Mgh,) the walls cracked in several places, without falling: (Mgh, K: *) and tadaAEati AlHiyTaAnu liloxaraAbi the walls fell to ruin by degrees; syn. tahaAdamat: (S:) [but Mtr says,] tadaAEato A_ilaY AlxaraAbi is a vulgar phrase; not [genuine] Arabic. (Mgh.) And tdAEY said of a sand-hill, (assumed tropical:) It, being put in notion, or shaken in its lower part, poured down. (Msb.) And [hence,] tadaAEato A_ibilu baniY fulaAnK (tropical:) (tropical:) The camels of such a one became broken by emaciation. (TA.) ― -b3- tadaAEawo biAlA^aloqaAbi They called one another by surnames, or nicknames. (Msb.) ― -b4- Alt~adaAEiY also signifies (assumed tropical:) The trying one another with an enigma or enigmas; or contending, one with another, in proposing an enigma or enigmas; syn. Alt~aHaAjiY. (TA in art. Hjw.) You say, bayonahumo A^udoEiy~apN yatadaAEuwona bihaA (assumed tropical:) [Between them is an enigma with which they try one another; or by proposing which they contend, one with another]. (S, K. *) ― -b5- yatadaAEawona faSola AlxiTaAbi (assumed tropical:) They compete, one with another, [as though each one challenged the others,] in discoursing of the science of chasteness of speech, and eloquence. (Har p. 446.) ― -b6- See also 8, in two places. ＝ -A2- [It is also used transitively:] you say, tadaAEawuA Alqawoma They [together] called the people. (Mgh in art. nqD. [See 6 in that art.])

7 AndEY AndEY AndEy
i. q. A^ajaAba. (K.) Akh heard one or more of the Arabs say, lawodaEawonaA laA@nodaEayonaA, meaning laA^ajubonaA [i. e. Had they called us, &c., we had certainly answered, or replied, or assented, or consented]. (S.)

8 Aid~aEaY A^dEY A^dEy AdEY AdEy dEA {dEY
He asserted a thing to be his, or to belong to him, or to be due to him, either truly or falsely: (K, * TA:) he claimed a thing; laid claim to it; or demanded it for himself: and he desired a thing; or wished for it. (Msb.) And Aid~aEawuA Al$~aYo'a and Al$Y' tadaAEawuA↓ signify the same [i. e. They claimed the thing, every one of them for himself]. (Mgh.) You say, Aid~aEayotu EalaY fulaAnK ka*aA [I asserted myself to have a claim upon such a one for such a thing; preferred a claim against such a one for such a thing; or claimed of such a one such a thing]. (S.) And Aid~aEaY zayodN EalaY Eamorw maAlFA [Zeyd asserted himself to have a claim upon 'Amr for property; or preferred a claim against 'Amr &c.]. (Mgh.) And Aid~aEayota EalaY~a maA lamo A^afoEalo [Thou hast asserted against me, or charged against me, or accused me of, that which I have not done]. (S and K in art. $rb, and S in art. Akl.) h`*aA A@l~a*iY kunotumo bihi tad~aEuwna, in the Kur [lxvii. 27], means This is that on account of which ye used to assert vain and false things: or which ye used to deny, or disbelieve: or, accord. to Fr, the latter verb may here be used in the sense of tadoEuwna; and the meaning may be, this is that which ye desired to hasten, and for which ye prayed to God in the words of the Kur [viii. 32], “ O God, if this be the truth from Thee, then rain Thou upon us stones from Heaven, or bring upon us some [other] painful punishment: ” it may be from Ald~uEaA='u: and it may be from Ald~aEowaY: (TA:) [i. e.] it means this is that which ye used to demand, and desire to hasten; from Ald~uEaA='u: or that which ye used to assert, [namely,] that there will be no raising to life; from Ald~aEowaY. (Bd.) And walahumo maA yad~aEuwna, in the Kur [xxxvi. 57], is explained as meaning And they shall have what they desire, or wish for; which is referrible to the meaning of Ald~uEaA='u. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, Aid~aEaY gayora A^abiyhi [He asserted the relationship of father to him of one who was not his father; or claimed as his father one who was not his father]. (T, Mgh, Msb.) And yad~aEiY A_ilaY gayori A^abiyhi [He asserts his relationship as a son, or claims the relationship of a son, to one who is not his father]. (T, Msb. See 4, in three places.) And yad~aEiyhi gayoru A^abiyhi [One who is not his father asserts him to be his son; or claims him as his son]. (T, Msb.) AlAid~iEaA='u in war signifies The asserting one's relationship; syn. AlAiEotizaA='u; (S, TA;) as also Alt~adaAEiY↓; (TA;) i. e. the saying “ I am such a one the son of such a one. ” (S.) And [hence] sometimes it includes the meaning of Informing, or telling; and therefore bi may be prefixed to its objective complement; so that one says, fulaAnN yad~aEiY bikarami fiEaAlihi, i. e. Such a one informs of the generosity of his deeds. (Msb.)

10 A_isotadoEawa
see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence, AstdEY signifies also It called for, demanded, required, or invited, a thing. See also daEaAbihi.]

daEowapN dE dEA dEwh dEwp wdE
[as an inf. n. of un.] signifies A single time or act (S, Msb) [of prayer and of imprecation, as is indicated in the S, and also, though less plainly, in the TA]. See duEaA='N. ― -b2- [Also, as such, A call.] You say, huwamin~iY daEowapu Alr~ajula (K, TA) and Alkalobi, and daEowapa Alr~ajuli and Alkalobi, in the former case dEwp being used as a simple subst., and in the latter case as an adv. n., (TA,) meaning qadoru maA bayoniY wabayonahu *aAka [i. e. He, or it, is distant from me the space of the call of the man and of the dog]. (K, TA.) And lahumu Ald~aEowapu EalaY gayorihimo The call is to them before the others of them: (K, TA: [yabodaA^u in the CK is a mistake for yubodaA^u:]) accord. to the T and the Nh, in the case of gifts, or pay, or salary. (TA.) ― -b3- The call to prayer: whence, in a trad., Ald~aEuwapu fiY AlHaba$api [meaning The office of calling to prayer rests among the Abyssinians]; (JM, TA;) said by the Prophet in preference of his muw^a*~in Bilál. (JM.) ― -b4- A call, or an invitation, to El-Islám. (Mgh.) You say, A^adoEuwka bidaEowapi AlA_isolaAmi and AlslAm diEaAyapi↓ and AlAslAm daAEiyapi↓, meaning I call thee, or invite thee, by the declaration of the faith whereby the people of false religions are called: daAEiyapN being an inf. n. syn. with daEowapN, like EaAfiyapN and EaAqibapN: (JM:) daEowapu AlA_isolaAmi and daEAyatuhu↓ and daAEiyatuhu↓ signify the same: and daEowapu AlHaq~i [in like manner] means the declaration that there is no deity but God. (TA.) ― -b5- An invitation to food, (S, M, Msb, K, TA,) and to beverage; or, accord. to Lh, specially a repast, feast, or banquet, on the occasion of a wedding or the like: (TA:) thus pronounced by most of the Arabs, except 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, who pronounce it, in this sense, diEowapN↓: (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Msb:) it is an inf. n. in this sense, (S,) or a simple subst.: (Msb:) and duEowapN↓ signifies the same; (K;) or, as some say, this, which is given as on the authority of Ktr, is a mistake: (TA:) and so does madoEaApN↓ [app. an inf. n.]. (S, Msb, K.) You say, kun~aAfiY daEowapi fulaAnK and madoEaAtihi↓, meaning [We were included in] the invitation (duEaA=' [see 1]) of such a one to food: (S, Msb: [but in the latter, naHonu, in the place of kun~aA:]) [or we were at the repast, or feast, or banquet, of such a one; for] you say [also] daEaAhu A_ilaY Ald~aEowapi and AlY AlmadoEaApi↓ [He invited him to the repast, or feast, or banquet: and in this sense daEowap is commonly used in the present day]. (MA.) ― -b6- See also diEowapN: ― -b7- and daEowaY. ― -b8- Also i. q. HalifN or HalofN (accord. to different copies of the K) [both in the sense of Confederation to aid or assist]: (K, TA:) [whence] one says, daEowapN fulaAnK fiY baniY fulaAnK [meaning The confederation of such a one is with the sons of such a one]. (TA.)

duEowapN dE dEA dEwh dEwp wdE
: see the next preceding paragraph.

diEowapN dE dEA dEwh dEwp wdE
respects relationship, (S, Msb,) like daEowaY↓ or daEowaY fiY Aln~asabi; (S;) meaning A claim in respect of relationship; (K;) [i. e.] one's claiming as his father a person who is not his father; (Az, Mgh, Msb;) [in other words,] one's claiming the relationship of a son to a person who is not his father: or one's being claimed as a son by a person who is not his father: (Az, Msb:) thus pronounced by most of the Arabs, except 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, who pronounce it, in this sense, daEowapN↓. (S, Msb.) See also daEowaY. ― -b2- Also Kindred, or relationship, and brotherhood: so in the saying, liY fiYAlqawomi diEowapN [I have in, or among, the people, or company of men, kindred, or relationship, and brotherhood]. (Ks, Msb.) ― -b3- See also daEowapN.

daEowaY dEwY dEwy
: see duEaA='N, in five places. ― -b2- Also a subst. from 8; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, TA;) omitted in the K, though better known than the sun; (TA;) and so daEaAwapN↓ (M, Msb, K) and diEaAwapN↓ and diEowapN↓, (M, K,) accord. to the general pronunciation, (M, TA,) and daEowapN↓, (M, K,) accord. to the pronunciation of 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, (M, TA,) and daAEiyapN↓; (TA, there said to be syn. with daEowaY;) [meaning An assertion that a thing belongs to one, or is due to one; a claim; as is indicated in the S and Mgh and K &c.;] a demand; a suit; (Yz, Az, Msb;) whether true
or false: (Mgh, K, TA:) the pl. of daEowaY is daEaAwK and daEaAwaY; the former of which is preferable accord. to some, being, as IJ says, the original form; but some say that the latter is preferable: (Msb:) [the latter only is mentioned in the Mgh:] the alif in the sing. [written Y] is a sign of the fem. gender; and therefore the word is without tenween. (Mgh.) Yz mentions the sayings, liY fiY h`*aA AlA^amori daEowaY I have, in respect of this thing, [a claim or] a demand, and daEaAwaY or daEaAwK [claims or] demands, as written in different copies. (Az, Msb.) And lawo A^uEoTiYa Aln~aAsu bidaEaAwiyhimo [If men were given according to their claims, or demands,] occurs in a trad. (Msb.) ― -b3- See also diEowapN.

duEowiY~N dEwY dEwy
is a word used only in negative sentences: (S:) you say, maA biAld~aAri duEowiY~N There is not in the house any one: (S, K: *) Ks says that it is from daEawotu, and [properly] means layosa fiyhaA mano yadoEuw [there is not in it one who calls, &c.]. (S.)

duEaA='N dEA='
is an inf. n. of 1; (Msb, K;) as also daEowaY↓: (K:) the former is originally duEaAwN: (S:) [both, used as simple substs., signify A prayer, or supplication, to God:] and the pl. of the former is A^adoEiyapN. (S.) IF says that some of the Arabs, for daEowapN↓, say daEowaY↓, with the fem. alif [written Y]. (Msb, TA.) One says, Aall~`hum~a Almusolimiyna A^a$orikonaA fiY daEowaY↓, meaning [O God, make us to share] in the prayer (duEaA=') of the Muslims. (TA.) And hence, in the Kur [x. 10], fiyhaA suboHaAnak A@ll~`hum~a daEowaAhumo↓ [Their prayer in it shall be sbHAnk All~`hm~]. (TA.) [duEaA='N followed by li signifies An invocation of good, a blessing, or a benediction: followed by EalaY, an imprecation of evil, a curse, or a malediction.] suwrahu Ald~uEaA='i is a title of The first chapter of the Kur-án. (Bd.) ― -b2- [Hence,] duEaA='N signifies also Adoration, worship, or religious service. (TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. A_iymaAnN [i. e. Belief; particularly in God, and in his word and apostles &c.: faith: &c.]: a meaning mentioned by the Expositors of El-Bukháree. (TA.) ― -b4- [Also A call, or cry; and so daEowaY↓, as in the Kur vii. 4 (where the latter is explained by Bd as syn. with the former) and xxi. 15.] ― -b5- And [particularly] A calling, or crying, for aid or succour. (TA.)

daEiY~N dEA dEY dEy wdE
One invited to a repast: pl. duEawaA='u; as in the saying Einodahu duEawaA='u [With him, or at his abode, are guests invited to a repast]. (TA.) ― -b2- One who makes a claim in respect of relationship; (S;) [i. e.] one who claims as his father a person who is not his father; (Az, Mgh, Msb;) [in other words,] one who claims the relationship of a son to a person who is not his father: or one who is claimed as a son by a person who is not his father; (Az, Msb;) an adopted son: (S, K:) pl. A^adoy^iyaA='u, (S,) which is anomalous; (Bd in xxxiii. 4;) occurring in the Kur [in the verse just referred to], where it is said, wamaAjaEala A^adoy^iyaA'akumo A^abonaA='akumo (S) Nor hath He made your adopted sons to be your sons in reality. (Jel.) ― -b3- And One whose origin, or lineage, or parentage, is suspected; (K, TA;) as also madoEiY~N↓: pl. of the former as in the next preceding sentence. (TA.)

daEaAwapN dEAwh dEAwp
and diEaAwapN: see daEowaY.

diEaAyapN dEAyh dEAyp
: see daEowapN, in two places.

daE~aA='N dEA='
One who prays, or supplicates God, or who calls, &c., much, or often. (TA.)

Ald~aE~aA='apu AldEA='h AldEA='p
[an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates;] The sab~aAbap [or fore finger]; (K;) i. e. the finger with which one calls [or beckons]. [TA.)

daAEK dAE dAEy
[Praying, or supplicating God:] calling, or summoning: (Mgh:) [inviting:] and particularly, [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] one who calls, or summons, or invites, to obey a right or a wrong religion: (TA:) pl. duEaApN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and daAEuwna. (Msb, TA.) [Hence,] daAEiY A@ll~`hi [God's summoner, or inviter; i. e.] the prophet: (K:) and also, (Msb, K,) or simply Ald~aAEiY, (TA,) The muw^a*~in [or summoner to prayer]. (Msb, K, TA.) [Hence also, daAEiY AlmanaAyaA The summoner of death, lit. of deaths; like TaAriqu AlmanaAyaA] ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places. ― -b3- Also A punisher. (TA.)

daAEiyapN dAEy dAEyh dAEyp
: see daEowapN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also daEowaY. ― -b3- daAEiy~apN All~abani The remainder of the milk, (K,) or what is left, of the milk, in the udder, (S, Mgh,) that draws, or attracts, (K,) or in order that it may draw, or attract, (S, Mgh,) what is to come after it; (S, Mgh, K; *) as also All~abani daAEiY↓, occurring in a trad., where it is said, daEo daAEiYa All~abani [Leave thou the remainder of the milk, in the udder, that is to draw, or attract, what is to come after it]; (S, Mgh;) i. e. do not exhaust it entirely. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Hence, daAEiyapN is metaphorically applied to signify (tropical:) A mean, or means; a cause; or a motive; (Har p. 306;) [as also daAEK↓, often used in these senses in the present day;] and so, in an intensive sense, madoEaApN↓ [properly signifying a cause of drawing, attracting, or inducing, &c., originally madoEawapN, being a noun of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN]: (Idem p. 86:) [the pl. of the first is dawaAEK.] ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) The cry of horsemen in battle; (K;) as being a call to him who will aid, or succour. (TA.) ― -b6- dawaAEiY AlS~adori (assumed tropical:) The anxiety [or rather anxieties] of the bosom. (Ham p. 509.) ― -b7- dawaAEiY Ald~ahori (tropical:) The vicissitudes of fortune: (K, TA:) sing. daAEiyapN. (TA.)

A^udoEuw~apN *
: see what next follows.

A^udoEiy~apN *
(S, K) and A^udoEuw~apN↓ (K) An enigma; a riddle; (S, K; *) like A^uHojiy~apN [and A^uHojuw~apN]; and including such as is in verse, like that quoted above, in the second paragraph of this article. (S.)

madoEaApN mdEAh mdEAp
: see daEowapN, latter part, in three places: ― -b2- and see also daAEiyapN: [pl. madaAEK. ― -b3- Hence the saying,] lahu masaAEK wamadaAEK, i. e. (tropical:) [He possesses means of attaining honour and elevation, and] causes of glorying, or memorable and generous qualities, especially in war. (TA.)

[
madoEuw~N mdEw mdEy
pass. part. n. of 1; as also madoEiY~N↓.]

madoEiY~N mdEY mdEy mdEyy
: see what next precedes: ― -b2- and see also daEiY~N, last sentence.

mud~aEFY mdEY mdEy mdEyy
Claimed property [&c.]: mud~aEFY bihi is nought. (Mgh.) ― -b2- mud~aEFY Ealayohi One upon whom a claim is made for property [&c.]. (Mgh.) [A defendant in a law-suit.]

mud~aEK mdE mdEy
Claiming property [&c.]; a claimant. (Mgh.) [A plaintiff in a law-suit.]

1 daEayotu dEA dEyt
, aor. A^adoEiY, inf. n. duEaA='N: see 1 in art. dEw.

daEiY~N dEA dEY dEy wdE
: &c.: see art. dEw.

1 dagara dgr
, aor.
dagara
, (K,) inf. n. dagorN, (S, A, K,) He pushed, thrust, drove, impelled, or repelled. (S, A, K.) This is the primary signification. (S, A.) ― -b2- dagarahu, aor. as above, He pressed him, or squeezed him, until he died. (K.) ― -b3- dagarato Haloqa AlS~abiY~, (TK,) aor.
dagara
, (K,) inf. n. dagorN, (S, K,) She pressed the throat, or fauces, of the child, (K, * TA,) on account of the pain termed AlEu*orapu, (S, * TA,) and (or that is to say, TA) raised his uvula with her finger, (S, K, TA,) compressing that part on the occasion of the pain's being excited by the blood. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) So in the trad., EalaAma tuEa*~ibona A^awolaAdakun~a biAld~agori Wherefore do ye torment your children by raising the uvula &c.: (S:) and laA tuEa*~ibona A^awolaAdakun~a biAld~agori Torment ye not your children by pressing the throat, or fauces, &c. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b4- And dagarato waladahaA, (TK,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (K,) She fed her child ill: and she suckled him without satisfying him, (K,) so that he remained hungry, and applied himself to every one he met, and ate and sucked, and would suck the dug of a ewe or goat: and the like is said of a she-camel with respect to her young one, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed Es-Sukkaree, who thus explains the latter of the two traditions quoted above; but Az says that the right explanation is that given by A 'Obeyd, as is shown in the traditions [elsewhere]. (TA.) ― -b5- dagara Al$~aYo'a biAl$~aYo'i, (TK,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (K,) He mixed the thing with the thing. (K, * TK.) ＝ -A2- dagara Ealayohi, (K,) aor.
dagara
, (TA,) inf. n. dagorN, (K,) and dagoraY↓, (K, TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (TA,) He rushed upon him without consideration; (K, TA;) he charged upon him. (TA.) Hence the saying, laASaf~aY dagoraY↓, (S, A, K, *) and dagaraY↓, and dagoraA='a↓, (K,) and dagorFA laA Saf~FA, (S, K,) like EaqoraY waHaloqaY, and EaqorFA waHaloqFA, (S,) i. e., Rush ye upon them without
consideration, and oppose them not in regular ranks: (S, * A, * K, * TA:) or mix ye among them, &c. (Kr.) A woman is related to have said to her son, walaA Saf~aY A_i*aA raA^ati AlEayonu AlEayona fadagoraY↓ When the eye sees the eye, [or when eye meets eye in war,] then rush thou &c. (TA.) ― -b2- dagara fiY Albayoti He entered the house: (K:) as though he thrust himself in. (TA.)

Aid~agara A^dgr Adgr dgr
: see 8 in art. vgr.)

Ye two repaired the condition of the tribes of 'Abs and Dhubyán by peace, (talaAfayotumaA A^amorahumaA biAlS~uloHi,) after they had shared, one with another, in destruction, and had brayed [among themselves] the perfume of Menshim as a sign of their having leagued together against their enemy; i. e., after slaughter had come upon the last of their men, as upon the last of those who perfumed themselves with the perfume of Menshim: for [it is said that] mn$m is the name of a woman who sold perfume in Mekkeh, and a party bought of her some perfume, and leagued together to fight their enemy, making the dipping of their hands in that perfume to be a sign of their league; and they fought until they were slain to the last of them: whence the prov., A^a$oA^amu mino EiTori mano$ima: (EM p. 117:) [so that, accord. to this explanation, which is one of many, mn$m is made perfectly decl. for the sake of the rhyme:] or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) after they had manifested enmities and faults. (TA.) One says also, in cases of enmity, laA^aduq~an~a $uEuwraka, meaning (assumed tropical:) I will assuredly manifest thy circumstances. (TA.) ＝ -A3- duq~a, inf. n. daq~N and diq~N, He was seized with the malady termed diq~ [i. e. hectic fever]. (MA.)

(TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (assumed tropical:) [He made a minute examination. ― -b3- And He spoke, or expressed himself, and] he proved a question, or a problem, in a subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure, manner. (El-Munáwee, TA.) ― -b4- See also 4.

(TK:) it signifies an act between two. (TA.) [And dAq~hu fiY AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) He was minute, &c., with him in the affair, or case.] AlmudaAq~apu fiY AlA^amori signifies Alt~adaAq~u↓; (S;) which is an instance of tafaAEulN from Ald~iq~apu: (Sgh, K:) you say, tadaAq~aA↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) They were minute, &c., each with the other. (TK.) You say also, dAq~ Aln~aZara fiY muEaAmalaAtihi wanafaqaAtihi [He examined minutely into his dealings and his expenses]. (TA in art. dnq.) ― -b2- And [hence] mudaAq~apN, metonymically, signifies (tropical:) The being niggardly, stingy, or avaricious. (Az, TA in art. dnq.)

(TA.) ― -b2- Also Seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food, (IDrd, M, K,) bruised, or brayed, (M,) and what are mixed therewith; (IDrd;) such as are termed qazoH, and the like: all such seeds of the cooking-pot are called duq~ap by the people of Mekkeh: (IDrd, Sgh:) and salt with such seeds mixed therewith: (M, K:) this is the application now commonly obtaining: (TA:) or salt alone: (M:) or salt bruised, or brayed: (Lth, K:) whence the saying, maA lahu duq~apN He has not salt. (Lth, M, K. *) ― -b3- And [hence,] (tropical:) Beauty, or prettiness: (M, K, TA:) whence the phrase AimoraA^apN laA duq~apa lahaA, (M,) or qaliylapu Ald~uq~api, (K,) or maA lahaA duq~apN, (TA,) (tropical:) A woman who is not beautiful, or pretty; (M, K; *) who has not beauty, or prettiness. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A certain ornament (HaloYN) of the people of Mekkeh. (K.) ― -b5- And The small, or young, (Ha$ow,) of camels. (TA.)

inf. n. of the intrans. verb daq~a [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) [As a simple subst.,] The state, or condition, or quality, of that which is termed diq~N [and daqiyqN; properly and tropically: i. e., it signifies slenderness, &c.]: and smallness, littleness, or the like; [properly and tropically;] contr. of EiZamN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Littleness in estimation, paltriness, inconsiderableness, meanness, vileness, or contemptibleness. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And (assumed tropical:) Subtileness, niceness, abstruseness, reconditeness, or obscureness.]

(K.) ― -b2- See also madoquwqN [with which it is sometimes syn.]: ― -b3- and see daqiyqN.

diqaAqN dqAq dqyq

A certain medicine (JK, M, K) for the eye, (JK, K,) bruised, brayed, or pounded, (JK, M, K,) and then sprinkled (JK, M) therein. (JK.)

daqiyqN dqyq
contr. of galiyZN (JK, * S, M, * Msb, K) and jaliylN; (Msb;) as also duqaAqN↓ and diq~N↓; (S, K;) the last contr. of jil~N: (JK, S, M:) [i. e. Slender, or small in diameter or circumference as compared with length: also small in all dimensions; small in size; minute, or fine, either as a whole, or in its component particles: and sometimes, as applied to a garment or the like, thin, or fine, as opposed to thick or coarse; like raqiyqN: but properly,] daqiyqN differs from raqiyqN; the former signifying the contr. of galiyZN [as stated above], and the latter, the contr. of vaxiynN: therefore one says HasFA raqiyqN and HasFA vaxiynN [“ thin soup ” and “ thick soup ”], but not HasFA daqiyqN; and one says sayofN daqiyqu AlmaDoribi [a sword thin in the edge, or in the part next the point]; and rumoHN daqiyqN [a slender spear]; and guSonN daqiyqN [a slender branch]; and HabolN daqiyqN [a slender rope]: (IB, TA:) pl. [of mult. diqaAqN and of pauc.] A^adiq~apN. (Msb.) One says, walaA jil~N maA lahu diq~N↓ [He has neither slender, or small, or fine, nor thick, or great, or coarse]; i. e. daqiyqN walaA jaliylN. (S in art. jl.) And A^axa*otu wajil~ahu diq~ahu↓ [I took the slender, &c., thereof, and the thick, &c., thereof]; like as one says, Ax*t qaliylahu wa kaviyrahu. (S in the present art.) And it is said in a trad., wajil~ahu Aall~`hum~a A@gofiroliY *anobiY kul~ahu diq~ahu↓ [O God, forgive me all my sin, the small thereof and the great thereof]. (TA.) $ajarN diq~N↓ means Shrubs, bushes, or small trees: (M:) opposed to $ajarN jil~N. (Lth in art. jl, and Mgh in art. bql.) Accord. to AHn, diq~N↓ signifies Plants that are slender and soft to the camels, so that the weak of the camels, and the young, and such as has its teeth worn down to the sockets, and the sick, eat them: or, as some say, their small leaves: (M:) or slender and long leaves of the A^araAk: and grain trodden out but not winnowed: pl. A^adoqaAqN. (JK.) And Hulalu diq~K↓ means Thin, or fine, [garments, or dresses, of the kind called] Hulal; opposed to Hulalu jil~K: (Mgh:) or diq~N↓ signifies the contr. of jil~N as applied to carpets, and to the garments called A^akosiyap [pl. of kisaA='] and the like, and to the [cloth called] Hilos, and to the mat and the like. (TA in art. jal.) ― -b2- [Hence,] daqiyqN is also applied to a thing, an affair, or a case, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Little in estimation, paltry, inconsiderable, mean, vile, or contemptible; in this case, contr. of jaliylN: (IB, TA:) and means also (tropical:) niggardly, stingy, or avaricious; (M, TA;) in whom is little, or no, good; (M, K, TA;) applied to a man: (M:) pl. [of pauc.] A^adiq~apN and [of mult.] diqaAqN and A^adiq~aA='u. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a thing, an affair, or a case, (assumed tropical:) Subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure: (M, K, TA:) [applied likewise to speech; and so diq~N↓:] you say, jaA='a bikalaAmK diq~K and daqiyqK (tropical:) [He uttered subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure, speech]. (TA.) ― -b4- [The fem.] dqyqp↓ [used as a subst.] signifies (tropical:) Small cattle; i. e. sheep or goats; opposed to jaliylapN (JK, K, TA) which signifies camels: (JK, TA:) pl. daqaAy^iqu. (TA.) You say, maA lahu daqiyqapN walaA jaliylapN (tropical:) He has neither sheep, or goats, nor camels: (TA:) or neither a sheep, or goat, nor a she-camel. (M.) And kamo daqiyqatuka (tropical:) How many are thy sheep, or goats? (TA.) And huwa raAEiY Ald~aqaAy^iqi (tropical:) He is the pastor of sheep, or goats. (TA.) And A^aEoTaAhu mino daqaAy^iqi AlmaAli (tropical:) [He gave him of the small cattle]. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, [i. e. daqiyqapN↓,] as a conventional term of the astronomer, (assumed tropical:) [A minute of a circle;] the sixtieth [in the O, and in some copies, app. most, of the K, erroneously, “ thirtieth, ” as remarked by MF and SM and others,] part of a darajap [or degree of a circle: pl. daqaAy^iqu, as above]. (K, TA.) ― -b6- ↓ [And (assumed tropical:) A minute of time; the fourth part of a darajap (or degree) of time: pl. as above. ― -b7- daqiyqapN↓ is also sing. of daqaAy^iqu as syn. with madaAq~N, q. v.] ＝ -A2- daqiyqN signifies also Flour, or meal, (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) of wheat &c.; (Msb;)
[thus used as a subst.; as though] in the sense of madoquwqN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, Farina,] You say, jaraY Ald~aqiyqu fiY Als~unobuli [The farina pervaded the ears of wheat]. (L in art. qmH.) And Hamala Ald~aqiyqa [It bore farina] is said of seed-produce [or corn]. (TA in art. Hnq. [See 4 in that art.])

daqaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. daqaEN, (Msb,) He (a man, S) clave to the dust, or earth, (S, Msb, K,) by reason of abasement, or abjectness; (S, Msb;) or, as some say, by reason of poverty: or he clave to the dust, or earth, and became poor; as also AdqE↓: or he clave to the dust, or earth, or some other thing, by reason of anything whatever: (TA:) and he became lowly, humble, or submissive, and clave to the dust, or earth. (S, TA.) It is said in a trad. [cited voce xajila], A_i*aA juEotun~a daqiEotun~a When ye [women] are hungry, ye become lowly, humble, or submissive, and cleave to the dust, or earth; (S, TA;) or ye bear poverty ill. (TA in art. xjl.) ― -b2- He was, or became, grieved, unhappy, or disquieted in mind; as also daqaEa, inf. n. daqoEN and duquwEN; and lowly, humble, submissive, or abased. (TA.) ― -b3- He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, in seeking, or requesting, an object of want, and desired it vehemently. (TA.) ― -b4- He was, or became, content with mean sustenance. (K; but only the inf. n., namely daqaEa, of the verb in this sense, is there mentioned.) ― -b5- [And, as shown above,] He bore poverty ill. (S, K; but only the inf. n., as above, is mentioned in them.) [Thus the verb bears two contr. meanings.] El-Kumeyt says,
walamo yadoqaEuwA Einoda maA naAbahumo
liSarofi zamaAnK walamo yaxojaluwA
i. e. They did not bear poverty ill [on the occasion of what befell them by reason of a changing of fortune], nor did they bear richness ill: or, as some say, they did not cleave to the ground in consequence of poverty and hunger, &c., nor did they become lazy, or indolent, and remiss, in seeking subsistence. (TA.) ― -b6- He (a young camel) turned away with disgust from the milk; was averse from it; loathed, or nauseated, it; syn. ba$ima Eani All~abani. (K.) ― -b7- daqaEa, inf. n. daqoEN, [mentioned
above,] also signifies He pursued small means of gain; as also AdqE↓. (TA.)
