A camel that throws forth his fore legs, and scrapes the dust, or earth, (K, TA,) when he goes the pace, or at the rate, or in the manner, termed xabab. (TA.)

daAqiEN dAqE
: see daqiEN. ― -b2- Content with what is mean, or vile; as also midoqaAEN↓: and both signify one who cares not for whatever has fallen into food or beverage or any other thing: or, as some say, who pursues mean, or vile, things: (TA:) or the former signifies one who seeks, or pursues, small means of gain. (S, TA.)

dawoqaEapN dwqEh dwqEp
Poverty: and abasement, or abjectness: (S, K:) and calamity. (TA.) You say, in imprecating, ramaAhu A@ll~`hu biAld~awoqaEapi [May God afflict him with poverty: &c.]: (S:) or rmAh All~`h fiY Ald~awoqaEapi [may God cast him into poverty: &c.]. (TA.)

dayoquwEN dyqwE
: see A^adoqaEu.

A^adoqaEu *
Vehement hunger; (ISh, K;) as also dayoquwEN↓. (S, K.) ― -b2- *urapN daqoEaA='u [fem. of A^adoqaEu] Bad [millet]: (IDrd, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd.) ― -b3- A^aroDN daqoEaA='u Land having in it no plants, or herbage. (K.) ― -b4- Ald~aqoEaA='u↓, [used as a subst.,] (Lh, S, Msb, K,) and Ald~iqoEimu↓, (Lh, S, K,) in which the m is augmentative, as it is in dirodimN syn. with darodaA='u, (S,) and AlA^adoqaEu, and Ald~aqaAEu↓, and Ald~aqaAEu↓, (Lh, K,) The dust, or earth: (Lh, S, Msb, K:) or the fine dust or earth upon the face of the ground. (TA.) One says, in imprecating, bifiyhi Ald~aqaEaA='u, and Ald~iqoEimu, and AlA^adoqaEu, May the dust, or earth, be in his mouth. (Lh.)

mudoqiEN mdqE
: see daqiEN. ― -b2- Fleeing: hastening, or going quickly. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- Lean, or emaciated, in the utmost degree. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- Causing to cleave to the dust, or earth: (S, K:) applied in this sense to poverty. (S.)

mudaq~aEN mdqE
: see mudaf~aEN.

midoqaAEN mdqAE
: see daAqiEN. ― -b2- Vehemently, or excessively, desirous; eager; or covetous: (K:) pl. madaAqiyEu. (TA.) ― -b3- A_ibilN madaAqiyEu Camels that eat the herbage until they make it to cleave to the ground by reason of its paucity. (S.)

4 Adql Aln~axolu Adql Alnxl
, (inf. n. A_idoqaAlN, TA,) The palmtrees produced dates such as are termed daqal: (S, Msb, K:) or the dates of the palm-trees became daqal. (Es-Sarakustee, Msb.) ― -b2- Adqlt Al$~aApu The sheep, or goat, was, or became, lean, or emaciated, and small in body; despised and little in the eyes of beholders. (K.)

daqolN dql
Weakness of the body (IAar, K) of a man. (IAar, TA.)

daqalN dql
[A certain kind of palm-trees;] i. q. xiSaAbN [not as meaning “ palm-trees having much fruit, ” but as an appellation applied by the people of El-Bahreyn to the palm-trees which others call daqalN: see art. xSb]: (S, O, TA:) in the K, AlxiDaAbu is erroneously put for AlxiSaAbu: (TA:) n. un. with p: (S:) Az says that daqalN signifies species (A^alowaAnN, of which the sing. is lawonN, [but here meaning varieties,]) of palm-trees; and the dates thereof are bad, though the daqalap may be abundant in fruit; and some have red dates, and some have black; the body of the dates being small, and the stones being large: (TA:) accord. to AHn, the term daqalN is applied to any palmtrees [of which the varieties are] unknown: the n. un. daqalapN is syn. with xaSobapN, of which the pl. is xiSaAbN: and what are termed A^adoqaAlN [pl. of daqalN] are the worst of palm-trees, and their dates are the worst of dates. (O, TA.) ― -b2- Also [The fruit of the trees thus called; described above;] the worst of dates: (JK, S, Msb, K:) or a bad kind of dates: (Mgh:) or dates of which the kinds are unknown: (M, K:) accord. to EsSarakustee, the fruit of the dawom: n. un. with p. (Msb.) A rájiz says,
lawo kunotumu tamorFA lakunotumu daqalaA
A^awo kunotumu maA='F lakunotumu w $alaA
[If ye were dates, ye would be dates of the worst kind; and if ye were water, ye would be such as distils scantily, in interrupted drops, from a mountain or rock]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The mast (sahom) of a ship; (S, K;) from the same word in the first of the senses explained above; (S;) in Pers., tiyri ki$otiY, (MA, PS,) and sutuwno; (MA;) i. e., (or so daqalapN [the n. un.], JK,) the tall piece of wood of a ship, (JK, T, M, Mgh,) fixed in the midst thereof, (JK, T, M,) for the sail, (JK,) i. e., upon which the sail is extended, (T,) or [rather] to which the sail is suspended; (Mgh;) as also dawoqalN↓. (K.)

daqalapN dql dqlh dqlp
n. un. of daqalN [which see throughout]. (T, S, &c.) ― -b2- $aApN daqalapN and daqilapN↓ and daqiylapN↓ and mudoqilN↓ A sheep, or goat, lean, or emaciated, and small in body; despised and little in the eyes of beholders: pl., of any but the last, diqaAlN: (K:) or, as ISd thinks, the pl., of daqiylapN is daqaAy^ilu, unless it be formed by the rejection of the augmentative letter [in the sing.]. (TA.)

daqilapN dql dqlh dqlp
: see the next preceding paragraph.

daqiylapN dqylh dqylp
: see the next preceding paragraph.

dawoqalN dwql
: see daqalN, last sentence.

mudoqilN mdql
: see daqalapN.

1 dak~a dk
, aor.
daku3a
, (S,) inf. n. dak~N, (S, K,) He broke, or crushed, in any manner; or bruised, brayed, or pounded; i. e., beat with a thing so as to break or crush; i. q. daq~a. (S, K.) He threw down, pulled to pieces, or demolished. (K.) He broke a wall, and a mountain. (Lth, TA.) He beat a thing and broke it so as to lay it even with the ground. (S.) Hence the saying in the Kur [lxix. 14], faduk~ataA dak~apF waAHidapF, (S,) i. e. And they shall be beaten together with one beating, and the whole shall become fine dust: or they shall both be spread with one spreading, so as to become an even ground. (Bd.) [For] dak~a AlA^aroDa, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) means He made even the elevations and depressions of the earth, or ground. (K, TA.) A^a*aA duk~ati AlA^aroDu dak~FA, in the Kur [lxxxix. 22], means When the earth shall be made level, without hills, (Ibn-'Arafeh, Bd,) and without mountains: or it means, shall become fine dust scattered: (Bd:) or shall be shaken so that every building thereon shall be demolished and non-existent. (Jel.) See also dak~N below. ― -b2- dak~N also signifies The spreading (kabos [for which kanos is erroneously put in the CK]) of earth, and making it even. (K.) When a roof, or flat house-top, has been spread with earth (kubiasa biAlt~uraAbi), one says, duk~a Alt~uraAbu Ealayohi [Earth was spread upon it]: and dak~a Alt~uraAba EalaY Almay~iti, inf. n. dak~N, means He poured earth upon the corpse. (AZ, AHn.) ― -b3- Also The filling up a well (K, TA) with earth; and so dakodakapN↓. (TA.) You say, dakakotu Alr~akiY~a I filled up the wells with earth: (S:) and Alr~akiY~a dakodaka↓ He filled up the wells with earth. (TA.) ― -b4- And dak~ahu signifies also He pushed him, or thrust him; like Sak~ahu and lak~ahu. (As, TA.) ― -b5- [Hence,] dak~a jaAriyatahu (tropical:) He (a man) distressed his young woman, or female slave, by throwing his weight upon her when
desiring to compress her. (AA, TA. [See also rak~a.]) And dak~a Ald~aAb~apa biAls~ayori (tropical:) He distressed, or jaded, or fatigued, the beast by journeying. (TA.) And duk~a Alr~ajulu, (S, K,) i. e. dak~atohu AlHum~aY, (AZ, S,) or dak~ahu AlmaraDu, (K,) meaning (tropical:) Fever, or disease, weakened the man: (TA:) or he became sick, or ill. (K.) ― -b6- And dak~N also signifies The sending forth camels all together. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.)

2 dk~khu dkk dkkh dkkp dkp
He mixed it; namely, colocynth with dates or some other thing. (O, L, K.) You say, dak~ikuwA lanaA Mix ye for us. (L, O.) [See mudak~akN.]

6 tdAk~ Ealayohi Alqawomu tdAk Elyh Alqwm
The people pressed, or crowded, upon him. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Alee, vum~a tadaAkakotumo EalaY~a tadaAkuka AlA_ibili Alhiymi EalaY HiyaADihaA, i. e. Then ye pressed [upon me like the pressing of thirsty camels upon their wateringtroughs]. (TA.) And one says, tadaAk~ato Ealayohimu Alxayolu The horses, or horsemen, pressed upon them. (TA.)

7 Andk~ A^ndY A^ndk Andk nAd nd ndA ndY ndy {ndk
It (a place) became levelled, its elevations and depressions being made even. (K.) ― -b2- It (a camel's hump) became spread upon the animal's sides, (TA,) or upon his back. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b3- It (sand) became compact. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 dakodaka dkdk
, inf. n. dakodakapN: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- One says of the stallion-camel when he covers, yudakodiku Aln~aAqapa [app. meaning He distresses the she-camel by his weight: see dak~a AljaAriyatahu, above]. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

R. Q. 2 tadakodakavi AljibaAlu tdkdkv AljbAl
The mountains became dak~aAwaAt, i. e. hills of mould or clay. (S.)

dak~N dk
An even, or a level, place; (K;) [and so A^adak~u↓, as is shown by an explanation of its fem. in this paragraph:] or land, or ground, broken, and made even: (S:) you say A^aroDN dak~N: (Akh, S:) pl. dukuwkN. (S, K.) Hence, in the Kur [vii. 139 and xviii. 98], jaEalahu dak~FA, (Akh, S, TA,) i. e. [He made it, in the former instance, and shall make it, in the latter instance,] even, or level, (AZ, Az, Ibn-'Arafeh,) without any hill: (Ibn- 'Arafeh: [this addition relating to the former instance:]) or crumbled: (Ksh, * Bd:) or, accord. to Akh, dak~FA may be here an inf. n.; as though the meaning were dak~ahu dak~FA↓: [see 1:] or it may be elliptical, meaning jaEalahu *aA dak~K: another reading is jaEalahu dak~aA='a↓, (S,) meaning in the former instance a hill rising from the ground like the dak~apa: (Ksh:) or meaning jaEalahu A^aroDFA dak~aA='a, (S,) i. e. He made it even, or level, ground; (Ksh, Bd;) because the word jabal [to which dk~A=' virtually relates] is masc. (S.) ― -b2- Also, [as a subst.,] Even, or level, sand; and so dak~apN↓: pl. [of either, agreeably with analogy,] dikaAkN. (K.) ― -b3- And A [mound, or hill, of dust or earth, such as is called] tal~: (K:) or the like of a tal~: (L:) in some of the copies of the K, Altk~ is erroneously put for Alt~l. (TA.)

duk~N dk
A low mountain: (S, K:) or an elevated, or overlooking, hill of mould, or clay, in which is somewhat of ruggedness: (As, TA:) pl. dikakapN; (As, S, K;) and dikakN [app. another, though irregular, pl. of the same,] is said to signify qiyraAn [i. e. small isolated mountains, or knolls of mountains, &c., (see qaArapN,)] breaking, or crumbling, down: or disintegrated [hills, or mountains, such as are called] hiDaAb. (TA.) ― -b2- [See also A^adak~u, of which it is a pl.] ＝ -A2- Also Strong and bulky. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

dak~apN dk dkh dkp
A certain thing, (S,) [i. e.] an elevated place, (Msb,) a flat-topped structure, (K,) upon which one sits; (S, Msb, K;) i. q. masoTabapN [a kind of wide bench, of stone or brick &c., generally built against a wall]: (Msb:) pronounced by the vulgar dik~apN↓ [and commonly applied by them to a long seat of wood]: (TA:) and duk~aAnN↓ signifies the same; (S, Msb, K;) but accord. to some, this belongs to art. dkn [q. v.]: (S, Msb, TA:) the pl. of the former is dikakN, like as the pl. of qaSoEapN is qiSaEN: (Msb:) and the pl. of duk~aAnN↓ is dakaAkiynu. (TA.) [For another modern application, see maHofilN.] ― -b2- See also dak~N.

dik~apN dk dkh dkp
: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- [It is also vulgarly used for tik~apN, q. v.]

dakakN dk dkk dkp
The state of having no hump, or no prominence of the hump, in a camel. (K.) [See A^adak~u.]

dukukN dk dkk dkp
[a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] She-camels having their humps broken, bruised, or crushed. (TA.)

dukakapN dkk dkkh dkkp dkp
A thing [meaning food] made of habiyd [i. e. colocynths, or colocynth-seeds,] and flour, when flour is scarce. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) [See also mud~akakN.]

dakiykN dkyk
, applied to a year, (S, TA,) and a month, (TA,) and a day, (K,) Complete. (S, K.)

dak~aA='u dkA='
, fem. of A^adak~u [q. v.], used as a subst., (TA,) A hill of mould or clay, (As, S, M, K,) not rugged, (As, M, K,) nor amounting to a mountain: (TA:) or the pl. signifies natural [mounds, or hills, of dust or earth, such as are called] tilaAl: (TA:) the pl. is dak~aAwaAtN, (As, S, M, K,) because it is used as a subst.: (TA:) or it has no sing.: (K:) ISd says, this is what the lexicologists say; but in my opinion the sing. is dak~aA='u. (TA.)

duk~aAnN dkAn
: see dak~apN, in two places: and see also art. dkn.

dakodakN dkdk
and dikodikN: see what next follows.

dakodaAkN dkdAk
(As, S, K) and dakodakN↓ and dikodikN↓ (K) Sand that is compact, and cleaving to the ground, (As, S, K,) not elevated, (S,) or not much elevated: (As, TA:) or sand containing dust or earth, compacted together: (AHn, TA:) or sand pressed, and even, or level: or land in which is ruggedness: (K:) or a low, or depressed, and even, or level, tract of land: (TA:) n. un. of the first [and app. of each of the others] with p: (ISh, T in art. rbw:) pl. dakaAdiyku and dakaAdiku. (S, K.)

A^adak~u *
, and its fem. dak~aA='u: see dak~N. You say also A^akamapN dak~aA='u, meaning A hill wide [and app. flat, or nearly so,] in its top: (TA:) or an expanded hill: (Msb:) pl. dak~aAwaAtN, which is extr. in this case, because dk~A=' is here an epithet. (TA.) And duk~N, [its regular pl.,] applied to sands, Even and compact. (AHn, M in art. *lf.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A horse contracted [in make] and broad in the back; (S;) or a horse broad in the back, (Ks, A 'Obeyd, Mgh, K, TA,) and short (Ks, A 'Obeyd, Mgh, TA) therein; (TA;) of the sort called baraA*iyn; (A 'Obeyd, TA:) pl. duk~N. (S, Mgh, K.) ― -b3- And the fem. signifies A she-camel having no hump: (S, K:) or whose hump is not prominent, (K, TA,) but spreading upon her sides: (TA:) pl. duk~N and dak~aAwaAtN, (S,) said in the S to be like HumorN and HamoraAwaAtN, but one does not say HamoraAwaAtN, like as one does not say A^aHomaruwna: (IB:) and in like manner the masc. is applied to a he-camel: (K:) or dak~aA='u [in the sense here explained] has no masc., and therefore it is allowable to say dak~aAwaAtN. (IB.)

midakN md mdk
(tropical:) A strong man, that treads the ground vehemently: (S, TA:) or strong to work; (K;) and the fem., with p, is applied in this latter sense to a female slave. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Also a dial. var. [now vulgarly used] of mitak~N [q. v.]. (TA.)

HanoZalN madak~akN HnZl mdkk
Colocynth eaten with dates or other things. (K.) [See also dukakapN.]

madokuwkN mdkwk
[Broken, crushed, or bruised, &c.: see its verb, 1]. ― -b2- A^aroDN madokuwkapN Land having no A^asonaAd [or elevations (in the CK, erroneously, AisonaAd)], producing [the shrub called] rimov. (AHn, K.) ― -b3- madokuwkN applied to a horse, Having no prominence of his Hajabap [or crest of the hip or haunch]; (K;) and so madoluwkN. (K in art. dlk.) ― -b4- Applied to a man, Weakened by fever, (S, * TA,) or by disease: or sick, or ill. (TA.) ― -b5- See also what follows.

A^aroDN mudakodakapN *
i. q. madoEuwkapN, (K, TA,) meaning Land in which are many people, and pastors of camels or cattle, so that it is marred thereby, and abounds with the traces and urine of the cattle, and they dislike it, except when it collects them after a cloud [has rained upon it] and they cannot avoid it; as also madokuwkapN↓. (TA.)

superEntry.head: Quasi dkr
superEntry.entry:
dikorN dkr
and dukorN: see *ikorN.

1 dakana AlmataAEa dkn AlmtAE
, (Msb, K,) aor.
dakuna
, (K,) inf. n. dakonN; (TA;) and dk~nhu↓; (K;) He put the goods, household-goods, or furniture and utensils, one upon another. (Msb, K, TA.) [In the TA, this is said to be tropical: if so, it seems that the proper signification is, He made the goods,
&c., like a duk~aAn, or bench upon which one sits: see 2.] ＝ -A2- , dakina, aor.
dakana
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. dakanN, (S, Msb,) It (a thing, TA, or a garment, S, or a horse, Msb) was, or became, of a blackish colour; of a colour inclining to blackness: (S, K:) or of a colour inclining to that of dust; [or brown; i. e.] of a colour between redness and blackness: (Msb, TA:) and Aid~akana↓ [originally Aidotakana] signifies the same as dkn [app. dakina]. (TA.) And dakina said of a garment, It became dirty and dust-coloured. (TA.)

2 dk~n Ald~uk~aAna dkn AldkAn
He made [or constructed] the duk~aAn. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

8 A_idotakana
see 1.

dakonN A^dkn dkn
and dakanN: see what next follows.

dukonapN A^dkn dknh dknp
(S, K) and dakonnN↓ and dakanN↓ [which last is the inf. n. of dakina] (TA) A blackish colour; a colour inclining to blackness: (S, K:) or a colour inclining to that of dust; [or brownness; i. e.] a colour between redness and blackness. (TA.)

dukayonaA='u dkynA='
[dim. of dakonaA='u fem. of A^adokanu] A certain small reptile (duw~ayob~apN), of such as are termed A^aHonaA$. (K.)

duk~aAnN dkAn
A shop; [generally a small chamber, with an open front, along which extends a wide bench of stone or brick;] syn. HaAnuwtN: (S, Msb, K:) and a dik~ap [or kind of wide bench, of stone or brick &c., generally built against a wall], (Msb, TA,) upon which one sits, (Msb,) [i. e.] constructed for the purpose of sitting upon it: (TA:) and the like of which is built against a leaning palm-tree, to support it: (As, AHát, Msb:) if used as syn. with HaAnuwtN, it is masc. and fem.: (Msb:) En-Näwawee affirms it to be masc.: (TA:) accord. to some, (Msb,) a Persian word, [originally dukaAno,] (S,) arabicized; (S, Msb, K;) and if so, the n is a radical letter: (MF, TA:) IKtt and several others say that the n is a radical, and that the word is derived from the verb first mentioned above: but Es-Sarakustee says that the n is augmentative accord. to Sb, and in like manner says Akh; and that the word is from the phrase A^akamapN dk~aA='u meaning “ an expanded hill: ” (Msb:) the pl. is dakaAkiynu. (S, K.)

A^adokanu *
A thing, (S, TA,) [or a garment, (see 1,)] or a horse, (Msb,) of a blackish colour; of a colour inclining to blackness: (S, K:) or of a colour inclining to that of dust; [or brown; i. e.] of a colour between redness and blackness: (Msb, TA:) and a garment dirty and dust-coloured: (TA:) fem. dakonaA='u; (Msb, TA;) applied also to a serpent: pl. dukonN, applied also to clouds. (TA.) In the following verse, Lebeed applies it as meaning A wine-skin that has become in good condition in respect of its colour and odour by reason of its oldness; (S;) or a blackish, or black, wine-skin: (EM p. 169:)
A^ugoliY Als~ibaA='a bikul~i A^adokana EaAtiqK
A^awo jawonapK qudiHato wafuD~a xitaAmuhaA
(S, EM:) i. e. I buy wine at a high price, together with every blackish, or black, old, wineskin, or wine-jar smeared with pitch, from which one has ladled out, the sealed clay upon its mouth having been broken. (EM.) ― -b2- variydapN dakonaA='u [A mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth] having a large quantity of seeds with which it is seasoned: (K:) [app. because of its colour: but SM says,] as though the said seeds were put one upon another on it. (TA.)

1 dal~a dl
, aor. yadul~u, He, or it, directed; directed aright; guided; or caused to take, or follow, a right way or course or direction. (IAar, T.) And dul~a He (a man) was directed, directed aright, guided, &c. (IAar, T.) You say, dal~ahu Ealayohi, (S, M, K,) aor. as above, (S, M,) inf. n. dal~N, (M,) or duluwlapN, (S, K,) and dilaAlapN, (S, M, K,) [but this is afterwards said in the M to be a simple subst., as it is also in the Msb, and so is duluwlapN in the M,] and dalaAlapN, (S, K,) which is of higher authority than dilaAlapN, (S,) and dulaAlapN, (K,) and [perhaps] dal~iylaY, [which see below, voce dilaAlapN,] (K,) or this is a simple subst., (M,) He directed him, or rightly directed him, or guided him, to it; (S, * M, K;) namely, the way, (S,) or a thing: (M:) or he showed him it; namely, the way. (TA.) And dal~ahu AlT~ariyqa [He directed him to the way; or showed him the way]. (TA.) And dal~a Al$~aYo'a, and A_ilayohi [or Ealayohi], aor. as above, inf. n. duluwlapN, [He indicated the thing, by a word &c.,] said of a man; as also Adl~↓ [i. e. Adl~ Al$~aYo'a, &c.]. (Msb.) You say also, of a word, yadul~u EalaY ka*aA [It denotes, or signifies, such a thing]. (The lexicons passim.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to Sh, you say, dalilotu bih`*aA AlT~ariyqi, [aor. A^adal~u,] inf. n. dalaAlapN, i. e. I knew this way; and dalalotu bihi, aor. A^adil~u, inf. n. dalaAlapN: accord. to AZ, you say, biAlT~ariyqi Aid~alalotu↓, inf. n. Aid~ilaAlN, [I was, or became, directed, or rightly directed, or guided, in the way:] and [Az says,] I heard an Arab of the desert say to another, EalaY A^amaA tanodal~u↓ AlT~ariyqi [meaning Wilt thou not be directed, or rightly directed, to the way?]: (T:) [for] Andl~↓ signifies he was, or became, directed, or rightly directed, (M, K, TA,) to the way: (TA:) and IAar cites as an ex., (T,)
maA laka yaA A^aHomaqu laAtanodal~u
wakayofa yanodal~u A@moruw^N Eivowal~u
[What aileth thee, O stupid, that thou wilt not be rightly directed? but how shall the dull and slack be rightly directed?]. (T, M, TA: but in the M, yA fulaAnu; and in the TA, yA A^aEowaru.) And sometimes Astdl~↓ is quasi-pass. of dal~ahu AlT~ariyqa [explained above: see 10 below]. taHomilu AlA^aEobaA='a mino Eahodi A_iramo

daluka
, (Msb,) inf. n. duluwkN, (S, Mgh, &c.,) (tropical:) The sun set; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.;) accord. to Z, because he who looks at it rubs (yadoluku) his eyes, so that it is as though it were the rubber; (TA;) and in like manner, Aln~ujuwmu the stars: (Msb:) or became yellow, (K, TA,) and inclined to setting: (TA:) or declined (K, * TA) so that the beholder almost required, when looking at it, to contract the rays from his eyes with the palm of his hand: (TA:) or declined after midday: (Ibn-'Omar, TA:) or it signifies (or signifies also, Msb) the sun declined from the meridian, or midheaven, (I'Ab, Fr, Zj, Az, S, * Mgh, * Msb, K, &c.,) at noon; (I'Ab, Fr, Zj, Az;) and in like manner, Aln~ujuwmu the stars. (Msb.) Az says that, in his opinion, the words of the Kur [xvii. 80] A^aqima A@lS~alaApa liduluwki Al$~amosi (TA) mean Perform thou prayer from the declining of the sun at noon: so that the command expressed by these words with what follows them includes the five prayers: (Mgh, * TA:) for by the dlwk are included the first prayer [of noon] and that of the EaSor; and by the gasaq of night, the two prayers [of sunset and nightfall] of which each is called Ei$aA='; and by the quroA=n of the fajor, the prayer of daybreak: if you make the dlwk to be the setting, the command is restricted to three prayers: in the language of the Arabs, duluwkN is said to be syn. with zawaAlN; and therefore the sun is said to be daAlikapN when it is declining at noon and when it is setting. (TA.) [Respecting the phrase dalakato baraAHi or biraAHi, accord. to different readings, occurring at the end of a verse, see baraAHi, and see also raAHapN in art. rwH.] It is said in [one of the works entitled] the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb, ” that dalakati Al$~amosu signifies The sun became high; like damakat and Ealat and AiEotalat. (TA.)

, (Mgh, K, [in the CK, dal~AhA is erroneously put for dalaAhaA,]) [and dalaA biAld~alowi,] first pers. dalawotu Ald~alowa, (T, S, Msb,) and dalawotu biAld~alowi, (Msb,) aor., first pers., A^adoluw, inf. n. dalowN; (T;) and Ald~alowa AdlY↓; (Mgh; [the only authority that I find for the latter verb in the sense here explained;]) He pulled the dalow [or bucket] up, or out, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) from the well, (T, Mgh,) full: (T, Mgh:) or he pulled the dlw to make it come forth. (K.) Hence, i. e. from AdlY Aldlw as explained above, the saying, in a trad., if it be correct, Eani AlmaA='a waraduwA maA='K fasaA^aluwA A^aholahu A^ano yudoluwhumo↓ [They came to water, and they asked its owners to draw for them from the water]; for yudoluwA lahumo, or yudoluwA dalowahumo. (Mgh.) And A^adoluw HaAjatiY, from dalawotu Ald~alowa explained above, means (assumed tropical:) I seek, or demand, the accomplishment of my want: (Ham p. 500:) or dalaA HaAjatahu means (assumed tropical:) He sought, or demanded, the object of his want. (TA.) And dalawotu bifulaAnK A_ilayoka, (S, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) I begged, or beg, such a one to make intercession for me to thee. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] dalaA (assumed tropical:) He drove, or urged on: (IAar, T:) or did so gently; for dalowN [the inf. n.] means the driving, or urging on, gently. (M.) You say, dalawotu Aln~aAqapa, (S, K,) aor. A^adoluw, (TA,) inf. n. dalowN, (S, TA,) (tropical:) I made the she-camel to go gently, or leisurely. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- And dalawotuhu and daAlayotuhu↓ (tropical:) I was gentle with him; namely, a man; (S, K, TA;) treated him with gentleness or blandishment, soothed him, coaxed him, or wheedled him; (S, TA; and K in art. dlY [in which, as is said in the TK, daAwayotuhu is erroneously put, in some copies, for daArayotuhu];) endeavoured to conciliate him. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 4, in three places.

And dal~aAhu mino saToHK biHabolK He let him, or it, down from a house-top by means of a rope. (Mgh.) And dl~Y rijolayohi mina Als~ariyri [He hung down his legs from the couch]; and AdlY↓ occurs in the same sense. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., dul~iYa EalaY~a jiraAbN mino $aHomK mino baEoDi HuSuwni xayobara, meaning [A bag, or provision-bag, of fat] was let down, or let fall, upon me [from one of the forts of Kheyber]. (Mgh.) See also 4. ― -b2- And dl~Y Al$~aYo'a He made, or brought, or drew, the thing near to another thing (mino gayorihi); like Ald~alowi A_idolaA='u↓. (Har p. 173.) ― -b3- dal~aAhu biguruwrK (assumed tropical:) He caused him to fall into that which he desired [to bring about] by exposing him to perdition, or destruction, or loss, without his knowledge; from Ald~alowi A_idolaA='u↓. (S.) [In the Kur vii. 21,] fadal~aAhumaA biguruwrK means (assumed tropical:) And he caused them to fall (fdl~AhmA) into disobedience by deceiving, or beguiling, them: so says Aboo-Is-hák [Zj]: or (assumed tropical:) he excited their cupidity [with deceit, or guile]; originating from the case of a thirsty man's being let down (yudal~aY) into a well in order that he may satisfy his thirst from its water, and his not finding water in it, so that he is let down into it with deceit, or guile: or it means he emboldened them to eat of the tree with deceit, or guile; originally dal~alahumaA. , [in the CK, erroneously, dalayotu,] and dalawotu↓ (K;) or A^adolayotu Ald~alowa, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_idolaA='N; (T, Msb;) and Ald~alowa dalawotu↓, [and app. biAld~alowi,] aor. A^adoluw, [inf. n. dalowN;] (T, * Msb;) I let down the dalow [or bucket] (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) into the well, (T, S, Mgh, K,) to fill it, (T,) or to draw water with it. (M, Msb.) A^adoli dalowaka fiY Ald~ilaA='i [Let down thy bucket with the other buckets] is a prov. used in urging [a person] to strive, or labour, for gain; (TA;) originating from a company's assembling at a well, and letting down their buckets in order that every one of them may take his share of the water, or what is easily procurable by him thereof: meaning, use means to acquire, like as do others. (Har p. 167.) See also 2, in four places. ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) AdlY biHuj~atihi (tropical:) He adduced his plea, or the like, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) correctly, or validly; (T;) or he defended himself by adducing it or urging it: (S:) or he established his plea, or the like, and so obtained his claim or demand or suit. (Msb.) And in like manner you say, AdlY biHaq~ihi (tropical:) [He urged, or established, his right or due]. (TA.) ― -b3- And AdlY bimaAlihi (tropical:) He gave, (dafaEa, M, K, TA,) or presented, or offered, (rafaEa, S, TA,) his property, (S, M, K, TA,) A_ilayohi [to him], (M,) or AlY AlHaAkima [to the judge]. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [ii. 184], watudoluwA bihaA A_ilaY, AlHuk~aAmi, (S, K,) i. e. (tropical:) And [do not] give it, or offer it, as a bribe to the judges: (S, * TA:) or and do not endeavour to conciliate with it the judges in order that they may cut off for you what is the right of others: (T:) or and do not throw it to the judges to be decided by them, (Mgh, Bd, Jel,) or as a bribe. (Jel.) And in a letter of 'Omar, faA@fohamo A_i*aA A^udoliYa A_ilayoka And understand thou
when an application is made to thee by litigants for the decision of a cause. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And AdlY biraHimihi (tropical:) He sought to bring himself near, to approach, or to gain access, [A_ilaY gayorihi to another,] by means of his relationship: (S, K, TA:) and he pleaded, or made intercession, thereby. (TA.) bihi A_ilayoka waqado dalawonaA↓, in a prayer for rain, of 'Omar, referring to El-' Abbás, i. e., accord. to the “ Ghareebeyn, ” (assumed tropical:) And we have sought to approach, or to gain access, to Thee by him, app. means that they sought to obtain the mercy and aid of God [by means of his intercession], like as one seeks to get at, or obtain, the water by means of the dalow [or bucket]. (M.) One says also, A^adolaY A_ilaY Almay~ati biAlbunuw~api wanaHowihaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) He was united to the dead by sonship, and the like; from A_idolaA='u Ald~alowi. (Msb.) And fulaAnN yudoliY A_ilaY Almay~iti bi*akirK (assumed tropical:) Such a one is united with the dead by a male. (Mgh.) ― -b5- AdlY fiyhi means (tropical:) He said of him what was evil, or foul. (M, K.) ― -b6- And AdlY said of a horse &c., He put forth his yard, for the purpose of staling or covering; (M, K;) as also dl~Y↓ said of an ass, as is also the former verb. (M.) ― -b7- See also 1, first and second sentences.

It was let down or lowered; it hung down, or dangled; it was let down; (T, * M, Mgh;) into, and over, a pit or the like; (M;) it hung (K) from (mino) a tree; (S, K) it hung down as a fruit [from a tree]. (Bd in liii. 8.) [Hence,] tdl~Y EalayonaA mino A^aroDi ka*aA [He, or it, came down, or descended, upon us from such a land]. (TA.) And tdl~Y biAl$~ar~i He descended upon one with evil, or mischief. Accord. to Fr, vum~a danaA fatadal~aY [in the Kur liii. 8] means vam~a tadal~aY fadanaA, (T,) i. e. Then he (Gabriel) hung down from the highest region of the sky, and so drew near to the Apostle: showing that he took him up without becoming separated from his place: or the meaning of the phrase, as it stands, is, then he drew near to the Prophet, and he clung to him: (Bd:) but accord. to Zj, it means then he drew near, and drew nearer; and is like the phrase danaA fulaAnN min~iY waqaruba. (T. [See also another explanation in what follows.]) ― -b3- And He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; or he lowered, humbled, or abased, himself. A_i*aA tadal~ato bihi A^awo $aAribN vamilN

daAliyapN dAl dAlyh dAlyp
A [water-wheel, or machine for irrigating land, such as is called] manojanuwn, (S, M, K,) that is turned by an ox or a cow: (S:) and [such as is called] a naAEuwrap: (K:) or the nAEwrp is turned by water: (S:) and a thing made of palm-leaves (M, K) and pieces of wood, with which water is drawn [for irrigating land] by means of ropes, or cords, (M,) [app. held and drawn at one end by a man, and at the other end] tied to a tall palm-trunk: (M, K:) it is a bucket (dalow), and the like, with pieces of wood made in the form of a cross, [i. e. with two pieces of wood placed across and so tied together,] the two arms of which are bound to the top [or rim] of the bucket; them one end of a rope is tied to it, and the other end to a palm-trunk standing at the head of the well; and one irrigates [land] with it [app. by drawing and swinging it up by means of another, or of the same, rope]: the word is of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN [because it is pulled up]: the pl. is dawaAlK: El-Fárábee deviates from others, by explaining it as meaning a manojanuwn; and J follows him: (Msb:) [a similar apparatus for irrigating land is used in the northern parts of Egypt, called qaTowap and dalow↓: it consists of a bowl-shaped bucket, with four cords attached to its rim: two men, each holding two of the cords, throw up the water by means of it into a trough or trench: accord. to Mtr,] the daAliyap is a tall palm-trunk set in the manner of the machine with which rice is beaten [to remove the husks], having at its head a large bowl, with which water is drawn [for irrigating land]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also Land that is irrigated by means of the dalow [or bucket] or the [machine called] manojanuwn [mentioned above]. Black grapes, but not intensely black, (AHn, M, K,) the bunches of which are the largest of all bunches, appearing like goats hung [upon the vines]: the berries thereof are coarse, breaking in the mouth, and round; and are dried. (AHn, M.) [See also dawaAliY~u, in art. dwAl.) ― -b5- [The sing. also signifies A grape-vine itself: and a shoot of a grape-vine: pl. as above.]

, (TK,) inf. n. damonN, (TA,) i. q. damalahaA; (S, K;) i. e. He put the land into a right or proper state, prepared it, or improved it, [or manured it,] with [damaAn, i. e. dung such as is termed] siroqiyn. (TA.) ＝ -A2- damina, (S, M, K,) aor.
damana
, (K,) inf. n. damanN, (KL,) (tropical:) He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (S, M, K, TA,) of long continuance, (M, K, TA,) Ealayohi against him: (S, M, TA:) and daminato quluwbuhumN (tropical:) Their hearts bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (S, TA,) of long continuance. (TA.) [Perhaps from daminati Aln~axolapu said in the TK to signify The palm-tree became rotten and black: see damaAnN, below.] ― -b2- The inf. n. damanN also signifies The being lasting, continual, or permanent. (KL.) [And Andmn↓ app. signifies It was, or became, of long continuance: see a usage of its part. n. munodaminN voce dimonapN.]

2 dam~anati AlmaA$iyapu AlmakaAnu *
, (M, K,) inf. n. tadomiynN, (K,) The cattle dunged (M, K *) and staled (M) in, or upon, the place. (M, K.) And dm~n Al$~aA='u AlmaA='a The sheep, or goats, dunged in the water.
(S, TA.) ― -b2- dm~n Alqawomu Ald~aAra, (S,) or AlmawoDiEa, (M,) The people, or party, blackened [by the dung of their cattle, or by their cooking,] (S, M,) the house, or abode, (S,) or the place. (M.) ― -b3- dm~n fulaAnN finaA='a fulaAnK, (T,) or baAbahu, (K,) (tropical:) Such a one came, and kept, or clave, to the court, or yard, of such a one, (T, TA, *) or [simply] kept, or clave, to his door. (K. [Freytag assigns this signification (which he renders “ semper stetit ad alicujus portam ”) to A^adomana followed by an accus. case, as on the authority of the K.]) ＝ -A2- And dm~nhu, (Kr, M, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He granted him, or conceded to him, indulgence, or facilitation. (Kr, M, K.)

4 Admnhu A^dAm A^dmn A^dmnh Admnh Admnp dmn
, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_idomaAnN, (Msb,) He did it continually, or perpetually: (S, K:) he kept, or clave, to it (T, M, Msb, TA) without desisting from it, or without quitting it, (M,) constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, (Msb,) or inseparably; (TA;) namely, drinking, (T,) and wine, (T, M,) &c. (M.)

5 tdm~n A^dAm A^dmn dAm dmn tdmn tdmnn
app. signifies It (water, or a place,) had dung of sheep or goats, or of camels, fallen into it, or upon it: see its part. n. mutadam~anN, below.]

[
7 A_inodamana
see 1, last sentence.]

damonN dAm dmn dmnn dmnp
: see damaAnN.

dimonN dAm dmn dmnn dmnp
[Dung, such as is called] siroqiyn, (T, M, K,) or sirojiyn, (Msb,) that has become compacted, (T, M, Msb, K,) and formed a cake upon the ground: (T:) and camels', sheep's, goats', or similar, dung; syn. baEorN: (S, M, K:) also, (T,) or dimonapN↓, of which the former word is the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.], (TA,) [dung of the kind called] baEor, and mud, or clay, that have become mixed together, at a watering-trough or tank, (T, TA,) and compacted, or caked: (T:) and remains of water in a watering-trough or tank. (TA.) See also dimonapN, in three places. ― -b2- fulaAnN dimonu maAlK is a phrase like A_izaA='u maAlK, (S, TA,) and means (assumed tropical:) Such a one is a manager, or tender, of cattle, or camels &c., (K, TA,) who keeps to them inseparably. (TA.)

dimNnapN dmn dmnh dmnnh dmnp
: see the next preceding paragraph. Also A trace, (M,) or traces, (K,) of a house or an abode: (M, K: *) and the traces of men [in a place where they have sojourned]; and a place which they have blackened; (S, M, Msb, K, TA;) where they have left marks of the dung of cattle; a patch of ground which the people who have occupied it have blackened, and where their cattle have staled and dunged: (TA:) [a black, or dark, patch of compacted dung and urine of cattle:] a place near to a house or an abode: (M, K:) a place in which [dung such as is called] siroqiyn has become compacted, or caked: (M, TA:) and a piece of zibol [i. e. srqyn]: (TA:) pl. dimanN (S, M, K) and dimonN↓, (M, Msb, K,) or [rather] the latter is a [coll.] gen. n.: (M:) [accord. to Az,] dimonN↓ signifies what men have blackened [where they have sojourned, consisting] of the traces of baEor &c.; and is a gen. n., and also pl. of dimonapN. (T.) It is said in a trad., A_iy~aAkumo waxaDoraA='a Ald~imani, meaning (assumed tropical:) Avoid ye the beautiful woman that is of bad origin: she is thus likened to the herbage that grows in the diman; that appears to be in a flourishing condition, but is unwholesome as food, and of stinking origin. (M. [See also A^axoDaru: and see Eu$obapu Ald~aAri, in art. E$b.]) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (T, S, M, Msb, K, TA,) of long continuance (munodaminN↓ M, or qadiymN K, and vaAbitN TA) in the bosom: it is said that it is not thus termed unless of long continuance: (M, TA:) pl. dimanN (T, K) and [coll. gen. n.] dimonN↓. (Msb, K.)

damaAnN dmAn
[Dung such as is called] sirojiyn (M) or siroqiyn (K, TA) with which land is manured; (TA;) [as also damaAlN and dabaAlN.] ― -b2- And Ashes. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (As, Sh, T, S, M, IAth, K,) or dumaAnN↓, with damm, like other words significant of diseases and the like, as in the “ Ghareeb ” of El-Khattábee, or, accord. to the “ Towsheeh, ” both of these, and dimaAnN↓, (TA,) and damonN↓, (M, K,) and A^adamaAnN↓, (Ibn-Abi-z-Zinád, T, IKtt, K,) Rottenness and blackness of a palm-tree: (M, K:) or the state of a palm-tree A_i*aA A^anosagato, as As says, (T, S, [and the like is said in the M, A^ano tunosiga Aln~axolapu,]) but Sh says, correctly, A_i*aA A@no$aq~ato [when it splits], (T,) in consequence of rottenness and blackness: (T, S, M:) or, accord. to IAth, corruptness and rottenness of fruits (Alvmr [perhaps a mistranscription for Alt~amor i. e. dates]) before their coming to maturity; as also damaAlN: (TA:) or damaAnN and damaAlN both signify an unsoundness, or infection, in the spadix of the palm-tree, (Mgh and TA in art. dml,) so that it becomes black, (TA ib.,) before it attains to maturity, (Mgh and TA ib.,) or before it is fecundated. (TA ib.) ＝ -A3- Also damaAnN, (M, K,) or in this sense it is correctly dam~aAnN↓, (TA,) One who manures land with [the dung called] siroqiyn. (M, K, * TA.) ＝ -A4- [Golius adds the signification of “ Tormentum, supplicium, ” as from the KL, in my copy of which the only explanation given is EfwntY kh bh drxt xrmA rsd “ a rottenness that infects a palm-tree: ” he seems to have found in his copy of that work EqwbtY, either alone, or followed by some words imperfectly written.]

dumaAnN dmAn
and dimaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

dam~aAnN dmAn
: see damaAnN.

dam~uwnN dmwn
Bad, foul, or unseemly. (K.)

dum~ayonaY dmy dmynY dmyny
The [hole called] dam~aA=' of a jerboa: (K:) because of its continuance therein. (TA.)

A^adomaAnN *
A certain tree of the [kind called] janobap. (K. [Golius read mina Aljan~api i. e. “ of Paradise, ” for mn Aljanobapi.]) ＝ -A2- Also, accord. to the K, A certain canker, disease, or bane, of palm-trees: but this is A^adamaAnN↓. (TA.)

A^adamaAnN *
: see what next precedes, and damaAnN. h*A mdmnhm [thus in the TA: app. either madominuhumo, and if so meaning This is their place of continuance, or mudam~anuhumo, meaning the place where their cattle dung and stale].

rajulN mudominu xamorK rjl mdmn xmr
, (S,) or mudominu Alxamori, (T,) A man who is a continual drinker of wine; (S;) an incessant drinker of wine: (T, TA:) likened in a trad. to an idolater. (TA.)

mutadam~anN mtdmn
A place in which, or upon which, cattle have dunged and staled. (K, * TA.) And water into which the dung of sheep or goats, or of camels, has fallen. (S.)

munodaminN mndmn
: see dimonapN, last sentence.

superEntry.head: (dmw or dmY)
superEntry.entry:
1 damiYa dm dmY dmy dmyp
, (T, S, M, MA, Msb, K,) [held by some to be originally damiwa,] like raDiYa, (S, K,) which is from Alr~iDowaAnu, being thus [with Y] because of the kesreh, (S,) [but most hold the last radical to be Y,] and damaY, (TA as from the Msb, [but not in my copy of the latter work,]) aor. yadomaY, inf. n. damFA or damFY (T, S, M, MA, Msb, K) and dumiY~N, (S, MA, [but in the Msb it seems to be indicated that it is damaYN,]) said of a thing, (S,) or of a wound, (Msb,) and damiyato said of the arm or hand, (T,) It bled; blood issued from it: (Msb:) [and] it was, or became, bloody; i. e., smeared, or defiled, with blood. (MA.)

2 dam~ayotuhu dmY dmy dmyp dmyth dmytp
, (S, M, K,) inf. n. tadomiyapN, (S,) i. q. A^adomayotuhu↓, (S, M, K,) i. e. [I made him to bleed;] I struck him, or smote him, so that blood issued from him: (S:) [and I made him bloody; for] dam~aAhu signifies [also] he smeared him, or defiled him, or made him to be smeared or defiled, with blood. (MA.) Hence the prov., wuloduki mano dam~aY Eaqabayoki, (M, TA,) Thy son is he who made thy two heels to be smeared with blood; (TA in art. wld;) i. e., whom thou thyself broughtest forth; (K and TA in that art.;) he is thy son really; not he whom thou hast taken from another, and adopted. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- dm~Y AlmaA$iyapa (assumed tropical:) It (pasture, or herbage,) fattened the cattle so as to make them like what are termed dumFY [pl. of dumoyapN]. (M.) ― -b3- dam~ayotu lahu, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) I made a way easy to him. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) I made, or brought, [a thing] near to him. (K.) You say, dam~aY lahu fiY ka*aA wa ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He made, or brought, near to him [some object of desire in such and such cases]. (Th, M.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) I appeared to him. (K.) One says, xu*o maA dam~aY laka (assumed tropical:) Take thou what has oppeared to thee. (Th, M.)

4 A^a1o2a3a
see 2.

10 AstdmY AstdmY Astdmy
He (a man) stooped his head, blood dropping from it; (M;) as also AisotadaAma, formed by transposition from AstdmY. (Kr, TA in art. dwm.) ＝ -A2- AstdmY gariymahu (assumed tropical:) He acted gently with his debtor; as also AisotadaAmahu: (Fr, M and K in art. dwm:) judged [by ISd] to be formed by transposition from the latter. (M in that art.) ― -b2-
AstdmY mawad~atahu He looked, or watched, or waited, for his love, or affection: [formed by transposition] from AisotadaAma. (M in art. dwm.)

damN dm
[Blood;] one of the [four] A^axolaAT [or humours], (M,) well known: (T, M, K:) accord. to some, (Msb,) it is originally damawN: (S, Msb:) or it is originally damFY; (Zj, Mbr, S, M, Msb, K;) thus in the correct copies of the K; (TA; [in some copies damoYN, and in the CK damaYN;]) though deviating from other words of the same form in respect of its pl. [which see below]; (Mbr, S;) as is shown by its dual, (Zj, M,) which is damayaAni, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) whereby [also] the letter gone from it is shown to be Y; (Mbr, S;) but it has also for its dual damaAni; (T, M, Msb, K;) and some of the Arabs say damawaAni; (S, M;) in which last, however, [accord. to ISd,] the w is substituted for Y, though generally w is changed into Y: (M:) and this original form is used by a poet, [namely, Hoseyn Ibn-El-Homám, accord. to one of my copies of the S,] in his saying,
falasonaA EalaY AlA^aEoqaAbi tadomaY kuluwmunaA
wal`kino EalaY A^aqodaAminaA yaqoTuru Ald~amaY↓
[And we have not our wounds bleeding upon the heels; but upon our feet the blood drops]: (S:) or it is originally damoYN; (Sb, T, S, M, Msb;) as is shown by its pls., (Sb, S,) which are dimaA='u (Sb, T, S, M, K) and dumiY~N, (Sb, S, M, K,) also pronounced dimiY~N; (TA;) like as ZaboYN and dalowN have for their pls. ZibaA='u and ZubiY~N and dilaA='N and duliY~N; for if it were like qafFA and EaSFA, it would not have such pls. (Sb, S.) dam~N is ignored by Ks; but is used by poetic license; (M;) or it is a dial. var. of damN. (K in art. dm.) damapN↓ has a more special signification than damN, the two words being like bayaADapN and bayaADN; (S;) [i. e.] it signifies A portion of blood: (T, M, K:) or it is a dial. var. of damN, (M, K,) accord. to IJ. (M.) The dim. of damN is dumaY~N↓. (S.) [Hence,] rajulN *uw damK A man seeking to obtain, or prosecuting for, [the revenge of] blood. (TA.) damu fulaAnK fiY vawobi fulaAnK is a saying of the Arabs, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is the slayer of such a one. (Ham p. 632.) Ald~amu Ald~amu waAlhadomu Alhadomu, or waAlhadama Alhadama, is a saying of the Arabs, meaning If thy blood be sought, my blood shall be sought; and if thy blood go for nought, my blood shall go for nought: or, accord. to the latter reading, as is said in the Nh, and where thou shalt be buried, I will be buried: or thine abode shall be mine abode. (JM in art. hdm, q. v.) See also an ex. voce dumoyapN. ― -b2- damu AlA^axawayoni [The red, resinous, inspissated juice called dragon's blood;] what is called AlEanodamu; (S;) i. q. damu AlgazaAli; (K voce maZ~N;) now called AlqaATiru Alamik~Y~u; or a species thereof; (TA;) [vulgarly qaTor mak~ap; and also called damu Alv~uEobaAni;] what is called in Pers. xuwn siyaAwu$aAn (K.) ― -b3- damu AlgizolaAni A certain herb, or leguminous plant, having a beautiful blossom: (M, K:) accord. to Lth, AlgizolaAni dumoyapu↓ is the name of a certain herb, or leguminous plant, having a blossom. (T.) ― -b4- banaAtu damK A certain plant, (M, K,) well known; (K;) a certain red plant. (T in art. bnY.) ＝ -A2- Ald~amu The cat: (M, K:) mentioned by En-Nadr in “ The Book of Wild Animals. ” (M.)

damapN dm dmh dmp
: see the next preceding paragraph.

Ald~amaY AldmY Aldmy dmyp
, said to be the original form of Ald~amu: see damN.

damK dm
Bleeding; having blood issuing from it: (S, * Msb:) [and] bloody; i. e. smeared, or defiled, with blood: and daAmK↓ signifies the same [in both senses]. (MA.)

dumoyapN dmy dmyh dmyp
An image, or effigy, (S, M, Mgh, K,) of ivory and the like, (S,) or of marble, (M, K,) variegated, decorated, embellished, or coloured, (M, Mgh, K,) in which is redness like blood: (Mgh:) or an image, or effigy, in a general sense: (Kr, M, K:) accord. to Abu-I-'Alà, because originally painted with red, as though from Ald~amu: and any beautiful female is likened thereto, because adorned: (TA:) metonymically applied to (tropical:) a woman: (IAar, T:) or anything that is deemed beautiful in respect of whiteness: (TA:) and an idol: (Lth, S, K:) said in the R to be so called because of the shedding of blood at the place thereof for the purpose of propitiation; but MF says that this derivation requires consideration: more probably because it is decorated: (TA:) pl. dumFY. (S, Mgh, K.) Accord. to MF, it is also pronounced dimoyapN↓. (TA.) One says, A^aHosanu mina Ald~umoyapi, meaning More beautiful than the image of ivory. (Har p. 611.) And laAwa Ald~umaY is an oath of the Pagan Arabs, meaning No, by the idols: or, as some relate, it is laA wa Ald~imaA='i↓ meaning No, by the blood of what is sacrificed upon the stones set up to be worshipped: so in the Nh. (TA.) ― -b2- The pl., dumFY, also signifies Garments upon which are pictures or effigies. (S.) ― -b3- See also damN, last sentence but two.

dimoyapN dmy dmyh dmyp
: see the next preceding paragraph.

damoyaA='u dmyA='
, as in the Tekmileh; in the K, erroneously, daAmiyaA='↓, (TA,) Good, or good fortune, and prosperity. (K, * TA.)

damiY~N dm dmY dmy dmyp
[Of, or relating to, blood;] rel. n. from damN; as also damawiY~N↓. (S.) ― -b2- [In the phrase x* mA dm~Y, in Freytag's Lex., dmY~ is a mistake for dam~aY: see 2, last sentence.]

dumaY~N dm dmY dmy dmyp
dim. of damN, q. v. (S.)

damawiY~N dmwY dmwy
: see damiY~N.

Ald~amawiy~apu Aldmwyh Aldmwyp dmwy
, meaning Hectic fever (Hum~aY Ald~iq~i) is a vulgar word of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.)

daAmK dAm dAmy
: see damK. [And see the next paragraph.] ― -b2- daAmiY Al$~afapi, (M, K,) applied to a man, (M,) [lit. Having a bleeding lip,] means (tropical:) poor. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- $ajarapN daAmiyapN (assumed tropical:) A beautiful tree. (TA.)

daAmiyapN dAmy dAmyh dAmyp
, (S, K,) or $aj~apN daAmiyapN, (T, * M, * Msb,) A wound in the head that bleeds but does not flow with blood (T, S, M, Msb, K) as yet: (M:) such as flows with blood is termed daAmiEapN. (T, Msb.) [See $aj~apN.]

daAmiyaA=' dAmyA='
: see damoyaA='a.

mudam~FY mdmY mdmy mdmyy
Red; applied to a garment, or piece of cloth: (M:) or anything in the colour of which is blackness and redness: (T:) [of a dark red colour, like blood:] or anything intensely red: (S:) applied in this last sense [particularly] to a horse &c.: (S, K:) or, applied to a horse, of a sorrel colour (A^a$oqaru) intensely red, like the colour of blood: (T:) or, so applied, of an intense sorrel colour: (M:) and kumayotN mudam~FY of an intensely red bay colour: (S, TA:) or of an intense red colour like that of blood: (TA:) or intensely red in the back [and] as far as the thin and soft parts of the belly: and A^a$oqaru mudam~FY of which the sorrel colour is overspread, in its upper portion, with a yellowness like the colour of the yellow [or gilded] bay: (A 'Obeyd, T:) and lawonN mudam~FY a colour in which is blackness. (M.) sahomN mudam~FY An arrow upon which is the redness of blood (S, K) that has adhered to it so that it inclines to blackness: a man, when he shot at the enemy with an arrow, and hit, and the enemy then shot it at him with blood upon it, used to put it in his quiver, auguring good from it: or, as some say, it means an arrow which the archers shoot by turns, one at another; an explanation reducible to that before mentioned: (S:) or an arrow which one shoots at his enemy and the latter then shoots at the former: (M:) or an arrow shot once. (T.)

musotadomK mstdm
Having blood dropping from the nose, while stooping the head. (As, S, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) One who draws forth his debt from his debtor with gentleness. (As, S, K.)

1 dan~a dAn dn dnn
: see R. Q. 1, in four places. ＝ -A2- [danina is mentioned by Golius and Freytag (by the former as from the S) as though it were the verb of which dananN (q. v.) is the inf. n.; but I find no authority for it: and if dananN have a verb, it should, accord. to rule, be dan~a, aor. yadan~u.]

2 dan~a3a
see R. Q. 1.

4 Adn~ A^dAn A^dn A^dnY A^dnn Adn dAn dnA dnY dny {dnY |d
, (T, K,) inf. n. A_idonaAnN, (T, TA,) He (a man, T, TA) remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (T, K, TA,) [as though set in the ground like a dan~,] baAlmakaAni in the place; like A^aban~a: (T, TA:) on the authority of Aboo-Turáb, (T,) or Ibn-ElFaraj. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 danodana dndn dndnn
It buzzed, or made a buzzing sound; syn. Saw~ata, and Tan~a, (K,) and TanoTana; (Sh, T, TA;) as also dan~a↓, and dn~n↓; said of the fly, (K,) [and of the bee, and of the hornet, and the like; for] danodanapN [inf. n. of danodana] (Lth, T, M, K) and daniynN [inf. n. of dan~a↓] (Lth, T, M) and dinodinN↓ [a simple subst.] (M) signify
the buzzing (Sawot, Lth, T, M, K) of the fly, (M, K,) or the bee, (Lth, T,) and the hornet, (Lth, T, M, K,) and the like. (M.) ― -b2- And [hence,] He (a man) spoke in a low, gentle, or soft, tone, so that his speech was not understood; (A'Obeyd, K, TA;) [as also dan~a↓; for] danodanapN [inf. n. of the former] (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and daniynN [inf. n. of dan~a↓] and dinodinN↓ (M, K) signify the speaking in a low, gentle, or soft, tone, (A'Obeyd, T, S,) or in the manner termed hayonamapN, (M, K,) so that the speech is not understood: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M:) or danodanapN signifies [merely] the speaking in a low, or faint, tone: (M:) accord. to IAth, it is a little above what is termed hayonamapN. (TA.) A poet says,
nudanodinu mavola danodanapi Al*~ubaAbi
[We buzz in our speech like the buzzing of the fly]. (Sh, T.) And it is said in a trad., HawolahaA nudanodinu, (S,) or HawolahumaA, (M, JM, TA,) which is thus explained: the Prophet asked an Arab of the desert, “ What dost thou say in the ta$ah~ud? ” [see this word, which means the repetition of a form of words at the close of the ordinary prayers:] and he answered, “ I ask of God Paradise, and seek protection of Him from the fire [of Hell]: but as to thy danodanap and the danodanap of Mo'ádh, I do not approve it: ” and the Prophet said, HawolahumaA nudanodinu; (M, JM; *) i. e. [We speak with a low, or faint, voice] about those two things, namely, the seeking Paradise and the praying for protection from the fire [of Hell]; and on account of them: (JM:) accord. to some, it is from danodana Hawola AlmaA='i He went round about the water: [hence it may mean we utter our prayer respecting them with a low, or faint, sound, as though we were buzzing round about them like flies; seeking to enter the one, and to keep outside the other:] As says that it may be from the signification of the sound [of buzzing], or from that of going round about: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, the Prophet said, EanohumaA nudanodinu [From a consideration of them we utter our prayer with a low, or faint, voice;] i. e. our danodanapu arises from them; and is because of them: and hence, (JM,) danodana means also He (a man, JM) went to and fro in one place. (JM, TA.)

dan~N dAn dn dnn
A wine-jar: (MA:) a [jar of the kind called] Hub~: (S:) or [a jar] in form like a Hub~: (Msb:) or a large raAquwd [or earthen jar, smeared inside with pitch, long in the lower part], (M, K,) in form like the Hub~, (M,) but taller; (M; in the K, or taller than the Hub~;) uniform in make, [tapering to the bottom,] having at the lower end what resembles the qawonas [or tapering top] of a helmet: (M:) or smaller than the Hub~, having a pointed lower extremity, [so I render EusoEusN, (agreeably with the TK,) regarding it as a dial. var., or perhaps a mistranscription, of EuSoEuSN, which properly signifies the “ os coccygis, ”] (M, K,) so that (M) it will not sit [upright] without one's digging a hole for it: (M, K:) IDrd says that it is a genuine Arabic word: (M:) pl. [of mult.] dinaAnN (T, S, M, Msb) [and dinanapN and (of pauc.) A^adonunN and A^adun~N, as appears from the following saying of IAar, quoted by Az:] one says dan~N and A^adonunN and A^adun~N and dinaAnN and dinanapN. (T.) (M.) And in another trad., A_i*aA A^akalotumo fasam~uwA A@ll~`ha wadan~uwA, i. e. [When ye eat, pronounce the name of God, and] eat of that which is near you: (M:) or A_i*aA A^akalotumo fadan~uwA, i. e. [When ye eat,] eat of that which is next you. huwa A@bonu Eam~ dinoYK *
and dinoyFA and dinoyaA and dunoyaA↓ mean [He is a son of a paternal uncle] closely related; syn. laH~FA [q. v.]: when you pronounce the d with damm, you do not make the word perfectly decl.: when you pronounce it with kesr, you make it either perfectly or imperfectly decl.: but when you prefix Eam~ to a determinate noun, dinoY may not be in the gen. case: for instance, you say, huwa A@bonu Eam~ihi dinoyFA, i. e. [He is the son of his paternal uncle] closely related; as also dinoyapN↓; because dinoY, being indeterminate, cannot be an epithet applied to that which is determinate: (S:) and [in like manner] you say, huwa A@bonu Eam~iY, or Abn xaAliY, or Abn Eam~atiY, or Abn xaAlatiY, or Abn A^axiY, or Abn A^uxotiY, (M, K,) all mentioned by Lh, the last two as on the authority of Aboo- Safwán, but all except the first and second as unknown to Ks and to As, (M,) followed by dinoyapN↓ and dinoyFA and dinoyaA and dunoyaA↓, (M, K, TA,) the last two without tenween, (TA; [and so written in the M; but in the CK and my MS. copy of the K, in the place of these two is put dunoyFA, which is disallowed by J;]) meaning [He is the son of my paternal uncle, and the son of my maternal uncle, &c.,] closely related: (M, K:) and huwa Eam~uhu dunNyaA↓ and dinoyapF↓ and dinoyFA and dinoyaA [He is his paternal uncle closely related]: (Ks, T:) Lh says that the w is changed into Y in dinoyapF↓ and dinNyFA because of the nearness of the kesreh and the weakness of the intervening letter, as is the case in fitoyapN and EiloyapN: but it seems that these words are originally dunoyaA↓, i. e., by a relationship, or uterine relationship, nearer to me than others; and that the change of the letter is made only to show that the Y is that of the fem. of A^adonaY. (M.) You say also, humo rahoTuhu dinoyapF↓ They are his people, and his tribe, closely related. (S and TA in art. rhT.)

Prov. ii. 357:) and he adds, “ Proverbii sensus esse videtur: Quilibet propinquus seu amicus unicus non est; sed præter eum est alius ”]: (T, Meyd:) so says AZ. daniy~ahN dny dnyh dnyp
A low, or base, quality, property, natural disposition, habit, practice, or action; syn. naqiySapN; (Mgh;) or such as is blamed; originally daniyoy^apN: (TA:) pl. danaAyaA. (Har p. 327.) A^adonaY *
Nearer, and nearest; opposed to A^aqoSaY: (TA:) fem. dunoyaA; (M, TA;) in which the [radical] w is changed into Y, as in EuloyaA and quSoyaA: (ISd, TA voce buqowaY:) [the pl. of the masc. is A^adaAnK and A^adonawona; the latter in the accus. and gen. A^adonayoni: and] the pl. of the fem., dunFY, (S, K, TA,) like kubarN pl. of kuboraY, and SugarN pl. of SugoraY; (S, TA;) said by some to be extr. and strange [in respect of usage]; and El-Mutanebbee has been blamed for using it; (MF, TA;) but in the case referred to he has used Ald~unaY for Ald~unoyaA, [not as a pl.,] suppressing the Y by poetic license. (TA.) [Hence,] gulibati Alr~uwmu fiY A^adonaY AlA^aroDi, in the Kur xxx. 1 and 2, The Greeks have been overcome in the nearer, or nearest, part of the land. (Bd, Jel.) And Aljamorapu Ald~unoyaA [The nearest heap of pebbles;] the heap of pebbles nearest to Minè. (TA. [See art. jmr.]) And
Als~amaA='u Ald~unoyaA [The nearest heaven; i. e. the lowest;] the heaven that is the nearest to us: (T, TA:) also called samaA='u Ald~unoyaA [which means the heaven of the present world; as will be seen from what follows]. (TA.) See also exs. of the fem. in the paragraph commencing with the words huwa A@bonu Eam~K dinoYK, in four places. ― -b2- Also Former, and first; and fore, and foremost; opposed to A=xirN. (TA.) [Hence,] laqiytuhu A^adonaY daniY~K↓ (S, K, TA) and A^adonaY danFA↓, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AdnY dan~Y` and AdnY daniY~K,]) i. e. I met him the first thing. (S, K.) [And A^adonaY Alfami The fore, or foremost, part of the mouth.] And Ald~unoyaA [for Ald~aAru Ald~unoyaA, and AlHayaApu Ald~unoyaA, The former dwelling, or abode, and life; i. e. the present world, and life, or state of existence]; contr. of AlA=xirapu: (M, K:) [or] it is so called because of its nearness: (T, S:) [and may be rendered the sublunary abode, &c.: and the inferior abode, &c. It also signifies The enjoyments, blessings, or good, of the present world, or life; worldly blessings or prosperity, &c.] And sometimes it is with tenween, (K, TA,) when used indeterminately: (TA:) [thus,] IAar mentions the saying maA lahu dunoyFA wa laA A=xirapN [as meaning He has none of the enjoyments, or blessings, of the present world, nor in prospect any enjoyments, or blessings, of the world to come]; with tenween. (M, TA.) And you say, baAEa dunoyaAhu biA=xiratihi [He purchased his enjoyments of the present world at the expense of his enjoyments of the world to come]. (Z, TA in art. byE.) And Aabonu Ald~unoyaA means The rich man. (Msb in art. bnY.) ― -b3- Also More, and most, apt, fit, or proper: thus in the Kur [xxxiii. 59], in the phrase *`lika A^adonaY A^ano yuEarafona [That will be more, or most, apt, fit, or proper, that they may be known]; (Ksh, Mgh;) i. e., that they may be known to be free women, as distinguished from female slaves, who did not cover their faces. (Jel.) ― -b4- Also Less [in number or quantity &c.], and least [therein]; opposed to A^akovaru. (TA.) walaA A^adonaY mino *`lika walaAA^akovara, in the Kur [lviii. 8], means Nor less in number than that, nor more in number. (Bd.) And walanu*iyqan~ahumo mina A@loEa*aAbi A@loA^adonaY duwna A@loEa*aAbi A@loA^akobari, in the Kur [xxxii. 21, lit. And we will assuredly make them to taste of the smaller punishment besides the greater punishment], means, accord. to Zj, whatever punishment is inflicted in the present world and the punishment of the world to come. (M.) ― -b5- Also Worse, [or inferior in quality,] and worst; or more, and most, low, ignoble, base, vile, mean, or weak; opposed to xayorN. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 58], A^atasotabodiluwna A@l~a*iY huwa A^adonaY biA@l~a*iY huwa xayorN [Will ye take in exchange that which is worse, or inferior, for that which is better? or], accord. to Zj, meaning that which is less in value [for that which is better]? AdnY being thus, without ': Fr says that it is here from Ald~anaA='apN: and Zuheyr El-Kurkubee [or (accord. to some) El-Furkubee] read A^adonaA^u. (T.)

(TA.) diho↓ in Pers. means Give thou: and metonymically, the act of striking. (TA.)

duhodur~N dhdr
a noun signifying What is false, or vain; a lie; syn. baATilN and ka*ibN: as also duhodur~ayoni, (K,) its dual, (TA,) or duho dur~ayoni, or duho dur~ayono: (as in different copies of the S:) whence duhodur~ayoni and duhodur~iy~apN↓ are epithets applied to a liar; or a great or habitual liar: and accord. to AZ, the Arabs used to say, duhodur~aAni laA yugoniyAani Eanoka $ayoy^FA [Lies will not avail thee aught]: and duhodun~N signifies the same as duhodur~N. (TA.) ― -b2- duhodur~ayoni is also a noun, (K,) i. e. a verbal noun, (TA,) signifying He was, or has become, unoccupied, or without work; syn. baTala; (K;) like saroEaAna for saruEa, and hayohaAti for baEuda. (TA.) Hence the prov., (TA,) duhodur~ayoni saEodu Alqayoni, (As, K,) without the conjunction wa [after the first word], and dhdr~yn being written as one word, (TA,) meaning Saad the blacksmith became, or has become, unoccupied, or without work; not being employed because of the people's being diverted from other things by drought (As, K) and distress. (TA.) Some say saAEdu Alqayoni: and Aboo-'Obeydeh Maamar Ibn-El-Muthennà relates it thus: dhdr~yn saEoda Alqayon, with sEd in the accus. case, and says that dhdr~yn is governed in the accus. case by a verb understood; apparently meaning that it is a noun signifying AlbaATilu, dual of duhodur~N, not a verbal noun, as though the prov. meant Cast ye away what is false, or vain, and Saad the blacksmith: but what he says is not correct. (TA.) Or a certain blacksmith asserted his name to be Saad
for some time, and then his lying became manifest; so this was said to him; meaning, Thou hast added falsehood to falsehood, O Saad the blacksmith. (K.) It is also related separately; (K;) and so J and others relate it; saying dh dr~yn: (TA:) [in one copy of the S, I find it written duho dur~ayono: in another, duho dur~ayoni:] duho being an imperative from Ald~ahaA='u; its final radical letter being transposed to the place of the medial, so that it becomes duwoho, and the w being then rejected because of the two quiescent letters, (K,) so that it becomes duho, like as is done in the case of qulo: (TA:) and dur~ayoni being from dar~a, “ it was consecutive; ” (K;) by the dual form being meant repetition, as in the case of lab~ayoka &c.: (TA:) so that the meaning is Be thou very lying (K) and cunning, (TA,) O Saad (K) the blacksmith: (TA:) and this explanation, says IB, is good, except inasmuch as that the d in dr~yn thus derived should be with fet-h; or, he adds, it may be with damm to assimilate it to the d in duho [like as Alqayoni is terminated with kesr to assimilate it to dur~ayoni]. (TA.) Or the origin of the saying was this: Saad the blacksmith was a Persian, who went about the districts of ElYemen, working for the people; and when he became without work in a district, he used to say, in Persian, diho badoruwdo: [so in a copy of the S; and this, or diho bidoruwdo, is the correct reading: in another copy of the S, daho baduwrudo: and in the copies of the K, diho badoruwdo:] (S, K:*) meaning, [O town, or village,] farewell: to acquaint them that he was going forth on the morrow: (K:) or meaning I am going forth to-morrow: (S:) in order that he might be employed: and they arabicized the expression, and made him the subject of a prov. with respect to lying; and said, When ye hear of the blacksmith's departure at night, he is assuredly coming in the morning. (S, K.) Some say that the prov. is elliptical, for baTala qawolu saEodK Alx [False is the saying of Saad &c.]. (TA.) [This is mentioned in the S in art. dr.]

It (sand) poured down, and for the most part fell. (Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, He, or it, fell down, from a higher to a lower place. (Msb.) ― -b3- And It (the night) for the most part went: (Msb:) or departed, or retreated. (K, TA.)

dahorN dhr
(T, S, M, K, &c.) and daharN↓, (M, K,) the latter either a dial. var., agreeably with the opinion of the Basrees in cases of this kind, and therefore such cases are limited by the authority of hearsay, or it is so written and pronounced because of the guttural letter, and so is accordant to a universal rule, agreeably with the opinion of the Koofees, (ISd,) Time, from the beginning of the world to its end; (Esh-Sháfi'ee, Az, Msb, Er-Rághib;) as also HiynN: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, Az:) this is the primary signification: (Er-Rághib:) and any long period of time; (Z, Mgh, K, Er-Rághib;) thus differing from zamaAnN, which will be explained below: (Er-Rághib:) and a portion of the longest period of time: (Az:) or dahorN signifies, (S, A,) or signifies also, (Az, Msb,) time; or a time; or a space, or period, of time; syn. zamaAnN, (Sh, Az, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) whether long or short: (Msb:) or this is the proper signification of zamaAnN, but not of dahorN: (Er-Rághib:) and (tropical:) a division of the year: and (tropical:) a less period: (Az, Msb:) Az says, I have heard more than one of the Arabs say, A^aqamonaA EalaY maA='i ka*aA dahorFA [We stayed at such a water a long time, or a time]; and h`*aA AlmaroEaY yakofiynaA dahorFA [This pasture-land will suffice us a long time, or a time]; but one does not say that Ald~ahoru is four times, or four seasons, because its application to (tropical:) a short period of time is tropical, and an extension of its proper signification: (Msb:) or it signifies i. q. A^abadN [meaning a long unlimited time; or an extended indivisible space of time; or duration without end; time without end]; (S, Msb;) it differs from zamaAnN in having no end: (Khálid Ibn-Yezeed:) or a prolonged, or lengthened, term; syn. A^abadN mamoduwdN: (K, in some copies of which, in the place of Abd, we find A^amad:) and (tropical:) the period, or duration, of life; an age: (Kull p. 183:) the present state of existence: (Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) a thousand years: (K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^adohurN (K) and [of mult.] duhuwrN: (S, A, K:) both said to be pls. of dahorN, and no other pls. are known as those of daharN; the form A^adohaArN not having been heard. (TA.) ― -b2- You say maDaY Ealayohi dahorN and duhuwrN [A long time and long times, or an age and ages, &c., passed over him, or it]. (A.) ― -b3- And kaAna *`lika dahora Aln~ajomi That was in the time of God's creation of the stars; meaning, in the beginning of time; in ancient time. (A.) ― -b4- [And fiY A^aw~ali Ald~ahori In the beginning of time. (A.) ― -b5- [And yaboqaY Ald~ahora It remains for ever. ― -b6- And laA A=tiyhi Ald~ahora I will not come to him, ever. See also daAhirN.] ― -b7- And SaAma Ald~ahora [He fasted ever, or always]. (TA in art. Awl, &c. [See a trad. cited voce A=la, in that art.]) ― -b8- [Hence, because, in one sense, time brings to pass events, good and evil,] Ald~ahoru was applied by the Arabs to Fortune; or fate: and they used to blame and revile it: and as the doing so was virtually blaming and reviling God, since events are really brought to pass by Him, Mohammad forbade their doing thus. (Az, Mgh, TA, &c.) It is said in a trad., laA tasub~uwA A@ld~ahora faA_in~a A@ld~ahora huwa A@ll~`hu, (S, Mgh, TA, &c.,) or, accord. to one reading, faA_in~a A@ll~`hu huwa A@ld~ahoru, (Az, Mgh, TA, &c.,) in which some explain Aldhr in the first proposition as having a different meaning from that which it has in the second, whereas others assign to it the same meaning in both cases: (TA:) the meaning of the trad. is, Revile ye not [fortune, or] the Efficient of fortune; for the Efficient of fortune is God: (Az, S, TA, &c.:) or, accord. to the second reading, for God is the Efficient of fortune. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) some reckon Ald~ahoru as one of the names of God: (K, &c.:) but some disallow this: and some say that it is allowable if meant to signify, as rendered above, the Efficient of fortune. (TA, &c.) ― -b9- zawoju dahorK A husband prepared for the accidents or calamities of fortune. (S in art. bhr. [See bahorN.]) ― -b10- dahorN also signifies An evil event or accident; a misfortune; a calamity. (K.) See also dahaAriyru. [And see 1.] ― -b11- Also A purpose; an intention: (S, K:) a desire: (TA:) the scope, or end that one has in view. (K, TA.) You say, maA dahoriY bika*aA, (S, TA,) and maA dahoriY ka*aA, (TA,) My purpose, or intention, (S, TA,) and my desire, and my scope, or the end that I have in view, (TA,) is not such a thing. (S, TA.) ― -b12- Also (tropical:) A custom, or habit, (S, K,) that is constant, or permanent, (Kull p. 183,) or that lasts throughout life. (TA.) You say, maA *aAka bidahoriY (tropical:) That is not my custom, or habit, (S,) that lasts throughout my life: (TA:) and maA dahoriY bika*aA (tropical:) My habit throughout life is not so. (TA.)

daharN dhr
: see dahorN.

dahoriY~N dhr dhrY dhry
(S, A, Msb, K) and duhoriY~N↓ (K) One who deviates from the truth, and introduces into it that which does not belong to it, syn. muloHidN; (S, A;) who asserts that the duration of the present world is from eternity, (A, Msb,) or that it is everlasting, (K,) and does not believe in the resurrection, (Msb,) or in the world to come. (TA.) ― -b2- And the latter, (S, A, Msb, K,) or the former, (IAmb,) An old, or aged, man. (IAmb, S, A, Msb, K.) Th says that both are rel. ns. from Ald~ahoru, though the latter is contr. to rule, [as is also remarked in the Msb,] like suholiY~N from AlA^aroDu Als~aholapu. (S.) ― -b3- Some say also that the latter signifies An acute, or ingenious, or expert, man. (TA.)

duhoriY~N dhr dhrY dhry
: see the next preceding paragraph.

dihoraArN dhrAr
: see dahaAriyru.

duhruwrN dhrwr
: see dahaAriyru.

dihoriyrN dhryr
: see dahaAriyru.

dahyirN dhyr
: see daAhirN.

dahaAriyru dhAryr
, a pl. without a sing.; (K, TA;) or its sing. is dahorN↓, like as the sing. of ma*aAkiyru is *akarN, and that of ma$aAbihu, $abahN; or its sing. is duhoruwrN↓, or dihoraArN↓, [in the TA written by mistake dhrAt,] or dihoriyrN↓; (TA;) Misfortunes; calamities: as in the phrase waqaEa fiY Ald~ahaAriyri He fell into misfortunes, or calamities. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also Severe, or calamitous. (S.) It is said in a trad. of Sateeh,
faA_in~a *aA Ald~ahora A^aTowaArFA dahaAriyru
[For verily this age is at times calamitous]. (TA.) dahorN dahaAriyru, A severe, or calamitous, age, is a phrase like layolapu layolaA='u, and nahaArN A^anoharu, &c.: (S:) [see also daAhirN:] and it also signifies a time of two states, adverse and prosperous: (TA:) and duhuwrN dahaAriyrN, various, or varying, times: (K:) or long times. (A.) [See daAhirN.] ― -b3- Also dahaAriyru [or rather, as IbrD says, dahoru Ald~ahaAriyri, for this has the signification immediately following,] The beginning of time past: and [absolutely] preceding, or past, time. (K, TA.) You say kaAna *`lika fiY dahori Ald~ahaAriyri [That was in the beginning of past time: or in the time of by-gone ages]. (TA.)

dahorN daAhirN dhr dAhr
(S, K) and dahorN dahiyrN↓ (K) are phrases in which the epithet has an intensive effect, [meaning A long, or an endless, period, or course, of time,] (K,) like A^abadN A^abiydN (S, TA) and A^abadN A=bidN: (TA:) or a severe, or calamitous, age. (TA.) [See also dahaAriyru.] ― -b2- laA A=tiyka dahora Ald~ahiriyna I will not come to thee, ever: (S, K:) similar to the phrase A^abada AlA=bidiyna. (TA.)

humo madohuwrN bihimN hm mdhwr bhm
, and madohuwruwna, They are afflicted with an evil event. (K.)

, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
daha$a
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. daha$N; (S, Msb;) and duhi$a, (S, A, K,) which is said to be formed by transposition from $udiha, but Az denies this, and says that duhi$a is the superior form; (TA;) He became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (S, K:) or he became bereft of his reason or intellect (Msb, K) in consequence of shame, or of fear, (Msb,) or of heedlessness, or diversion by some occupation, or of fear, or grief, or intense grief, (K,) or of fright, and the like: (TA:) and dh~$↓, inf. n. tadohiy$N, signifies the same: (K, TA:) or this last is trans., like Adh$. (TK.) ＝ -A2- daha$ahu: see 4.

see 1: ＝ -A2- and 4.

He, (God, S, TA, or a man, Msb, K,) or it, (shame, A, TA, and an affair, TA,) confounded, or perplexed, him, so that he was unable to see his right course: (S, K:) or bereft him of his reason or intellect; (Msb, K;) as also daha$ahu↓, aor.
daha$a
, inf. n. daho$N; but some disallow this; (Msb;) and dh~$hu↓. (TK.)

dahi$N *
(A, K) and madohuw$N↓ (S, A, Msb, K) and daho$aAn↓ [whether with or without tenween is not indicated] (TA) Confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (S, K:) or bereft of his reason or intellect (Msb, K) in consequence of shame, or of fear, (Msb,) or of heedlessness, or diversion by some occupation, or of fear, or grief, or intense grief, (K,) or of fright, and the like. (TA.)

[A fit of confusion, or perplexity, so that he was unable to see his right course, or a fit of alienation of mind in consequence of shame or fear, &c., befell him]. (A, TA.)

madohuw$N *

Q. 1 dahoqana dhqn
: see the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- dahoqanuwhu, (inf. n. dahoqanapN, TK,) They made him a dihoqaAn. (K.) El-'Ajjáj says,
duhoqina biAlt~aAji wabiAlt~asowiyri
[He was made a dhqAn by receiving the tAj (meaning either crown or turban) and by being decked with bracelets]. (TA.) ― -b2- dahoqana AlT~aEaAma, (A'Obeyd, TA,) inf. n. dahoqanapN, with which dahomaqapN is syn., (As, TA,) He made the food soft, or delicate: (As, A'Obeyd, TA:) because softness, or delicacy, of food is from Ald~ahoqanapu [as meaning Alt~adahoqun]. (As, TA.)

Q. 2 tadahoqana tdhqn
He was, or became, a dihoqaAn: (S, K, Mgh, TA:) or he had, or possessed, much wealth; as also dahoqana↓ [app. in both of these senses]: (Msb:) derived from dihoqaAnN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also He affected, or feigned, or made a show of, sharpness or quickness of intellect, cleverness, ingeniousness, skilfulness, knowledge, or intelligence; syn. takay~asa. (TA.)

dahoqanapN dhqnh dhqnp
[inf. n. of Q. 1: and signifying The state, or condition, of a dihoqaAn;] a subst from dihoqaAnN; (JK, K;) derived from the latter word. (Mgh.) You say, lahu dahoqanapN bimawoDiEi ka*aA [He has a state, or condition, which is that of a dihoqaAn in such a place. (S.)

dihoqaAnN dhqAn
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) also written duhoqaAnN, (JK, Msb, K,) in [some of] the copies of the S written [dihoqaAnN and dahoqaAnN,] with kesr and fet-h, [thus written in one of my copies of the S,] and said by AO [as there cited] to be like qrTAs, which is written with each of the three vowels, (TA,) an arabicized word, (S, Msb, K,) from the Pers. [diho “a town or village” and xaAno “a prince or lord”]; (TA;) if derived from tadahoqana, (Kh, Sb, S,) i. e. if the n be regarded as radical, perfectly decl. [and written as above]; (Kh, Sb, S;) but if derived from Ald~ahoqu, imperfectly decl. [and written dihoqaAnu &c.], because of the measure fElAnu; (S;) [but this statement relates especially to the measure faEolaAn, with fet-h to the f; except in the case of a proper name; and an epithet of this measure, moreover, that forms its fem. by the addition of p, as dhqAn does, is perfectly decl.; and it should be observed also, that,] accord. to IJ, dhqAn is of the measure fElAl, from tadahoqana, and there is no instance, in the language, of the measure tafaEolana; (Har p. 102;) it signifies The headman, or chief, of a village or town: (Es-Sem'ánee, Msb, TA: [agreeably with the Pers. original:]) or the proprietor thereof, in Khurásán and El-' Irák: (Es-Sem'ánee, TA:) or, as used by the Arabs, a great man of the unbelievers of the ' Ajam [or Persians]: but they disdained this appellation: (Mgh:) Lth says that it is a nickname, or name of reproach: (TA:) it became predominantly applied to such of them as was of the people of the districts of cultivated land and of villages or towns: and then to anyone possessing much land or other immoveable property: (Mgh:) [it signifies generally a dweller, or one having a fixed abode, in a district of cultivated land, or in a village or town of such a district; a rustic; a husbandman:] or it signifies a chief, headman, or person in authority, over the husbandmen, or peasants, of the 'Ajam [or Persians]: and the headman of a province: (K:) and a possessor of land or other immoveable property: (Msb:) and a merchant: (Msb, K:) and one who manages affairs firmly, or strongly, with sharpness: (K:) the fem. is with p: (JK, Mgh, K:) and the pl. is dahaAqiynu (Msb, K) and dahaAqinapN. (K.) [See a verse cited voce ja*aA in art. j*w. The same verse, but with qaroyatiY (my village or town) in the place of qaroyapK, is also cited in the TA in the present art.]

diholiyzN dhlyz
[An entrance-passage of a house; an entrance-hall; a vestibule;] what is between the [outer] door or gate and the house; (S, K;) the place of entrance to a house: (Msb:) a Persian word, (S, Msb,) originally dAlyj, and dAlyz, and dAlAn, and, as some say, daliyjN, (Lth,) arabicized: (Lth, S, Msb:) [also, in modern Arabic, an ante-
chamber: and the anterior apartment of a large tent or pavilion: accord. to the MA, a large tent: accord. to some copies of the K, i. q. jayoy^apN: accord. to some, xaniy~apN, which reading is preferred by the author of the TK, who explains dhlyz, from the “Burhán,” as meaning “absurd words:” accord. to some, Haniy~apN, which I think the right reading, meaning a bowed, or curved, structure: Golius seems to have found another reading in the K, namely, Hay~apN:] pl. dahaAliyzu. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^abonaA='u Ald~ahaAliyzi (assumed tropical:) Foundlings, (K, * TA,) whose fathers are unknown. (TA.) [They are so called because they are generally abandoned at the entrances of mosques or private houses, whence they are usually taken by persons who adopt them.]

dahama
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. dahomN, (TA,) It (an event, S, Msb) came upon them, or happened to them, suddenly, unexpectedly, without their being aware of it, or without any previous cause; surprised them; took them by surprise, or unawares: (Msb:) or dahamaka and dahamaka, aor.
dahama
, it (anything) came upon thee so as to overwhelm thee, or cover thee, or as a thing that overwhelmed thee, or covered thee. (Th, K.) And dahimatohumu Alxayolu [The horsemen came upon them suddenly, &c.]: and AO says that dahamatohum is a dial. var. thereof. (S.) See also dahomN, below.

dahomN A^dhm dhm
A malicious, or mischievous, or grievous, act, by which one takes others unawares, or by surprise. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, TA,) or duhomN↓, (JK, and so in one place in the TA,) A numerous company: (Lth, JK, TA:) or a multitude: pl.duhuwmN. (S.) A rájiz says,
jiy^onaA bidahomK yadohamu
majorK kaA^an~a fawoqahu Aln~ujuwmaA
[We came with a numerous company that would overwhelm the other numerous companies; a great army, as though the stars were above it]. (S, TA.) I know not what one of the creation, or of mankind, he is, and what one of the creatures of God he is. (K, * TA.)

duhomN A^dhm dhm
