Blackness: (JK, S, Msb, K:) and a deep ash-colour [without any tinge of white: see A^adohamu]. (ISd, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A brown ewe (naEojapN HamoraA='u): [see also dahomaA='u, voce A^adohamu:] and sing. of duhamN signifying a certain sort [or breed] of sheep or goats. (JK. [But I do not find either of these two significations in any other lexicon.])

Ald~uhayomi Aldhym
Calamity, or misfortune; (JK, S, K;) as also A^um~u Ald~uhayomi; (S, K;) and Ald~uhayomaA='u↓, (JK, S,) dim. of Ald~ahomaA='u [fem. of AlA^adohamu], so called because of its darkness: (S, TA:) or Ald~ahayomaA='u signifies black, dark, trial or conflict and faction or sedition or the like; and the dim. form is used to denote enhancement: (Sh, TA:) and Ald~ahomaA='u↓ signifies black, dark, calamity or misfortunes: (TA:) calamity, or misfortune, is termed Ald~uhayomu because of its darkness: (TA:) or, originally, (S,) this was the name of the she-camel of 'Amr Ibn-Ez-Zebbán Edh-Dhuhlee, who was slain, with his brothers, and their heads were put upon her, (S, K, TA,) in sacks hung upon her neck, and she returned to Ez-Zebbán: (TA:) whence the saying, A^avoqalu mino Himoli Ald~uhayomi [Heavier than the burden of Ed-Duheym]: (S:) and A^a$oA^amu mina Ald~uhayomi [More unlucky than Ed-Duheym]: (S, K, TA:) or, as some say, seven brothers were slain in a warring and plundering expedition, and were put upon Ed-Duheym; and hence the name became proverbial as applied to any calamity or misfortune. A^adohamu *
Black; (JK, S, * Mgh, Msb, * K;) as also duhaAmN↓: (K:) the former is applied in this sense to a horse, (S, * Mgh, Msb, * TA,) and to a camel, &c.: (TA:) or, applied to a camel, of a deep ashcolour without any tinge of white; (As, S, Msb, K;) when of a deeper hue, so as to be very black, he is termed jawonN: (S:) or, as some say, applied to a camel, like A^aSofaru, [in this case meaning black with some intermixture of yellow,] but less black: (TA:) fem. dahomaA='u; which, when applied to a sheep (S, M, Msb, K) or goat, (S, Msb,) means of a pure or an unmixed brown colour (xaAliSapu AlHumorapi): (S, M, Msb, K:) pl. duhomN. (TA.) The Arabs say, muluwku Alxayoli duhomuhaA [The kings of horses are the black thereof]. (TA.) And farasN A^adohamu bahiymN A black horse in which is no intermixture of colours. (TA.) And laA A=tiyka maA Han~ati Ald~ahomaA='u [I will not come to thee as long as she (among the camels) that is of a deep ash-colour without any tinge of white reiterates her yearning cry after her young one; meaning, ever]. (Lh, TA.) And ramaAdN A^adohamu Black ashes. (TA.) ― -b2- HadiyqapN dahomaA='u and mudohaAm~apN↓ (tropical:) [A walled garden] green inclining to black. (K.) Hence, (K,) mudohaAm~ataAni↓, (S, K,) in the Kur [lv. 64], (S, TA,) [Two gardens (jan~ataAni)] of which the greenness inclines to blackness; for every green plant, when its abundance and its moisture, or irrigation, are complete, inclines to blackness: (Zj, TA:) or black by reason of intense greenness arising from abundant moisture, or irrigation; and everything that is green (A^axoDar) the Arabs term A^asowadu. (S, TA.) ― -b3- raboEN A^adohamu [A place of alighting or abode] recently occupied by the tribe; [because blackened by their fires &c.:] pl. A^arobuEN duhomN. (TA.) And A^avarN A^adohamu A new, or recent, mark, trace, or vestige: (As, K:) and A^agoyaru means one that is “old, becoming effaced:” (As, TA:) and the former means also old, becoming effaced; (K;) as some explain it; (TA;) thus having two contr. significations. (K.) And waToA^apN dahomaA='u A new, or recent, footstep, or footprint: and gaboraA='u means “becoming effaced:” or the former means one that is becoming effaced, because it has become obscure to him who seeks it; (JK;) or an old footstep, or footprint: and HamoraA='u means one that is “new, or recent.” (S.) [See also A^agobaru.] ― -b4- Ald~ahomaA='u also signifies (tropical:) The cooking-pot: (JK, S, A, K:) or the black cooking-pot: (ISh, TA:) and the old cooking-pot. (K. [But it is implied in the TA that this last meaning is a mistake, occasioned by an omission; and that, instead of Alqidoru waAlqadiymapu, (in the CK Alqidoru Alqadiymapu,) we should read, Alqidoru waAlwaToA^apu Ald~ahomaA='u Alqadiymapu, explained above. Accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss in the KL, A^abuw AlA^adohami signifies The great cooking-pot in which a whole sheep is cooked at once.]) ― -b5- And The twenty-ninth night of the [lunar] month: (JK, K:) because of its blackness. (TA.) And
[the pl.] Ald~uhomu Three nights of the [lunar] month [during which is the change of the moon]: (K:) because they are black. (TA.) ― -b6- See also Ald~uhayomu. ― -b7- [Used as a subst.,] A^adohamu signifies also A shackle or fetter, or a pair of shackles or fetters; syn. qayodN: (S, K:) because of the blackness thereof: accord. to AA, of wood: (TA:) or a heavy shackle or fetter or a pair of shackles or fetters: syn. A^adaAhimu: (S, K:) because of the blackform of pl., which is proper to substs., because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it. (TA.) ― -b8- And [the fem.] dahomaA='u signifies (assumed tropical:) A multitude, or large number: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) a company of men; (Ks, S, K; *) and multitude thereof: (Ks, TA:) or (tropical:) the generality, the common mass, or the main part [thereof]: (Z, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the commonalty, or common people. (Mbr, Har p. 671.) [See also dahomN.] ＝ -A2- Also, dahomaA='u, The aspect, appearance, mien, guise, or garb, of a man. (JK, S, * K.) ＝ -A3- And Ald~ahomaA='u A certain herb, or tree, green, and broad in the leaves; (JK;) or a certain broad herb, (K,) having leaves and twigs, resembling the qaronuwap; (TA;) with which one tans. (JK, K.)

mudohaAm~apN mdhAmh mdhAmp
: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

mutadah~amN mtdhm
A catamite; i. q. maA^obuwnN and mivofarN and mivofaArN (AA, TA in the present art. and in art. dvr,) and mutadaA^~amN. (K, TA.)

1 dahanahu dhn dhnh dhnnh dhnp
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
dahuna
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. dahonN (MA, Msb, K, KL) and dahonapN, (K,) He anointed it (MA, Mgh, Msb, * KL) with duhon, (Mgh, Msb,) i. e., (Msb,) with oil (MA, Msb, KL) &c.; (Msb;) [oiled it; or greased it;] namely, his head, (MA, Mgh,) or his mustache, (Mgh,) or his hair, &c.: (Msb:) or he moistened it; namely, his head, &c.: (K:) and dh~nhu↓, inf. n. tadohiynN signifies the same [but app. in an intensive sense, or as applying to many objects]: (TA:) and A_idohaAnN [inf. n. of A^adohana↓] is like tadohiynN. (AHeyth, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] dahana AlA^aroDa, said of rain, (S, K,) (tropical:) It moistened the ground slightly, or a little: (S, TA:) or it moistened the surface of the ground. (K.) ― -b3- And [hence also,] dahanotuhu biAlEaSaA (S, K *) (tropical:) I struck him (S, K, TA) gently (TA) with the staff, or stick; (S, K, TA;) like as one says, masaHahu biAlEaSaA and biAls~ayofi. (TA.) And dahanotuhu biAlEaSaA dahanaAtK (tropical:) I struck him [gently] with the staff or stick [some gentle strokes: dahanaAtN being pl. of dahonapN↓, which is the inf. n. of un.]. (So in a copy of the S.) ― -b4- [Hence, likewise,] dahana signifies also He (a man, TA) played the hypocrite. (K, TA.) And you say, dahana fulaAnFA, aor.
dahuna
, inf. n. dahonN, meaning He acted with such a one hypocritically. (TK. [See also 3.]) ＝ -A2- dahunato, (K, and so in more than three copies of the S,) and dahanato, aor.
dahuna
; (K, and so in some copies of the S in lieu of dahunato;) and dahinato, aor.
dahana
; (AZ, K;) inf. n. [of the first] dahaAnapN (S, K) and [of the second or third or of both] dihaAnN; (K;) (tropical:) She (a camel) had little milk. (AZ, S, K, TA.) [See dahiynN.] ― -b2- And dahina, inf. n. dahonN, [or, as appears to be probable from what follows and from general analogy, dahanN,] said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, weak: and also, foolish, or stupid: and [app. soft, flaccid, or flabby; for] dahanN signifies the being soft, flaccid, or flabby; or softness, flaccidity, or flabbiness. (JK.) [See dahiynN.]

2 dah~ana
see 1, first sentence.

3 mudaAhanahN mdAhn mdAhnh mdAhnp
and A_idohaAnN↓ signify the same; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. (tropical:) The endeavouring to conciliate; syn. muSaAnaEapN: (S, TA:) or the making peace with another; or becoming reconciled with another: (Msb:) or the pretending the contrary of, or what is different from, that which one conceals in his mind: (K:) and the former signifies also the acting with dishonesty, or dissimulation: or ↓the latter has this signification; and the former signifies the striving to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent; syn. muwaArabapN: (TA:) or daAhanotu signifies I hid, concealed, or covered; syn. waArayotu [accord. to four copies of the S; but probably this is a mistranscription for waArabotu, meaning I strove to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent, as is indicated in the TA]; and A^adohanotu↓ signifies I acted with dishonesty, or dissimulation: (S:) or A_idohaAnN↓ is [originally] like tadohiynN [as has been stated above]: but is used as denoting the act of treating with gentleness or blandishment, soothing, coaxing, wheedling, beguiling, or deluding; and abstaining from restraint or prohibition: (AHeyth, TA:) or it originally signified the anointing such a thing as a hide with some oil or the like: and as such a thing is rendered soft to the sense [of feeling], it was used tropically, or metaphorically, to denote ideal softness, absolutely: hence, the treating with gentleness or blandishment, soothing, coaxing, wheedling, beguiling, or deluding, was termed mudaAhanapN: then this tropical signification became commonly known, and conventionally regarded as proper: and then the word [mdAhnp or AdhAn↓, or rather each of these words,] was tropically used as signifying the holding a thing in light, or little, or mean, estimation, or in contempt: so in the 'Ináyeh. (MF, TA.) It is said in the Kur [lxviii. 9], wad~uwAlawo tudohinu fayudohinuwna↓ (tropical:) They wish that thou wouldst endeavour to conciliate [them], and in that case they will endeavour to conciliate [thee]: (S, TA: *) or that thou wouldst be soft, pliant, or gentle, in thy religion, and in that case they will be soft, pliant, or gentle: (TA:) or that thou wouldst be soft, pliant, or gentle, to them, and in that case they will be so to thee: (Jel:) or, accord. to Fr, that thou wouldst be an unbeliever, and they will be unbelievers. (TA.)

4 Adhn A^d A^dhn A_d A_dhn Adhn dhn wdY |d |dhn
, inf. n. A_idohaAnN: see 1, first sentence: and see 3, in six places. [See also its act. part. n., below.] ― -b2- AlA_idohaAnu is also syn. with AlA_iboqaA='u, which, accord. to IAmb, is the primary signification: in the copies of the K erroneously written AlA_inoqaA='u. (TA.) One says, laA tudohino Ealayohi, meaning laA tuboqi Ealayohi [Show not thou mercy to him; or pity not him; or pardon not him]. (IAmb, TA.) And maA A^adohanota A_il~aA EalaY nafosika, i. e. maA A^aboqayota [Thou didst not show, or hast not shown, mercy, save to thyself]. (Lh, TA.) ― -b3- One says also, A^adohanotu fiY A^amorihi, meaning I fell short in his affair, or case. (JK.) ＝ -A2- And A^udohina He (a camel) was affected with the vertigo termed duhon. (JK.)

5 tadah~ana
see what next follows.

8 Aid~ahana A^d A^dhn A_d A_dhn Adhn dhn wdY |d |dhn
, of the measure AifotaEala, He anointed himself with duhon, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) i. e. oil, &c.; (Msb;) [oiled, or greased, himself;] as also tdh~n↓. (S.)

Q. Q. 2 tayadohana tydhn
He (a man) took a mudohun [q. v.]. (S.)

dahonN dhn dhnn
: see duhonN. ― -b2- Eayo$N dahonN Bad and scanty [means of subsistence]. (JK.)

duhonN dhn dhnn
Oil, (MA, Msb, KL,) &c., (Msb,) [i. e. grease of any kind,] or duhon [i. e. oil] of sesame &c., (Mgh,) with which one anoints, (Mgh, Msb,) [or greases,] or moistens, (K,) the head or mustache, (Mgh,) or the hair &c., (Msb,) or the head &c.: (K:) it is well known: (S:) and duhonapN↓ signifies a portion thereof: (K:) [or this latter, being the n. un., signifies a particular oil or kind of oil; like as the former does when it is prefixed to another noun:] you say duhonu AlbaAni (S and Mgh and Msb in art. bwn) and duhonapu baAnK (TA in the present art. from a poet) [both meaning oil of ben]: the pl. (of duhonN, S, Msb, and Bd in lv. 37) is dihaAnN (S, Msb, K, and Bd ubi suprà) and A^adohaAnN; (K;) [the latter a pl. of pauc.; both pls. signifying kinds of oil &c.;] or Ald~ihaAnu↓ signifies that with which one anoints; (Bd ubi suprà) or it has this signification also: (TA:) you say, dahanotuhu biAld~ihaAni [meaning I anointed him with oils or with ointment]: (S, in which this is mentioned as an ex. of the pl. of duhonN:) and hence the prov. kaAld~ihaAni EalaY Alwabari Like [ointment or] that with which one anoints [upon fur, or soft hair]. (TA.) [See also dihaAnN below.] ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Weak rain: (AZ, S:) or rain such as moistens the surface of the ground; (JK, K;) and so dahonN↓: (K:) pl. dihaAnN. (AZ, S, K.) ＝ -A2- And A vertigo (duwaAr) that affects the camel. (JK.)

dihonN dhn dhnn
A kind of tree with which beasts of prey are killed, (JK, K,) and by means of which they are taken: (JK:) it is a noxious tree, like the difolaY [q. v.]: (TA:) n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b2- And Such as is large, of trees. (JK.)

dahinN dhn dhnn
Oily, or greasy. (KL.) You say also rajulN mudohaAn~N↓ meaning dahinu Al$~aEari [A man having oily, or greasy, hair]. (TA.) [See also dahiynN.]

dahonapN dhn dhnh dhnnh dhnp
; pl. dahanaAtN: see 1.

duhonapN dhn dhnh dhnnh dhnp
: see duhonN. ― -b2- Also Odour: so in the saying huwa Tay~ibu Ald~uhonapi [He, or it, is sweet in respect of odour]. (K. [Erroneously written and explained by Golius in his Lexicon.])

dahonaA='u dhnA='
A [desert such as is termed] falaAp: (K:)
or a place of sands: (JK:) or a place all sand: (TA:) [or a desert of reddish sand. Hence,] with the article Al, A certain place [or desert tract] belonging to Temeem, in Nejd, (S K, TA,) extending to the distance of three days' journey, in which is no water; (TA;) as also Ald~ahonaY; (S, K;) this latter occurring in poetry. (TA.) [The same appellation is also applied to The great desert of which the central part lies towards the S. E. of Nejd.] ＝ -A2- Also A certain red herb, (K,) having broad leaves, used for tanning. (TA.)

[
duhoniy~apN dhny dhnyh dhnyp
An oily quality.]

dihaAnN dhAn dhn
A red hide. (S, K. [See also dahiynN.]) Hence, in the Kur [lv. 37], fakaAnato warodapF kaAld~ihaAni, i. e. And shall become red, (S,) or of a rosecolour, (Zj, L in art. wrd,) or of a red colour inclining to yellow, (L in that art.,) like the red hide: (S, Bd, Jel:) or like the hide that is of a pure red colour: (TA:) or like that [oil] with which one anoints; see duhonN: or it is pl. of duhonN: (Bd:) [thus] it means, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák [Zj], and shall become [red, &c., and] of various colours, by reason of the very great terror, like divers oils: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, like the dregs of oil, or of olive-oil; for this is another signification of AldhAn. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A slippery place. (JK, K.) And A smooth road: or long and smooth. (TA.)

dahiynN dhY dhy dhyn
[Anointed with oil, &c.; i. q. madohuwnN↓ and madohuwnapN]. You say liHoyapN dahiynN (K) and dahiynapN (TA) and daAhinN↓, (K,) [the last, properly, a possessive epithet,] meaning madohuwnapN [i. e. A beard anointed with oil, &c.]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A hide intensely red. (JK. [See also dihaAnN.]) ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a she-camel, (JK, S, K,) (tropical:) Having little milk: (S, K:) or having very little milk; (JK;) not yielding a drop of milk (JK, TA) when her dug is squeezed: (JK:) accord. to Er-Rághib, having the meaning of an act. part. n., i. e. that yields as much as that with which one may anoint himself: or, as some say, having the meaning of a pass. part. n., because she is anointed [or as though she were anointed] with the milk, by reason of its scantiness; and this is the more probable, because it has not the affix p: pl. duhunN. (TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a stallion, (assumed tropical:) That does not impregnate at all: as though because of the paucity of his seminal fluid. (TA.) ― -b3- And Weak; applied to a man, and to a thing: one says, A^atayota biA^amorK dahiynK [Thou didst, or saidst, or thou hast done, or said, a weak thing]: and Ibn-Hiráweh says,
liyanotaziEuwA turaAva baniY tamiymK
laqadN Zan~uwA binaA Zan~FA dahiynaA
[In order that they might wrest the inheritance of the sons of Temeem, verily they have opined of us a weak opining]. (TA.)

dah~aAnN dhAn dhn
A seller of oil: (MA, TA:) and a maker of oil. (MA.) [In the present day, it is applied to A painter of houses &c.]

daAhinN dAhn dAhnn
: see dahiynN.

mudohanN md mdhn
A camel affected with the vertigo termed duhon. (JK.)

mudohunN md mdhn
, with damm, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) only, (S,) to the m and h, (Msb, TA,) extr [in form], (Fr, TA,) for by rule it should be midohanN, (Msb,) or it was midohanN originally, (Lth, TA,) The utensil (A=lap) for duhon [or oil, &c.]; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) the thing [or pot or vase] in which duhon is put; (T, Msb, TA;) a flask, or phial, (qaAruwrap,) for duhon: (S, K:) [and mudohunapN↓, occurring in this art. and in art. wqb in the TA, signifies the same:] pl. madaAhinu. (S.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A place, (M, K, TA,) or a small hollow or cavity, in a mountain, (S, TA,) in which water remains and collects, or collects and stagnates: (S, M, K, TA:) or any place excavated by a torrent: (K:) or water exuding in stone. (TA.)

mudohinN md mdhn
[act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. ― -b2- A^afabih`*aA AlHadiyvi A^anotumo mudohinuwna, in the Kur [lvi. 80], means Do ye then reject this announcement? or disbelieve &c.? (TA:) or hold in light, or little, or mean, estimation, (Bd, Jel,) and reject, &c.? (Jel.)

madohanapN mdhn mdhnh mdhnp
A place where oil is made; an oil-mill. (MA.)

mudohunapN mdhn mdhnh mdhnp
: see mudohunN.

qawomN mudah~anuwna qwm mdhnwn
(tropical:) A people, or company of men, upon whom are [visible] the traces of ease and plenty, welfare, or well-being. (S, K, TA.)

madohuwnN mdhwn
: see dahiynN. ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aroDN madohuwanapN (tropical:) Land moistened slightly, or a little, by rain. (S, TA:) or having its surface moistened by rain. (TA.)

mudohaAn~N mdhAn
: see dahinN.

superEntry.head: dhw and dhY
superEntry.entry:
1 dahiYa dhY dhy
, aor. yadohaY, (JK, K,) inf. n. dahoYN and dahaA='N and dahaA='apN; (K;) and dahaY, aor. as above, inf. n. dahoYN; (JK;) and dahaA, (JK, TA,) aor. ydohuw, (JK,) or yadohaA [or yadohaY], (TA,) inf. n. dahaA='N (JK, TA) and dahaA='apN; (JK;) and dahuwa, aor. yadohuw, (JK,) [inf. n. app. dahaA='apN;] He possessed cunning; i.e. intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast; and excellence of judgment; (K, TA;) he was, or became, such as is termed daAhK and dahiY~N and dahK. (JK.) [See dahaA='N, below.] ＝ -A2- dahawotuhu, (JK, TA,) inf. n. dahowN; (TA;) and dahayotuhu, (JK,) third pers. dahaAhu, inf. n. dahoYN; (TA;) I treated him with cunning, &c. (JK, * and TA in explanation of the former.) [Both signify also I outwitted, deceived, deluded, beguiled, or circumvented, him.] And duhiytu means I was turned, or kept, from a thing, or an affair, by deceit, or guile. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- Also dahaAhu, inf. n. dahoYN, He attributed, or imputed, to him cunning, &c.; expl. by nasabahu A_ilaY Ald~ahaA='i [an inverted phrase]: or he attributed, or imputed, to him a vice, or fault, or the like; blamed him, censured him, found fault with him, or detracted from his reputation: or he smote him with a daAhiyap, i. e. great, formidable, grievous, or distressing, thing or event or accident or action: and dh~Ahu↓ signifies the same: (K:) thus in the K, with teshdeed: but in the M and Tekmileh it is said that dahayotuhu and dahawotuhu signify I attributed, or imputed, to him cunning (Ald~ahaA='); without mention of tadohiyapN [inf. n. of dah~aY]. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also dahaAhu AlA^amoru, aor. yadohaY, The thing, or event, befell him: (Msb:) and dahatohu daAhiyapN [a calamity befell him]. (S.) And maA dahaAka What befell, or hath befallen, thee? (S.)

2 1a2~a3a
see above.

3 dAhAhu dAhAh dAhAp
(inf. n. mudaAhaApN, M in art. Arb, and K in art. wrb, &c.,) He strove, or endeavoured, to outwit, deceive, delude, beguile, or circumvent, him; syn. A=rabahu, (S in art. Arb,) and waArabahu, (K in art. wrb,) and naAkarahu. (TA in art. nkr.) ― -b2- And dAhY bidaAhiyapK, inf. n. as above, He smote people with a calamity. (TA.)

4 AdhAhu A^dhAh A^dhY AdhAh AdhAp dhY
He found him to be such as is termed daAhK [i. e. cunning, &c.], (IDrd, TA,) or daAhiyap [which signifies the same in an intensive sense]. (JK.) ― -b2- [AdhY preceded by maA is also used as a verb of wonder.] A poet says,
A^abaA xaAlidK maA kaAna A^adohaY muSiybapF
A^aSaAbato maEad~FA yawoma A^aSobaHota vaAwiyaA
Aboo-Khálid, how great was the calamity that befell Ma' add on the day when thou diedst [or wast slain]! (Ham p. 440.)

5 tdh~Y dhY dhy tdhY tdhy
[He acted cunningly;] he did as do the duhaAp [or cunning, &c., pl. of daAhK]. (ISd, K.)

6 tdAhY tdAhY tdAhy
[He affected, or pretended, to possess dahaA='; i. e., to be cunning, &c.]. (IAar, K in art. xzr: see 1 and 2 in that art.)

dahK dh dp
: see daAhK, in two places. ＝ -A2- A_il~aA dahK falaA dahK: see art. dh.

dahowN dhw
: see dahaA='N.

dahoYN dhY dhy
: see dahaA='N. ＝ -A2- Also A large [bucket such as is called] garob. (AA, TA.)

dahowaA='u dhwA='
: see the next paragraph.

dahoyaA='u dhyA='
: see daAhiyapN. ― -b2- It is also used as a corroborative: (ISk, S:) you say daAhiyapN dahoyaA='u (ISk, JK, S, Msb) and dahowaA='u↓ (ISk, JK, S, Msb, K) and ↓: duhowiy~apN, (JK, K,) meaning A severe, grievous, or distressing, calamity or misfortune: (JK:) or a very severe or grievous or distressing [calamity]. (K.)

duhowiy~apN dhwyh dhwyp
: see what next precedes.

dahaA='N dhA='
(in which the ' is converted from Y not from w S) and dahoYN↓(JK, S, K) and dahowN↓ (JK, TA) [are all inf. ns., and] are syn., (JK, S, K, TA,) signifying Cunning; i. e. intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast; (TA in art. AHd;) i. q. A_irobN, (K,) and nukorN: (S, K:) and excellence of judgment. (S, K.)
[It is said in the S, app. with reference to dahaA='N, that the dual is dahoyaAwaAni: but this is the regular dual of dahoyaA='u; like HamoraAwani, dual of HamoraA='u]

dahiY~N dhY dhy
: see what next follows, in three places.

daAhK dAh dAhy dAp
and dahK↓ (JK, K) and dahiY~N↓, part. ns. of dahaY and dahiYa and dahuwa [respectively]: (JK,) and daAhiyapN↓, applied to a man, Cunning; i. e. possessing intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast: and excellent in judgment: (S, K:) i. q. munokarN [as syn. with nakirN]: (TA, and JK in explanation of daAhiyapN:) knowing, or skilful, in affairs: (TA:) or dahiY~N↓ signifies [simply] intelligent: (AA, K:) and daAhiyapN↓ is [an intensive epithet, signifying very cunning; i. e. possessing much intelligence, &c.;] from dahaA='N explained above: or [it means one who is as though he were calamity, or misfortune, personified;] from Ald~aAhiyapu in the sense commonly known [which see below]: (TA in art. AHid:) the pl. (of daAhK, JK, TA) is duhaApN, and (of dahK↓, JK, TA) dahuwna, (JK, K, TA,) and of dahiY~N↓, A^adohiyaA='u (JK, M, TA) and duhawaA='u, in the K, erroneously, A^adohiyapN and dahowaA='u. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ald~aAhiY The lion. (K.)

daAhiyapN dAhy dAhyh dAhyp
A calamity, a misfortune, an evil accident; (JK, Msb;) a great, formidable, grievous, or distressing, thing or event or accident or action; (S, K;) and dahoyaA='u↓ signifies the same: (JK, TA:*) [the dim. of the former, duwayohiyapN↓, generally means a great calamity &c.; being an instance of what is termed taSogiyru taEoZiymK:] the pl. of daAhiyapN is dawaAhK: (Msb, TA:) and dawaAhiY Ald~ahori means the great, formidable, grievous, or distressing, events of fortune that befall men. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also daAhK, in two places.

duwayohiyapN dwyhy dwyhyh dwyhyp
: see the next preceding paragraph.

A^adohaY *
[More, and most, cunning, &c. Hence,] A^adohaY mino qayosi boni zuhayorK [More intelligent, or sagacious, than Keys the son of Zuheyr]: a prov. (Meyd.)

madohuw~N mdhw
and madohiY~N pass. part. ns.; (JK, TA;) Treated with cunning, &c. (TA in explanation of the former.)

2 dw~Y dwAyp dwY dwy
He took his way in the daw~ [q. v.]. (M, K.) And dw~Y fiYAlA^aroDi He went away into the country, or in the land. (T.) Ru-beh uses the phrase dw~Y bihaA as signifying He passed by them; meaning, by them, a male [wild] ass and his she-asses. (T.) And it is said of the daw~iy~ap that it is thus called liA^an~ahaA tudaw~iY SaAra fiyhaA, i. e. Because it makes away with those who are in it. (T.) ＝ -A2- See also art. dwY.

It is said in the trad. respecting the night-journey [of Mo- hammad to Jerusalem, and his ascension thence into Heaven], that Moses said to Mohammad, laqado daAwarotu baniY A_isoraAy^iyla EalaY A^adonaY mino h`*aA faDaEufuwA [(assumed tropical:) Verily I endeavoured to induce the children of Israel to incline to less than this, and they were unable]: or, accord. to one relation, he said raAwadotu. (TA.) See also 4. ― -b4- daAwara AlA^umuwra (tropical:) He sought to find the modes, or manners, of doing, or performing, affairs, or the affairs: (A:) AlmudaAwarapN is like AlmuEaAlajapN [signifying the labouring, taking pains, applying one's self vigorously, exerting one's self, striving, or struggling, to do, execute, or perform, or to effect, or accomplish, or to manage, or treat, a thing; &c.]. (S, K.) Suheym Ibn-Wetheel says,
A^axuw xamosiyna mujotamiEN A^a$ud~iY
wanaj~adaniY mudaAwarapu Al$~uw^uwni
[Fifty years of age, my manly vigour full, and vigorous application to the management of affairs has tried and strengthened me]. (S.)

4 AdArhu A^dAr A^dArh A_dArp AdArh AdArp dArY
, (S, M, A, K,) and dw~rhu↓, (M, A, K,) and bihi daAra↓, (M, TA,) and bihi dw~r↓, (S, K,) and AadaAra bihi, and AstdAr↓, (M, K,) He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to go, move, or turn, round; to circle; to revolve; to return to the place from which he, or it, began to move. (TA.) You say, A^adaAra AlEimaAmapa EalaY raA^osihi [He wound the turban round upon his head]. (A.) And AdAr Alz~aEofaraAna fiY AlmaA='i [He stirred round the saffron in the water, in dissolving it]. (A and TA in art. dwm.) And
bihi dawaAy^iru Alz~amaAni daArato↓
[The revolutions of fortune, or time, made him to turn round from one state, or condition, to another]. (A.) And bihi diyra↓, and A^udiyra bihi, (S, A, K,) and Ealayohi diyra↓ (K,) [the first and second lit. signifying He was made to turn round; by which, as by the third also, is meant] he became affected by a vertigo, or giddiness in the head. (S, * A, * K. [See also 1.]) ― -b2- AdArhu EalaY AlA^amori He endeavoured [to turn him to the thing, i. e.] to induce him to do the thing: and AdArhu Eanohu he endeavoured [to turn him from it, i. e.] to induce him to leave, or relinquish, it; (T, A;) or i. q. laAwaSahu; as also daAwarahu↓, q. v. (M, K.) ― -b3- A_idaArapN [the inf. n.] also signifies The giving and taking, from hand to hand, without delay: and agreeably with this explanation is rendered the phrase in the Kur [ii. 282], lijaArapN HaADirapN tudiyruwnahaA bayonakumo Ready merchandise, which ye give and take among yourselves, from hand to hand, without delay; i. e., not on credit]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1: ― -b5- and 2, in two places.

5 tdy~r AlmakaAna tdyr AlmkAn
He took the place as a house, or an abode. (A.) [The Y in this verb takes the place of w, as in dayorN and AayobapN &c.]

10 AstdAr AstdAr {stdAr
[It had, or assumed, a round, or circular, form; it coiled itself, or became coiled; it wound, or wound round;] it was, or became, round. (KL.) You say, AstdAr Alqamaru [The moon became round, or full: see also the act. part. n., below]. (A.) And laf~ato vawobFA kaA@loEiSaAbapi EalaY A@sotidaArapi raA^osihaA [She wound a piece of cloth like the fillet upon the round of her head, leaving the crown uncovered]. (Mgh and L and Msb voce miEojarN.) ― -b2- See also 1, in six places. ― -b3- And see 4.

daArN dAr dAry
, [originally dawarN, as will be seen below, A house; a mansion; and especially a house of a large size, comprising a court; or a house comprising several sets of apartments and a court; (see bayotN;)] a place of abode which comprises a building, or buildings, and a court, or space in which is no building: (T, M, K:) as also daArapN↓: (M, K:) or the latter is a more special term; (S;) meaning any particular house; the former being a generic term: (MF:) accord. to IJ, it is from daAra, aor. yaduwru; because of the many movements of the people in it: (M:) it is of the fem. gender: (S, Msb:) and sometimes masc.; (S, K;) as in the Kur xvi. 32, as meaning mavowaY, or mawoDiE, (S,) or as being a gen. n.: (MF:) pl. (of pauc., S) A^adow^urN and A^adowurN (S, Msb, K) and A=durN, (Abu-l- Hasan, AAF, Msb, K,) formed by transposition, (Msb,) [for A^awodurN,] and A^adowaArN (T, K) and A^adoyaArN (T) and A^adowirapN, (T, K,) and (of mult., S) diyaArN, (S, Msb, K,) like as jibaAlN is pl. of jabalN, (S,) and diwaArN (T) and diyaArapN (M, K) and duwrN, (T, S, M, Msb,) like as A^usodN is pl. of A^asadN, (S,) and diyraAnN (T, M, K) and duwraAnN (T, K) and diyarN and diyarapN, (T,) and [quasi-pl. n.] daArapN↓, and [pl. pl.] diyaAraAtN [pl. of diyaArN] and duwraAtN [pl. of duwrN], (M, K,) and [pl. of daArapN] daAraAtN. (T.) The dim. is duwayorapN↓. (Har p. 161.) [Hence, daAru AlDarobi The mint: &c.] ― -b2- Also Any place in which a people have alighted and taken up their abode; an abode; a dwelling. (T, Mgh.) Hence the present world is called daAru AlfanaA='i [The abode of perishableness; or the perishable abode]: and the world to come, daAru AlbaqaA='i [The abode of everlastingness; or the everlasting abode]; and daAru AlqaraAri [The abode of stability; or the stable abode]; and daAru Als~alaAmi [The abode of peace, or of freedom evil]. (T.) [And hence, daAru AlHarobi: see HarobN.] [Hence, also,] daArN is applied to A burial-ground. (Nh from a trad.) ― -b3- [And hence,] AisotaA^o*ino EalaY rab~iY fiY daArihi [Ask thou permission for me to go in to my Lord] in his Paradise. (TA from a trad. respecting intercession.) ― -b4- And saA^uriykumo daAra AlfaAsiqiyna, in the Kur [vii. 142, I will show you the abode of the transgressors], meaning Egypt: or, accord. to Mujáhid, the abode to which the transgressors shall go in the world to come. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence, also,] daArN signifies i. q. baladN [A country, or district: or a city, town, or village]. (Mgh, K.) ― -b6- And, with the art. Al, [El-Medeeneh;] the City of the Prophet. (K.) ― -b7- And hence, (TA,) daArN also signifies (tropical:) A tribe; syn. qabiylapN: (A, K:) for A^aholu daArK: (TA:) as also daArapN↓: (K:) pl. of the former, duwrN. (A, Msb.) You say, mar~ato binaA daAru baniY fulaAnK (tropical:) The tribe of the sons of such a one passed by us. (A.) And in the same sense dAr is used in a trad. in which it is said that there remained no dAr among which (fiyhaA) a mosque had not been built. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Mtr states that it is said to signify also A year; syn. HawolN; and if this be correct, which he does no hold to be the case, it is from Ald~awaraAnu, like as HawolN is from AlHawalaAnu: or, as some say, i. q. dahorN [as meaning a long time, or the like]. (Har p. 350.) ＝ -A3- And Ald~aAru is the name of A certain idol. (Msb, K.) ＝ -A4- [dAr and dyr explained by Freytag as meaning “ Medulla liquida in ossibus ” are mistakes for raArN and rayorN.]

daworN dAr dwr
an inf. n. of daAra. (S, M, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence, The circumference of a circle: see takosiyrN.] ― -b3- And A turn, or twist, of a turban, (T, A,) and of a rope, or any other thing: (T:) pl. A^adowaArN. (A.)

dayorN dyr
, originally with w; (T, S;) or originally thus, with Y, (M, [and so accord. to the place in which it is mentioned in the A and Msb and K,]) as appears from the occurrence of the Y in its pl. and in the derivative day~aArN, for if the Y were in this case interchangeable with w it would occur in other derivatives; (M;) [or this is not a valid reason, for day~aArN is held by J to be originally dayowaArN, i. e. of the measure fayoEaAlN; and ISd himself seems in one place to express the same opinion; in like manner as day~uwrN is held by the latter to be originally dayowuwrN; and taday~ara is evidently altered from tadaw~ara;] A convent, or monastery, (xAn,) of Christians: (M, K:) and also the SawomaEap [i. e. cloister, or cell,] of a monk: (A:) the pl. is A^adoyaArN (S, M, K) and duyuwrapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rA^osu Ald~ayori [lit. The head of the convent or monastery] is an appellation given to (tropical:) Any one who has become the head, or chief, of his companions. (IAar, S, A, K.)

daArapN dAr dArh dArp
: see daAy^irapN, in two places. [Hence,] daArapN Alqamari The halo (haAalp) of the moon; (S, A, Msb, * K;) as also daw~aArap↓: (K * and TA in art. Hlq:) pl. daAraAtN. (Msb.) Dim. duwayorapN↓. (Har p. 609.) One says, fulaAnN wajohuhu mivolu daArapi Alqamari [Such a one's face is like the halo of the moon]. (TA.) And AlA_isolaAmi Hat~aY yaxoruja Alqamaru mino laA taxorujo Eano daAy^irapi↓ daAratihi [Go not thou forth from the circle of ElIslám until the moon go forth from its halo]. (A.) ― -b2- Also A round space of sand; (K;) as also day~rapN↓, incorrectly written in the K diyrap↓ (TA) [and in some copies dayorap]; and tadowirapN↓: pl. of the first daAraAtN and duwrN: (K:) and pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the second day~irN↓: (TA:) or daArapN signifies, accord. to As, a round tract of sand with a vacancy in the middle; as also duwrapN↓, or, as others say, daworapN↓, and daw~aArapN↓ and day~irapN↓; and sometimes people sit and drink there. (T.) ― -b3- And Any wide space of land among mountains: (K:) it is reckoned among productive low lands: (AHn:) or a plain, or soft, tract of land encompassed by mountains: (A:) or a wide and plain space of land so encompassed: (As:) or i. q. buhorapN, except that this is always plain, or soft, whereas a dArp may be rugged and plain, or soft: (Aboo-Fak'as, Kr:) or any clear and open space among sands. (TA.) ― -b4- And Any place that is surrounded and confined by a thing. (T, A.) ― -b5- See also daArN, in three places. ＝ -A2- daArapu, determinate, (M, K,) and imperfectly decl., (M,) Calamity, or misfortune. (Kr, M, K.)

daworapN dAr dwr dwrh dwrp
: see daArapN: ＝ -A2- and see also daAy^irapN.

duwrapN dAr dwr dwrh dwrp
: see daArapN.

diyrapN dAr dyr dyrh dyrp
: see daArapN.

daAriY~N dAr dArY dAry dAryy
A man (A) who keeps to his house; (M, K;) who does not quit it, (M, A,) nor seek sustenance; (M;) as also daAriy~apN↓. (K.) ― -b2- And hence, (S,) (assumed tropical:) A possessor of the blessings, comforts, or conveniences, of life: (S, K:) pl. daAriy~uwna. (S.) ― -b3- Also A camel, or sheep or goat, that remains at the house, not going to pasture: fem. with p: (A:) or a camel that remains behind in the place where the others lie down; (M, K;) and so a sheep or goat. (M.) ― -b4- See also day~aArN. ＝ -A2- A sailor that has the charge of the sail. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- A seller of perfumes: so called in relation to Dáreen, (S, A, K,) a port of ElBahreyn, in which was a market whereto musk used to be brought from India. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., mavalu Aljaliysi AlS~aAliHi mavalu Ald~aAriY~i A_ino lamo yuHo*ika mino EiTorihi Ealiqaka mino riyHihi [The similitude of the righteous companion who sits and converses with one is that of the seller of perfumes: if he give not to thee of his perfume, somewhat of his sweet odour clings to thee]. (S.)

duwriY~N dAr dwr dwrY dwry dwryy
: see day~aArN.

daAriy~apN dAr dAry dAryh dAryp
: see daAriY~N.

dayoraAniY~N dyrAnY dyrAny
(anomalous [as a rel. n. from dayorN], M) and day~aArN↓ The master, (SaAHib, S, M, K,) or an inhabitant, (T, A,) of a dayor [i. e. convent, or monastery]. (T, S, M, A, K.)

dawaArN dwAr
: see the next paragraph, in three places.

duwaArN dwAr
A vertigo, or giddiness in the head; (S, * A, * K;) as also dawaArN↓. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, and dawaArN↓, (S,) or Ald~uwaAru and Ald~awaAru↓, (T, M, K,) and (but less commonly, TA) Ald~uw~aAru↓ and Ald~aw~aAru↓, (M, K,) A certain idol, (T, S, M, K,) which the Arabs set up, and around it they made a space, (T,) round which they turned, or circled: (T, M:) and the same name they applied to the space above mentioned: (T, M:) it is said that they thus compassed it certain weeks, like as people compass the Kaabeh: (MF:) or certain stones around which they circled, in imitation of people compassing the Kaabeh. (IAmb.) Imra-el- Keys says,
Ea*aAraY duwaArK fiY mulaA='K mu*ay~ali
[Virgins making the circuit of Duwár, in
long-skirted garments of the kind called mulaA=']: (S:) likening a herd of [wild] cows to damsels thus occupied and attired, alluding to the length of their tails. (TA.) Ald~uw~aAru↓ and Ald~aw~aAru↓ also signify The Kaabeh. (Kr, M, K.) And duw~aArN↓ (Th, M, [not duw~aArapN, as is implied in the K,]) A circling tract (musotadaAr↓) of sand, around which go the wild animals: (Th, M, K:) a poet says,
bid~uwaAri nihoY *iY EaraArK waHul~abi
[In the sandy tract around a pool of water left by a torrent, containing plants of the kinds called 'arár and hullab]. (Th, M.)

duwayorapN dwyrh dwyrp
: see daArN and daArapN, of each of which it is the dim.

day~irN dyr
: see daAarpN.

day~irapN dAr dyr dyrh dyrp
: see daAarpN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also daAy^irapN.

daw~aArN dwAr
[Turning round, circling, or revolving,] applied to the firmament, or celestial orb. (A.) ― -b2- Applied likewise to time, or fortune; (M, K;) as also daw~aAriY~N↓, (S, M, A, K,) which is said to be a rel. n., but is not so accord. to AAF, though having the form thereof, like kurosiY~N, (M,) the Y being a corroborative: (Msb voce waHo$iY~N:) thus in the saying,
waAld~ahoru biA@loA_inosaAni daw~aAriY~u↓
(S, M, * A, * K, *) occurring in a poem of El-'Ajjáj, (S,) and daw~aArN, (M, K,) i. e. And time, or fortune, turns man about from one state, or condition, to another: (S, M, * A, K: *) or turns him about much. (Msb in art. wH$.) ＝ -A2- See also duwaArN, in two places.

duw~aArN dwAr
: see duwaArN, in three places.

maA biAld~aAri day~aArN mA bAldAr dyAr
, (S, M, A, K,) originally dayowaArN, of the measure fayoEaAlN, (S,) and duwriY~N↓, (S, M, K,) and day~iwrN↓, (M, K,) in which a w is changed into Y, (M,) [dy~wr being originally dayowuwrN,] and daAriY~N↓, There is not in the house any one: (S, M, K:) the broken pl. of day~aArN and day~uwrN is dawaAwiyru; the w being unchanged because of its distance from the end of the word. (M.) ISd says, in the EawiyS, that Yaakoob has erred in asserting dy~Ar to be used only in negative phrases; for Dhu-r-Rummeh uses it in an affirmative phrase. (MF.) ― -b2- See also dayoraAniY~N.

day~uwrN dywr
: see the next preceding paragraph.

daw~aArapN dwAr dwArh dwArp
: see daArapN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also duw~aArapN, in two places: ― -b3- and daAy^irapN. ― -b4- Also [or perhaps duw~aArapN↓] The pieces of wood which the water turns so as to make the mill turn with their turning. (Mgh.) ― -b5- And A pair of compasses. (T, K, * TA.)

duw~aArapN dwAr dwArh dwArp
and daw~aArapN↓, of the head, A round part or portion. (M, K.) ― -b2- And of the belly, What winds, or what has, or assumes, a coiled, or circular, form, (maA taHaw~aY, [so in the M and L, in the K mAyaHowiY, which is evidently a mistake,]) of the guts, or intestines, of a sheep or goat. (M, L, K. *) ― -b3- Accord. to IAar, (T,) daw~aArapN↓ and faw~aArapN are applied to Anything [round] that does not move nor turn round: and duw~aArapN and fuw~aArapN to a thing that moves and turns round. (T, K, TA.) ― -b4- See also daw~aArapN.

daw~aAriY~N dwAr dwArY dwAry dwAryy
: see daw~aArN, in two places.

daAy^irapN *
, in which the p is added for the purpose of transferring the word from the category of epithets to that of substs, and as a sign of the fem. gender, ('Ináyeh,) The circuit, compass, ambit, or circumference, of a thing; (T, K, TA;) as in the phrases daAy^irapu AlHaAfiri the circuit of, or what surrounds, the solid hoof, (TA,) or the circuit of hair around the solid hoof, (T,) and daAy^irapu Alwajohi the circuit of the face, or the parts around the face; (TA;) and daArapN↓ signifies the same: (K:) pl. of the former dawaAy^iru; and of the latter daAraAtN. (TA.) [Hence one says, h`*aA A^awosaEu daAy^irapF mino *aAka, meaning (assumed tropical:) This is wider in compass, or more comprehensive, than that. See also 10, third sentence.] ― -b2- A ring: (M, K:) or the like thereof; a circle: and a round thing: as also daArapN↓; pl. as above. (T.) See an ex. voce daArapN. ― -b3- The circular, or spiral, curl of hair upon the crown of a man's head: (T, M, K:) or the place of the duw^aAbap. (IAar, M, K.) Hence the prov., maA A@qo$aEar~ato lahu daAy^iratiY [The circular, or spiral, curl of hair upon the crown of my head did not stand erect on account of him]: said of him who threatens thee with a thing but does not harm thee. (M.) ― -b4- [What is called, in a horse, A feather; or portion of the hair naturally curled or frizzled, in a spiral manner or otherwise]: pl. dawaAy^iru. (T, S, Msb.) In a horse are eighteen dwAy^r, (AO, T, S,) which are distinguished by different names, as AlqahoEapu and AlqaAliEu and Aln~aAxisu and All~aTaApu [&c.]. (AO, T.) ― -b5- The round thing [or depression] (T) that is beneath the nose, (T, K,) which is likewise called nuwnapN; (T;) as also daw~aArapN↓ (T, K) and day~irapN↓. (T.) [But the daAy^irap in the middle of the upper lip is The small protuberance termed HivorimapN, q. v.] ＝ -A2- A turn of fortune: (AO:) and especially an evil accident; a misfortune; a calamity; (A, * TA;) as also daworapN↓: (TA:) defeat; rout: (S, K:) slaughter: death: (TA:) pl. as above. (A, Msb, &c.) You say, daArato Ealayohimu Ald~awaAy^iru Calamities befell them. (M.) And hence, daAy^irapu Als~uwo'i [and Als~awo'i, in the Kur ix. 99 and xlviii. 6,] (S, Msb) Calamity which befalls and destroys. (Msb. [See also art. swA^.]) ＝ -A3- Also A piece of wood which is stuck in the ground in the middle of a heap of wheat in the place where it is trodden, around which the bulls or cows turn. (TA.)

tadowirapN dAr dwr tdwrh tdwrp
: see daArapN. ― -b2- Also i. q. majolisN [A sittingplace, &c.]. (Seer, M.)

madaArN mdAr mdrY
an inf. n. of daAra. (Lth, T.) ＝ -A2- And also, as a proper subst., (T,) The axis of the firmament, or celestial orb, [&c.] (T, A.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) The point upon which a question, or the like, turns. Pl. madaAraAtN.]

mudaArN mdAr mdrY
: see mudaw~arN: ― -b2- and see what next follows.

huwa maduwru bihi hw mdwr bh hw mdwr bp
and bh mudaArN↓ [He is affected by a vertigo, or giddiness in the head: see 4]. (A.)

mudaArapN mdAr mdArh mdArp mdrh
A skin made round, and sewed, (S, K,) in the form of a bucket, (S,) with which one draws water. (S, K.) A rájiz says,
laAyasotaqiY fiY Aln~azaHi AlmaDofuwfi
A_il~aA mudaAraAtu Alguruwbi Aljuwfi
[Nothing will draw water in a well of which most of the water has been exhausted, to which many press to draw, except the kind of buckets made of a round piece of skin, of ample capacity]: i. e. one cannot draw water from a small quantity but with wide and shallow buckets: but some say that mdArAt should be mdArAp, from AlmudaAraApu fiY AlA^umuwri; holding it to be for bimudaAraApi Ald~ilaA='i; and reading laA yusotaqaY. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also A garment of the kind called A_zaAr figured (K, TA) with sundry circles: pl. mudaAraAtN. (TA.)

mudowarapN mdwr mdwrh mdwrp
, thus preserving its original form, (K,) not having the w changed into A, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, mudaw~arap,] She-camels which the pastor goes round about and milks. (K.)

mudaw~arN mdwr
and mudaArN↓ [Made round, meaning both circular and spherical; rounded; and simply round: the former word is the more common: of the latter, see an ex. in a verse cited voce yalabN: and see also musotadiyrN].

musotadaAru mstdAr
[a noun of place and of time from AisotadaAra, agreeably with a general rule]: see duwaArN.

musotadiyrN mstdyr
[Having, or assuming, a round, or circular, form; round, or circular: see also mudaw~arN]. You say qamarN musotadiyrN musotaniyrN [A round, or full, shining moon]. (A. [Accord. to the TA, the latter epithet is added as an explicative of the former; but this I think an evident mistake.])

1 daAsa dAs
, aor. yduwsu, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. dawosN (S, M, A, Mgh, K) and diyaAsN (M, A, K) and diyaAsapN, (A, K,) He trod, trod upon, or trampled upon, (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) a thing, (S, M, Mgh,) or the ground, (Msb,) vehemently, (Mgh, Msb,) with the foot. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, daAsuwhu biA^aqodaAmihimo [They trod, or trampled, upon him, or it, with their feet]. (A.) And Alxayolu taduwsu AlqatolaY biAlHawaAfiri [The horses trample upon the slain with the hoofs]. (A.) ― -b2- daAsa AlT~aEaAma, (S, A,) or AlHinoTapa, (Msb,) or AlHab~a, (M,) aor. yaduwsu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. dyaAsapN, (S, A, Mgh,) or dawosN and diyaAsN, but some say that diyaAsN is not of the language of the Arabs, and some say that it is tropical, as though from daAsa in the
sense explained above, (Msb,) or the professors of practical religion use it in the place of diyaAsapN by a kind of license, relying upon the understanding of the hearer or reader, or do so erroneously, (Mgh,) He trod, or thrashed, (M, Mgh, Msb,) the wheat, (Mgh, Msb,) or grain, (M,) either by the feet of beasts, or by repeatedly drawing over it the midowas [q. v. infrà] until it became tibon [or cut straw]; (Mgh;) as also A^adaAsahu↓. (M.) You say, daAsuwhu dawosa AlHaSiydi [They trod, or trampled, upon him, or it, with the treading of reaped corn]. (A.) ― -b3- daAsahu, (IAar, TA,) inf. n. dawosN, (IAar, A, K,) He abased him. (IAar, A, K.) ― -b4- nazala AlEaduw~u bibaniY fulaAnK fajaAsahumo waHaAsahumo wadaAsahumo The enemy [came upon and] slew the sons of such a one, and went through the midst of their dwellings, and made havoc among them. [When a burd (a kind of garment) is rent, the like thereof is rent with the burd, the action being done by turns, so that there is no wearer of the burd; it having been rent so as to fall off]: (S:) the poet is speaking of a man's rending the clothing of a woman to see her person, and her rending his also. (T, TA. [This verse is related with several variations: see another reading of it voce ha*aA*ayoka, in art. h*; with another explanation of it.]) ― -b2- Ibn-Buzurj says, (T,) sometimes the article Al is prefixed to it, so that one says Ald~awaAlayoka, (T,) meaning One's walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side, (T,) or one's urging, or pressing forward, and striving, (A^ano yataHaf~aza, [in the CK, erroneously, An yataHaf~aza,]) in his gait, or pace, (K,) when he moves about his shoulder-joints, and parts his legs widely, in walking. (T, K,* TA. In the copies of the K, jAl [or jA'k] is erroneously put for HaAka, the reading in the T, TA. [The author of the TK follows the reading jAl; and has fallen into several other evident mistakes in explaining this expression; which is itself, in my opinion, when with the article Al, a mistake for Ald~awaAliyoku, mentioned in art. dlk.]) A poet uses the phrase yamo$iY Ald~awaAlayoka as meaning Walking, or going, in the manner explained above: (Ibn-Buzurj, T and TA in the present art.:) or yamo$iY Ald~awaAliyka. (TA in art. dlk.)

munodaAlN mndAl
as meaning Dangling, or moving to and fro; and hanging; is said by Seer to be of the measure munofaEilN from Alt~adal~aY, and formed by transposition; and if so, it has no inf. n.; for the word that is formed by transposition has no inf. n. (M. [But for this assertion I see no satisfactory reason.])

mutadawaAlN mtdwAl
: see dawalN. ― -b2- [AlkalaAmu AlmutadaAwalu signifies, in modern Arabic, The language commonly used.]

duwlaAbN dwlAb
, or dawolaAbN: see art. dlb.

1 daAma dAm dAmy
, aor. yaduwmu and yadaAmu; (S, M, Msb, K;) the see. pers. of the pret. when the aor. is yaduwmu being dumota; and when the aor. is yadaAm, dimota; (M;) and accord. to Kr, (M,) you say also dimota, aor. taduwmu, which is extr., (M, K,) and not of valid authority, held by the lexicologists [in general] to be anomalous like mit~a having for its aor. tamuwtu, and faDila of which the aor. is yafoDulu, and HaDira of which the aor. is yaHoDuru, and said by Aboo-Bekr to be a compound of the pret. of which the aor. is tadaAmu with the aor. of which the pret. is dumota; (M;) inf. n. dawomN and dawaAmN [which is the most common form] and dayomuwmapN [originally dayowamuwmapN, like qayoduwdapN originally qayowaduwdapN, &c.]; (S, M, Msb, K;) i. q. vabata [as meaning It (a thing, S, M, Msb) continued, lasted, endured, or remained]: (Msb, TK:) and it became extended, or prolonged; syn. Aimotad~a: (TK:) and [it continued, lasted, endured, or remained, long;] its time was, or became, long: (TA:) and i. q. baqiYa [as syn. with vabata (explained above) and as meaning it continued, lasted, or existed, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; it was, or became, permanent, perpetual, or everlasting]: (Msb in art. bqY:) and AstdAm↓ signifies the same as dAm [in all of these senses]: (TA:) [but Mtr says,] AstdAm Als~afaru [The journey continued, or continued long,] is not of established authority. (Mgh.) [Hence, daAma mulokuhu May his dominion be of long continuance.] And dAm EalaY AlA^amori; (MA;) and Ealayohi dAwm↓, [and dAwmhu↓, as is shown by a usage of the act. part. n. in art. dmn in the S, &c.,] (S, * MA,) inf. n. mudaAwamapN; (S;) He kept continually, or constantly, to the thing, or affair. (S, MA.) maA daAma means Continuance; because mA is a conjunct noun to dAm; and it is not used otherwise than adverbially, like as inf. ns. are used adverbially: you say, laA A^ajolisu maA dumota qaAy^imFA, i. e., dawaAma qiyaAmika [I will not sit during the continuance of thy standing]; (S, TA;) [or as long as thou standest; or while thou standest; for] mA denotes time; and qumo maA daAma zayodN qaAy^imFA means mud~apa qiyaAmi zayodK [i. e. Stand thou during the period of Zeyd's standing]. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) [And EalaYAld~awaAmi means Continually, or constantly; like daAy^imFA.] ― -b2- Said of rain, it means It fell, or descended, consecutively, continuously, or constantly. (Msb.) Some say, (M,) daAmati Als~amaA='u, aor. tadiymN, inf. n. dayomN, (M, K,) which, if correct, should be included in art. dym, (M,) meaning The sky rained continually; as also daw~amat↓ and day~amat, (M, K,) in which last the w is changed into Y as it is in diymapN, (M,) and AdAmt↓: (K:) or rained such rain as is termed diymap; (M in art. dym;) and so day~amat↓, inf. n. tadoyiymN; (S in art. dym;) and AdAmt↓. (Z, TA.) [See also dawomN, below.] IAar cites the following verse, (M, TA,) by Jahm Ibn-Shibl, (TA in this art.,) or Ibn-Sebel, (TA in art. sbl, in which, also, the verse is cited,) in praise of a horse, as is said in “ the Book of Plants ” of Ed-Deenäwaree, and in
“ the Book of Horses ” of Ibn-El-Kelbee, not, as J asserts it to be, in praise of a munificent man, (TA,)
huwa AljawaAdu bonu AljawaAdi boni sabalo
jaAda wa A_ino jaAduwA wabalo A_ino day~amuwA↓
[He is the fleet, the son of the fleet, the son of Sebel (a famous mare): if they are unremitting in their running, (the masc. pl. being here used, though relating to horses, in like manner as it is used in the Kur xli. 20,) he is fleet; and if they are fleet, he is vehement in his running]: or, as some relate it, A_ino daw~amuwA. (M, TA. [It should be observed that the three verbs in this verse, and the word sbl, also relate to rain.]) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a thing, T) was, or became, still, or motionless; said of water (T, S, * Msb, K, * TA) left in a pool by a torrent, and of the boiling of a cooking-pot; (Msb;;) and said, in this sense, of the sea: (M:) and it stopped, or stood still. (T, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, tired, or fatigued: (T, TA:) [app. because he who is so stops to rest.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) went round, revolved, or circled: (T, TA:) [app. because that which does so keeps near to one place.] dawamaAnN [an inf. n. of daAma like as HawamaAnN is of HaAma,] signifies (tropical:) The circling of a bird (K, TA) around water. (TA. [But in my MS. copy of the K, and in the CK, in the place of Ald~awamaAnu I find Ald~awamaA='u↓. See also 2.]) [Hence,] diyma bihi (tropical:) He was taken, or affected, with a vertigo, or giddiness in the head; as also bihi A^udiyma↓, (M, TA,) and Ausotudiyma↓ [app., in like manner, followed by bihi]. (Z, TA.) ― -b6- daAmati Ald~alowi, (K,) inf. n. dawomN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The bucket became full: (K:) in this meaning, regard is had to the stagnant water [in the bucket]. (TA.)

2 daw~amati Als~amaA='u dwmt AlsmA='
, and day~amat: and day~amuwA said of horses: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- dw~mt AlkilaAbu The dogs went far: (Akh, IAar, M, K:) or continued their course. (IAar, M.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, (de scribing a wild bull, T, TA,)
Hat~aY A_i*aA daw~amato fiY AlA^aroDi raAjaEahu
kiborN wa lawo $aA='a naj~aY nafosahu Alharabu
[Until, when they went far in the land, pride returned to him: but, had he pleased, flight had saved his blood: J, however, assigns to the verb in this instance another signification, as will be seen below]. (M, TA.) ― -b3- dw~m said of a bird, (T, M, K,) inf. n. tadowiymN, (T, S,) (tropical:) It circled (Lth, T, S, M, K, TA) in the sky, (Lth, T, M, K,) as also tdAwm↓, (KL,) [or tadw~m↓, (see mutadaw~imaAtN,)] to rise high towards the sky; (S;) as also AstdAm↓: (M, K:) or circled in the sky, (M,) or flew, (T, * K,) without moving its wings; (T, M, K;) like the kite and the aquiline vulture: (T, TA:) or put itself into a state of commotion in its flying. (TA. [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.]) Dhu-r-Rummeh makes Alt~adowiym to be on the earth, or ground, in the verse cited above in this paragraph; [as though the meaning were, (assumed tropical:) Until, when they went round &c.;] As disallows this, and asserts that one says only daw~aY fiYAlA^aroDi, and daw~ama fiY Als~amaA='i; but some affirm that Alt~adowiymu fiYAlA^aroDi is correct; and say that hence is de rived Ald~uw~aAmapu↓, meaning “ the round thing [or top] which the boy throws, and makes to revolve, or spin, upon the ground, by means of a string; ” though others say that this is so called from the phrase daw~amotu Alqidora [explained below], because, by reason of the quickness of its revolving, or spinning, it seems as though it were at rest: and tadowaAmN is like tadowiymN: some, however, say that tadowiymu Alkalobi signifies the dog's going far in flight: (S:) AHeyth says that, accord. to As, Alt~adowiymu is only the act of a bird in the sky: (T, TA:) AAF says that, accord. to some, Alt~adowiymu is in the sky, and Alt~adowiyapu is on the earth, or ground; but accord. to others, the reverse is the case; and this, he says, is the truth in his opinion. (M, TA. [See also daw~aYa in art. dwY.]) ― -b4- You say also, daw~amati, Al$~amosu, (M, K,) or dw~mt Al$ms fY Als~amaA'i, (T,) or fiYkabidi Als~amaA='i, (S,) i. e. daArato fiY Als~amaA='i [or dArt fY kbd AlsmA', lit. (tropical:) The sun spun in the sky, or in the middle of the sky; meaning, was as though it were spinning]; (T, M, K;) or was as though it were motionless [&c.]: (T, S:) and hence is [said to be] derived the word duw~aAmapN↓ applied to the boy's revolving, or spinning, thing. (T.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, (describing the [insect called] junodab, [generally said to be a species of locust,] TA in art. rmD)
maEoraworiyFA ramaDa Alr~aDoraADi yarokuDuhu
waAl$~amosu HayoraY lahaA fiY Aljaw~i tadowiymu
(T, * S, TA) i. e. Venturing upon the [vehement] heat of the pebbles, [meaning the vehemently-hot pebbles,] striking them with its foot, for so the jndb does, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) when the sun is [apparently] stationary in the summer midday, [as though perplexed in its course,] as though having a spinning [in the region between heaven and earth]: (T, TA:) or as though it were motionless. (S.) ― -b5- And one says, daw~amato Eayonuhu (assumed tropical:) [His eye rolled; i. e.] the black of his eye revolved as though it were in the whirl of a spindle. (IAar, M, K.) ＝ -A2- [dw~m is also trans.] You say, dw~m Ald~uw~aAmapa, (M, K,) inf. n. tadowiymN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He made the dw~Amp [or top] to revolve, or spin [so as to seem to be at rest, as has been shown above]: (M, K:) or he played with the dw~Amp. (TA.) ― -b2- And dw~mt Alxamoru $aAribahaA (tropical:) The wine intoxicated its drinker so as to make him turn round about. (As, S, TA.) ― -b3- And daw~amuwA AlEamaAy^ima (assumed tropical:) They wound the turbans around their heads. (TA.) ― -b4- And dw~m Almaraqapa (assumed tropical:) He put much grease into the broth so that it swam round upon it. (M, K.) ― -b5- Alt~adowiymu [or app. tadowiymu All~isaAni] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The mumbling the tongue, and rolling it about in the mouth, in order that the saliva may not dry up: so says Fr. (S, TA.) ― -b6- [Hence, app., as the context seems to indicate,] Dhu-r-Rummeh says, describing a camel braying in his $iqo$iqap [or faucial bag],
daw~ama fiyhaA riz~ahu wa A^aroEadaA
[as though meaning (assumed tropical:) He made his braying to roll, or rumble, in it, and threatened]. (Fr, S, TA.) ― -b7- And dw~m signifies (tropical:) He moistened a thing. (S, M, K.) Ibn-Ahmar says,
waqado yudaw~imu riyqa AlT~aAmiEi AlA^amalu
(S, M;) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [And hope sometimes, or often,] moistens the saliva [of the eager]: (S:) he is praising En-Noamán Ibn-Besheer, and means that his hope moistens his saliva in his mouth by making his eulogy to continue. (IB.) ― -b8- (tropical:) He mixed, or moistened, or steeped, (daAfa,) saffron, (Lth, T, S, M, K, TA,) and stirred it round in doing so: (Lth, T, TA:) he dissolved saffron in water, and stirred it round therein. (A, TA.) ― -b9- dw~m Alqidora, and AdAmhA↓, (S, M, K,) He stilled the boiling of the cooking-pot by means of some [cold] water: (S:) or he sprinkled cold water upon [the contents of] the cooking-pot to still its boiling: (M, K:) or the former, (K,) or both, (M,) he allayed the boiling of the cooking-pot by means of something, (M, K,) and stilled it: (M:) and the latter signifies he left the cooking-pot upon the A^avaAfiY [or three stones that supported it], after it had been emptied, (Lh, M, K,) not putting it down nor kindling a fire beneath it. (Lh, M.)

3 dAwm EalaY AlA^amori *
, and dAwm AlA^amora: see 1. ＝ -A2- See also 10.

4 AdAmhu A^dAm A^dAmh A^dAmp A_dAm A_dAmh A_dAmp AdAmh AdAmp
, (inf. n. A_idaAmapN, TA,) trans. of daAma; (S, M, * Msb, K; *) [i. e.] i. q. jaEalahu daAy^imFA [He made it to continue, last, endure, or remain: to be extended, or prolonged: to continue, last, endure, or remain, long: and to continue, last, or exist, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; to be permanent, perpetual, or everlasting]: (TK:) he did it continually, or perpetually: (MA:) he had it continually, or perpetually. (MA, KL.) [Accord. to Golius, followed in this case by Freytag, tdAwm↓ signifies Perennitate donavit; a signification app. given by Golius as on the authority of the KL; but not in my copy of that work.] ― -b2- AdAm Alqidora: see 2, last sentence. ― -b3- AdAm Ald~alowa (assumed tropical:) He filled the bucket. (K, TA.) ― -b4- AlA_idaAmapN also signifies tanoqiyru Als~ahomi EalaY AlA_ibohaAmi [i. e. The trying the sonorific quality of the arrow by turning it round upon the thumb: or, as explained in this art. in the TK, the making the arrow to produce a sharp sound upon the thumb: or rather this or the former is the meaning of A_idaAmapu Als~ahomi; for, as is said in the TK, AdAm Als~ahoma signifies nqrh ElY AlAbhAm (i. e. nq~rhu)]. (T, K.) ＝ -A2- AdAmt Als~amaA='u: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- A^udiyma bihi: see 1, last sentence but one.

5 tadaw~ama
see 2: ― -b2- and see also 10.

6 tadaAowama
see 2: ― -b2- and see also 4.

10 AstdAm AstdAm {stdAm
: see 1. ― -b2- And see also 2. ― -b3- And Ausotudiyma: see 1, last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- As a trans. v., (T,) i. q. AinotaZara, (Sb, T, TA,) as also tdw~m↓, (K, [or this may perhaps be used only without an objective complement expressed,]) and raqaba, (T,) or taraq~aba: (Sh, TA:) you say, Aisotadimo ka*aA, meaning AinotaZirohu and Auroqubohu (assumed tropical:) [Look thou for, expect, await, wait for, or watch for, such a
thing.] (T.) [When no objective complement is expressed, it seems to mean (assumed tropical:) He paused, and acted with deliberation, or in a patient or leisurely manner, or he waited in expectation; app. from the same verb as syn. with daw~ama; and thus, like one who hovers about a thing: see Haw~ama; and see also AinotaZara.] And AstdAmhu (tropical:) He acted with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely, in it; (S, M, K, TA;) namely, an affair, or a case: (S:) or he sought, desired, asked, or demanded, its continuance, or long continuance, or endless continuance: and so dAwmhu↓ (M, K, TA) in both of these senses: (K, TA:) or he asked him to render a thing continual &c.: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) and also (assumed tropical:) he acted gently and deliberately in it; namely, an affair, or a case: (Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) he acted gently with him; (Fr, T in art. dym, M, Msb, Kt;) i. e., another person, (Msb,) or his creditor; as also AisotadomaAhu, (Fr, T, M, K,) which we judge to be formed from the former by transposition, because we do not find it [in this sense] to have any inf. n. (M.) A poet says, (T, S, Msb,) namely, Keys Ibn-Zuheyr, (S,)
falaA taEojalo biA^amorika waA@sotadimohu
famaA Sal~aY EaSaAka kamusotadiymi↓
(T, S, Msb,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Therefore haste not in thine affair, but act with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely, therein]; for no one has straightened thy staff by turning it round over the fire, (T,) meaning, no one has managed thine affair soundly, like one who acts with moderation, &c. (T, Msb.) And another says, (S,) namely, Mejnoon, (TA,)
waA_in~aY EalaY layolaY lazaArK waA_in~aniY
EalaY*aAka fiymaA bayonanaA A^asotadiymuhaA
meaning (assumed tropical:) [And verily I am blaming Leylà; and verily, notwithstanding that,] I look for her aiding me by good conduct [in the matter that is between us]. (S.) You say also, A^asotadiymu A@ll~`ha niEomataka I seek, or desire, or ask, of God the continuance, or long continuance, or endless continuance, of thy favour, or the like. (Mgh, TA. *) And A^asotadiymu A@ll~`ha Eiz~aka I ask God to continue, or continue long, &c., thy might, or power, &c. (Msb.) The phrase AstdAm lubosa Alv~awobi, meaning [He continued long the wearing of the garment, or] he did not hasten to pull off the garment, may be from the saying Aisotadamotu EaAqibapa AlA^amori, meaning I looked, or watched, or waited, for the end, or issue, or result, of the affair, or case. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- Also He (a man) stooped his head, blood dropping from it: formed by transposition from AisotadomaY (Kr, TA.)

daAmN dAm dAmy
for daAy^imN: see the latter word.

dawomN dwm
an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, Msb, K.) — [Hence,] maA zaAlati Als~amaA='u dawomFA dawomFA The sky ceased not to rain [in the manner of the rain termed diymap]; and so dayomFA dayomFA↓; (M, K; [in the CK, erroneously, diyomFA diyomFA;]) in which the Y is interchangeable with the w; (M;) mentioned by AHn, on the authority of Fr. (TA.) ― -b2- See also daAy^imN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also [The cucifera Thebaïca; (Delile, “ Floræ Ægypt. Illustr., ” no. 941;) or Theban Palm; so called because abundant in the Thebaïs; a species of fan-palm; by some called gingerbread: accord. to Forskål, (under the heading of “ Flora Arabiæ Felicis, ” in his “ Flora Ægypt. Arab., ” p. cxxvi.,) Borassus flabelliformis; a name applied (after him) by Sonnini to the Theban palm; but now generally used by botanists to designate another species of fan-palm:] the tree of the muqol; (S, M, Msb, K;) a well-known kind of tree, of which the fruit is [called] the muqol: (TA:) n. un. with p: AHn says that the dawomap [is a tree that] becomes thick and tall, and has [leaves of the kind termed] xuwS, like the xwS of the date-palm, and racemes like the racemes of a date-palm. (M, TA.) Accord. to Aboo-Ziyád El-Aarábee, (AHn, M,) The nabiq [which properly signifies the fruit of the sidor, but here app. means, as it does in the present day, the tree called sidor, a species of lote-tree, called by Linn. rhamnus spina Christi, and by Forskal rhamnus nabeca,] is also thus called, (AHn, M, K,) by some of the Arabs: accord. to 'Omárah, great [trees of the kind termed] sidor: (AHn, M:) and, (M, K,) accord. to IAar, (M,) big trees of any kind. (M, K.) [See also dawomapN, below.]

dayomN dym dymp
, whence the saying maA zaAlati Als~amaA='u dayomFA dayomFA: see dawomN.

diyomN dym dymp
: see diymapN.

dawomapN dwm dwmh dwmp
n. un. of dawomN. (M, TA.) [Also, app., as in the present day, and as appears from what follows, A single fruit of the tree called dawom.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A testicle; (K;) as being likened to the fruit of the dawom. (TA.) ― -b3- [Golius also explains it, as on the authority of the K, as meaning “ Ebriosa mulier; ” and Freytag, as meaning “ mulier vinum vendens: ” both are wrong: it is mentioned in the K as the name of a woman who sold wine.]

diymapN dymh dymp
A lasting, or continuous, and still rain: (As, M, and TA voce DarobN, q. v.:) or rain in which is neither thunder nor lightning; the least of which is the third of a day or the third of a night; and the most thereof, of any period: (AZ, S in art. dym:) or rain that continues some days: (Msb:) or rain that continues long and is still, without thunder and lightning: (K, * TA:) or rain that continues five days, or six, (M, K,) or seven, (K,) or a day and a night, (T in art. dym, M, K,) or more; (T, TA;) or the least whereof is a third of a day or of a night; and the most thereof, of any period: (K, TA:) pl. diyamN, (S, M, K,) the w being changed [into Y] in the pl. because it is changed in the sing., (M,) and duyuwmN, (Abu-l-'Omeythil, T, K,) and [coll. gen. n.] diyomN↓ (Sh, T, TA.) [See also mudaAmN.] ― -b2- Hence other things are thus termed by way of comparison. (S.) It is said in a trad. (S, M) of 'Áïsheh, (M,) kaAna Eamaluhu diymapF (S, M, Msb) (assumed tropical:) His work was incessant [but moderate, or not excessive]; (Msb;) referring to Mohammad; (T, S, M, Msb;) on her being asked if he preferred some days to others: (T:) she likened it to the rain termed dymp in respect of continuance and moderation. (T, M.) And it is related of Hudheyfeh that he said, mentioning fitan [i. e. trials, or probations, or conflicts and factions, &c.], A_in~ahaA laA=tiyatukumo diymFA diymFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Verily they are coming to you] filling the earth, or land, [and] with continuance. (T.)

daAmaA='u dAmA='
(in the CK [erroneously] daA^omA'u) The sea, or a great river; syn. baHorN; (M, K;) because of the continuance of its water: (M:) originally dawamaA='u, or dawomaA='u: if the latter, the change of the w into A is anomalous. (TA.)

Ald~awamaA='u AldwmA='
: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

dayomuwmN dymwm
and dayomuwmapN, held by Aboo-'Alee to be from Ald~awaAmu, and therefore to belong to the present art.: (TA:) see art. dm. ＝ -A2- The latter is also an inf. n. of daAma [q. v.]. (S, M, Msb, K.)

duwaAmN dwAm
(tropical:) A vertigo, or giddiness in the head; i. q. duwaArN (S, * M, * K, TA. [In the CK, dawA'N is erroneously put for duwaArN.]) You say, A^axa*ahu duwaAmN (tropical:) [A vertigo took him, or attacked him]. (S.) And bihi duwaAmN (tropical:) [He has a vertigo]. (As, TA.)

duw~aAmN dwAm
: see what next follows.

duw~aAmapN dwAm dwAmh dwAmp
(assumed tropical:) The falokap [or round thing, i. e. top,] which the boy throws, and makes to revolve, or spin, upon the ground, by means of a string: (S, M, * K: *) the derivation of the word has been explained above: see 2, in two places: (T, S:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] duw~aAmN↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- duw~aAmapu AlbaHori (assumed tropical:) [The whirlpool of the sea; so in the present day;] the middle of the sea, upon which the waves circle (tdwm [i. e. tudaw~im]). (TA.)

daAy^imN *

duwnF dwn dwnn
Low, base, vile, mean, paltry, inconsiderable, or contemptible; (Fr, T, S, M, * Msb, K;) applied to a man &c.: (T, Msb:) and inferior, i. e. lower, baser, viler, &c., in grounds of pretension to respect or honour [or in any approvable quality]: (Lth, T:) and such as falls short [of a thing]; used in this sense as a prefixed noun: (Ham p. 686:) [see below what is said of its usage as a prefixed noun by Lth and by Sb: and used as an epithet, scanty, or deficient; applied to anything:] and of a middling sort; between good and bad; applied to a man and to a commodity: (M:) and also high, or eminent, in rank or condition; noble, or honourable: (T, K:) thus it bears two contr. significations (K) [and significations intermediate between those two]. A poet says,
A_i*aA maA EalaA Almaro'u raAma AlEalaA='
wayaqotaEu biAld~uwni mano kaAnaA duwnaA
[When the man is high in rank, or nobility, he seeks highness: and he who is low is content with that which is low]. (S.) Accord. to the most common usage, (Msb,) or accord. to what is asserted to be the most common usage, (Lh, M,) one says rajulN mino duwnK (T, M, Msb, K) and $aYo'N mino duwnK (M, Msb) A man who is [of a kind that is] low, base, &c., and a thing that is [of a kind that is] low, base, &c.: (Msb:) but sometimes they said rajulN duwnN and $aYo'N duwnN, without mino; (M, Msb;) and vawobN duwnN a bad [or an inferior] garment, or piece of cloth: (M:) or one should not say rajulN duwnN; (T, K;) for the Arabs did not use this phrase. (T.) Accord. to Lth, one says, h`*aA duwnu *aAka [This is the inferior of that], when meaning to denote by it low estimation, using the nom. case: (T:) [but this is uncommon, if allowable:] Sb says that duwn is not used in the nom. case as a prefixed noun: as to the saying in the Kur [lxxii. 11, an instance similar to which occurs also in vii. 167], min~aA AlS~aAliHuwna wa min~aA duwna *`lika, the meaning is, wa min~aA qawomN duwna *`lika [i. e. Of us are the righteous, and of us are a party below that party in rank or estimation]; (M, TA;) or, as another says, dwn is here in the accus. case but in the place of a noun in the nom. case because it is generally used as an adv. n. (TA.) ― -b2- As an adv. n., duwn signifies Below, contr. of fawoq; (S, K;) as denoting a falling short of the [right or approved] limit; (S;) or denoting low, or mean, estimation or condition; (Lth, T, M;) or a condition lower, baser, viler, &c., than that of another, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour [or in any approvable quality]; (Lth, T;) [and hence, inferior to, beneath, under, or short of, another in rank, height, size, &c.;] and less than another, and more deficient than another: (Fr, T:) and also above; i. q. fawoq; (T, K;) in highness, or eminence, of rank or condition, or in nobility; (T;) [and hence, exceeding another, and more than another:] thus bearing two contr. significations. (K.) You say, zayodN duwnaka meaning Zeyd is [below thee, or] in a condition lower, baser, viler, &c., than thine, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour [&c.]: and when one says, “ Verily such a one is high, or eminent, in rank or condition, ” or “ is noble, ” another replies, wa duwna *`lika meaning And above that. (T.) ― -b3- Also Beneath, below in situation, or under; syn. taHot. (T, TA.) Using it in this sense, you say, duwan qadamika xad~u Eaduw~ika [May the cheek of thine enemy be beneath thy foot]: (T, TA:) and jalasa duwnahu [He sat below him]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Before in respect of place, or in front: and [the contr., namely,] behind, or beyond. (T, M, K.) [You may say, using it in the former sense, jalasa duwnahu He sat before him, or in front of him: (see Ham p. 86:) and, using it in the latter sense,] you say, h`*aA A^amiyrN EalaY maA duwna jayoHuwna This [man] is governor, or prince, over what is beyond [the river] Jeyhoon. (TA.) ― -b5- And i. q. qabol [generally signifying Before in respect of time; but as some say, in respect of place also, which may perhaps be here meant]: (T:) and [the contr., namely,] i. q. baEod [generally meaning after in respect of time; but as
some say, in respect of place also, which may perhaps be here meant]. (Fr, T, TA.) ― -b6- It signifies also Nearer than another thing: (S, Msb, K:) so in the phrase h`*aA duwna *`lika [This is nearer than that]; (S Msb;) or h`*aA duwnahu [this is nearer than he, or it]. (K.) [Hence,] one says also, Audonu duwnaka meaning Draw thou near in the space that is between me and thee: (A Heyth, T:) [or approach thou nearer to me:] or draw thou near [or nearer] to me. (IAar, T, M, K.) And yaziydu baguD~u AlT~arofa duwniY, a saying of a poet, means Yezeed lowers the eye towards a spot between me and him. (A Heyth, T.) [xa$aEato duwnahu AlA^aboSaAru, also, has a similar meaning: see 1 in art. x$E. So, too, has the phrase, xaAwata Tarofahu duwniY: see 3 in art. xwt. And hence,] one says, duwna Aln~ahori jamaAEapN [In the way of, or to, the river, or on this side of the river, or nearer than the river, is a company of men; or] before thy reaching the river [there is to be found, or encountered, a company of men]. (K.) And duwna qatoli AlA^asadi A^ahowaAlN [In the way of, or to, the slaying of the lion, or] before thine attaining to the slaying of the lion, terrors [are to be encountered]. (T, TA.) [And duwnahu xaroTu AlqataAdi: see 1 in art. xrT.] And HaAla duwna Al$~aYo'i [It intervened as an obstacle in the way to the thing; or] it prevented from attaining the thing. (W p. 71.) [And layosa duwnahu $aYo'N There is nothing intervening as an obstacle in the way of, or to, him, or it.] And [hence,] qutila duwna maAlihi, and nafosihi, and A^axiyhi, and jaArihi, He was slain in defence of his property, and of himself, and of his brother, and of his neighbour. (Occurring in a trad. commencing with the words Algariyqu $ahiydN, in the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer, ” and thus explained in the margin of a copy of that work.) [And nabaHa duwnahu is a modern phrase meaning (assumed tropical:) He defended him as though by barking in the way to him.] ― -b7- [Hence,] also i. q. EalaY [as meaning Against; denoting defence by means of intervention: see an ex. in a verse cited voce $axoSN]. (Fr, T, TA.) ― -b8- And i. q. Einoda [meaning At, near, nigh, by, or near by; with, or present with; &c.]. (Fr, T, Ibn-Es-Seed.) Accord. to Ez-Zowzanee, it has this meaning in the saying of Imra-el-Keys, [describing a horse,]
faA^aloHaqanaA biAlhaAdiyaAti wa duwnahu
jawaAHiruhaA fiY Sar~apK lamo tuzay~ali
(TA, but only the former hemistich is there given,) i. e. And he made us to overtake the foremost of the wild animals, while near to him were those that lagged behind, in a herd, not dispersed. (EM p. 48.) ― -b9- And i. q. gayor [as meaning Other than, beside, or besides, exclusively of, or not as used before a substantive or an adjective]. (K.) Hence, in the Kur [xxi. 82], wayaEomaluwna EamalFA duwna *`lika [And who should do work other than, or beside, that]. (Fr, TA.) And in the same [iv. 51 and 116], wayagofiru maA duwna *`lika But He will forgive what is other than that: or, as some say, what is less than that. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And so, it is said, in the trad., layosa fiymaA duwna xamosi A^awaAqK SadaqapN [There is no poor-rate to be exacted in the case of what is other than, or not, or, rather less than, five ounces]. (K.) So, too, it is said to mean in the trad., A^ajaAza AlxuloEa duwna EiqaASi raA^osihaA [He allowed the divorcing a wife for a gift, or compensation, other than the EiqaAS (q. v.) of her head: in the CK, in which AlxaloEu is erroneously put for AlxuloEa, this is given as an ex. of *uwna in the sense of sawiY, which is syn. with gayor]: or the meaning is, for anything, even for the EqAS of her head. (K, TA.) ― -b10- It is also used (M, K, TA) as a subst. (M, TA) with mino prefixed to it, [very often in this case, in the Kur and elsewhere, as meaning gayor and sometimes in other senses explained above,] and likewise with bi (M, K, TA,) though rarely. (K.) One says, h`*aA duwnaka and h`*aA mino duwnika [This is below thee, or above thee: &c.]. (M, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxviii. 23], wawajada mino duwnihimu A@moraA^atayoni (M, TA) And he found in a place below them two women: (Bd:) or beside them, or exclusively of them. (Jel.) One says also, h`daA liYduwna laka or mino duwnika [meaning This belongs to me exclusively of thee]; i. e. thou hast no right nor share [with me] in this. (Kull p. 186.) The phrase fiyhimo mano layosa biduwnihi [app. as meaning Among whom was such as was not below him in respect of knowledge of poetry] is used by Akh in his book on rhymes. (M, TA.) ― -b11- It also denotes a command, (T, K,) and an incitement (Fr, T, S, K) to do a thing. (S.) Using it in the former sense, you say, duwnaka Ald~irohama, meaning Take thou the dirhem; (T;) or duwnaka Al$~aYo'a and duwnaka biAl$~aYo'i, meaning Take thou the thing: (M:) and using it in the latter sense, you say, duwnakahu, (S, K, TA,) meaning Keep thou, cleave thou, cling thou, or hold thou fast, to him; and take care of him: (TA:) or dunaka zayodFA Keep thou, &c., to Zeyd, taking care of him. (T.) Temeem [meaning a party of the tribe so named] said to El-Hajjáj, when he had slain, i. e. crucified, Sálih Ibn-' Abd-Er-Rahmán, “ Permit us to bury Sálih: ” and he replied, duwnakumuwhu [Take ye him]. (S, TA.) ― -b12- And it also denotes a threat. (T, K.) So in the sayings duwaka SiraAEiY [Beware thou of wrestling with me] and duwnaka fatamar~aso biY [Beware thou, and then set thyself against me to do evil if thou canst]. (T, TA.) ― -b13- It is said that no verb is derived from it: (T, S, M, Msb:) but some assert that daAna and A^udiyna [mentioned in the first paragraph of this art.] are derived from it. (S.) ― -b14- The dim. of duwna is duwayona↓: (Ham p. 404:) and duwayonapa↓ occurs as a dim. in a verse of a post-classical poet; but, [ISd says,] of what word I know not, unless they said duwnapa↓ [for duwna]. (M.)
